scenes.title: The Muse's Invocation
scenes.summary: The narrator calls upon the Muse to recount Ulysses' journey.
scenes.text:
Tell me, 'Muse, of that ingenious her'wh'travelled far and wide
after he had sacked the famous town of Troy. Many cities did he visit,
and many were the nations with whose manners and customs he was
acquainted; moreover he suffered much by sea while trying t'save his
own life and bring his men safely home; but d'what he might he could
not save his men, for they perished through their own sheer folly in
eating the cattle of the Sun-god Hyperion; s'the god prevented them
from ever reaching home. Tell me, too, about all these things, oh
daughter of Jove, from whatsoever source you may know them.

characters.name: Journey And Suffering
characters.role: Highlights the protagonist's struggles during his travels

scenes.title: Ulysses' Trials
scenes.summary: Ulysses is detained by Calypso after the fall of Troy.
scenes.text:
S'now all wh'escaped death in battle or by shipwreck had got safely
home except Ulysses, and he, though he was longing t'return t'his
wife and country, was detained by the goddess Calypso, wh'had got him
int'a large cave and wanted t'marry him. But as years went by, there
came a time when the gods settled that he should g'back t'Ithaca;
even then, however, when he was among his own people, his troubles were
not yet over; nevertheless all the gods had now begun t'pity him
except Neptune, wh'still persecuted him without ceasing and would not
let him get home.

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.role: Ulysses desires to return home to Ithaca and his wife.
characters.quote: he was longing t'return t'his wife and country

characters.role: The gods influence Ulysses' fate and journey.

scenes.title: The Gods' Council
scenes.summary: The gods discuss Ulysses' fate and Neptune's wrath.
scenes.text:
Now Neptune had gone off t'the Ethiopians, wh'are at the world's end,
and lie in tw'halves, the one looking West and the other East.1 He had
gone there t'accept a hecatomb of sheep and oxen, and was enjoying
himself at his festival; but the other gods met in the house of
Olympian Jove, and the sire of gods and men spoke first. At that moment
he was thinking of Aegisthus, wh'had been killed by Agamemnon's son
Orestes; s'he said t'the other gods:
"See now, how men lay blame upon us gods for what is after all nothing
but their own folly. Look at Aegisthus; he must needs make love to
Agamemnon's wife unrighteously and then kill Agamemnon, though he knew
it would be the death of him; for I sent Mercury t'warn him not t'do
either of these things, inasmuch as Orestes would be sure t'take his
revenge when he grew up and wanted t'return home. Mercury told him
this in all good will but he would not listen, and now he has paid for
everything in full."
Then Minerva said, "Father, son of Saturn, King of kings, it served
Aegisthus right, and s'it would any one else wh'does as he did; but
Aegisthus is neither here nor there; it is for Ulysses that my heart
bleeds, when I think of his sufferings in that lonely sea-girt island,
far away, poor man, from all his friends. It is an island covered with
forest, in the very middle of the sea, and a goddess lives there,
daughter of the magician Atlas, wh'looks after the bottom of the
ocean, and carries the great columns that keep heaven and earth
asunder. This daughter of Atlas has got hold of poor unhappy Ulysses,
and keeps trying by every kind of blandishment t'make him forget his
home, s'that he is tired of life, and thinks of nothing but how he may
once more see the smoke of his own chimneys. You, sir, take n'heed of
this, and yet when Ulysses was before Troy did he not propitiate you
with many a burnt sacrifice? Why then should you keep on being s'angry
with him?"
And Jove said, "My child, what are you talking about? How can I forget
Ulysses than whom there is n'more capable man on earth, nor more
liberal in his offerings t'the immortal gods that live in heaven? Bear
in mind, however, that Neptune is still furious with Ulysses for having
blinded an eye of Polyphemus king of the Cyclopes. Polyphemus is son to
Neptune by the nymph Thoosa, daughter t'the sea-king Phorcys;
therefore though he will not kill Ulysses outright, he torments him by
preventing him from getting home. Still, let us lay our heads together
and see how we can help him t'return; Neptune will then be pacified,
for if we are all of a mind he can hardly stand out against us."

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Explains the consequences of human folly
characters.quote: See now, how men lay blame upon us gods for what is after all nothing but their own folly.

characters.name: Journey And Suffering
characters.role: Highlights Ulysses' plight and longing for home
characters.quote: it is for Ulysses that my heart bleeds, when I think of his sufferings in that lonely sea-girt island, far away, poor man, from all his friends.

scenes.title: Minerva's Plan
scenes.summary: Minerva devises a plan to help Ulysses and Telemachus.
scenes.text:
And Minerva said, "Father, son of Saturn, King of kings, if, then, the
gods now mean that Ulysses should get home, we should first send
Mercury t'the Ogygian island t'tell Calyps'that we have made up our
minds and that he is t'return. In the meantime I will g't'Ithaca, to
put heart int'Ulysses' son Telemachus; I will embolden him t'call the
Achaeans in assembly, and speak out t'the suitors of his mother
Penelope, wh'persist in eating up any number of his sheep and oxen; I
will als'conduct him t'Sparta and t'Pylos, t'see if he can hear
anything about the return of his dear father—for this will make people
speak well of him."

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The gods decide Ulysses' fate.
characters.quote: And Minerva said, "Father, son of Saturn, King of kings, if, then, the gods now mean that Ulysses should get home..."

characters.quote: I will als'conduct him t'Sparta and t'Pylos, t'see if he can hear anything about the return of his dear father...

characters.quote: ...and speak out t'the suitors of his mother Penelope, wh'persist in eating up any number of his sheep and oxen;

scenes.title: Telemachus Meets Minerva
scenes.summary: Telemachus meets Minerva disguised as Mentes.
scenes.text:
S'saying she bound on her glittering golden sandals, imperishable,
with which she can fly like the wind over land or sea; she grasped the
redoubtable bronze-shod spear, s'stout and sturdy and strong,
wherewith she quells the ranks of heroes wh'have displeased her, and
down she darted from the topmost summits of Olympus, whereon forthwith
she was in Ithaca, at the gateway of Ulysses' house, disguised as a
visitor, Mentes, chief of the Taphians, and she held a bronze spear in
her hand. There she found the lordly suitors seated on hides of the
oxen which they had killed and eaten, and playing draughts in front of
the house. Men-servants and pages were bustling about t'wait upon
them, some mixing wine with water in the mixing-bowls, some cleaning
down the tables with wet sponges and laying them out again, and some
cutting up great quantities of meat.
Telemachus saw her long before any one else did. He was sitting moodily
among the suitors thinking about his brave father, and how he would
send them flying out of the house, if he were t'come t'his own again
and be honoured as in days gone by. Thus brooding as he sat among them,
he caught sight of Minerva and went straight t'the gate, for he was
vexed that a stranger should be kept waiting for admittance. He took
her right hand in his own, and bade her give him her spear. "Welcome,"
said he, "t'our house, and when you have partaken of food you shall
tell us what you have come for."
He led the way as he spoke, and Minerva followed him. When they were
within he took her spear and set it in the spear-stand against a strong
bearing-post along with the many other spears of his unhappy father,
and he conducted her t'a richly decorated seat under which he threw a
cloth of damask. There was a footstool als'for her feet,2 and he set
another seat near her for himself, away from the suitors, that she
might not be annoyed while eating by their noise and insolence, and
that he might ask her more freely about his father.

scenes.title: The Suitors' Banquet
scenes.summary: The suitors feast in Ulysses' house, causing trouble.
scenes.text:
A maid servant then brought them water in a beautiful golden ewer and
poured it int'a silver basin for them t'wash their hands, and she
drew a clean table beside them. An upper servant brought them bread,
and offered them many good things of what there was in the house, the
carver fetched them plates of all manner of meats and set cups of gold
by their side, and a manservant brought them wine and poured it out for
them.
Then the suitors came in and took their places on the benches and
seats.3 Forthwith men servants poured water over their hands, maids
went round with the bread-baskets, pages filled the mixing-bowls with
wine and water, and they laid their hands upon the good things that
were before them. As soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink they

scenes.title: Telemachus' Grief
scenes.summary: Telemachus expresses his sorrow over his father's absence.
scenes.text:
wanted music and dancing, which are the crowning embellishments of a
banquet, s'a servant brought a lyre t'Phemius, whom they compelled
perforce t'sing t'them. As soon as he touched his lyre and began to
sing Telemachus spoke low t'Minerva, with his head close t'hers that
n'man might hear.
"I hope, sir," said he, "that you will not be offended with what I am
going t'say. Singing comes cheap t'those wh'd'not pay for it, and
all this is done at the cost of one whose bones lie rotting in some
wilderness or grinding t'powder in the surf. If these men were t'see
my father come back t'Ithaca they would pray for longer legs rather
than a longer purse, for money would not serve them; but he, alas, has
fallen on an ill fate, and even when people d'sometimes say that he is
coming, we n'longer heed them; we shall never see him again. And now,
sir, tell me and tell me true, wh'you are and where you come from.

characters.role: Expressing sorrow over Odysseus' fate

scenes.title: Minerva's Identity Revealed
scenes.summary: Minerva reveals her true identity to Telemachus.
scenes.text:
Tell me of your town and parents, what manner of ship you came in, how
your crew brought you t'Ithaca, and of what nation they declared
themselves t'be—for you cannot have come by land. Tell me als'truly,
for I want t'know, are you a stranger t'this house, or have you been
here in my father's time? In the old days we had many visitors for my
father went about much himself."
And Minerva answered, "I will tell you truly and particularly all about
it. I am Mentes, son of Anchialus, and I am King of the Taphians. I
have come here with my ship and crew, on a voyage t'men of a foreign
tongue being bound for Temesa4 with a carg'of iron, and I shall bring
back copper. As for my ship, it lies over yonder off the open country
away from the town, in the harbour Rheithron5 under the wooded mountain
Neritum.6 Our fathers were friends before us, as old Laertes will tell
you, if you will g'and ask him. They say, however, that he never comes
t'town now, and lives by himself in the country, faring hardly, with
an old woman t'look after him and get his dinner for him, when he
comes in tired from pottering about his vineyard. They told me your
father was at home again, and that was why I came, but it seems the
gods are still keeping him back, for he is not dead yet not on the
mainland. It is more likely he is on some sea-girt island in mid ocean,
or a prisoner among savages wh'are detaining him against his will. I
am n'prophet, and know very little about omens, but I speak as it is
borne in upon me from heaven, and assure you that he will not be away
much longer; for he is a man of such resource that even though he were
in chains of iron he would find some means of getting home again. But
tell me, and tell me true, can Ulysses really have such a fine looking
fellow for a son? You are indeed wonderfully like him about the head
and eyes, for we were close friends before he set sail for Troy where
the flower of all the Argives went also. Since that time we have never
either of us seen the other."

characters.name: Identity
characters.role: Exploration of lineage and recognition
characters.quote: you are indeed wonderfully like him about the head and eyes, for we were close friends before he set sail for Troy where the flower of all the Argives went also.

scenes.title: Telemachus' Resolve
scenes.summary: Telemachus vows to seek news of his father.
scenes.text:
"My mother," answered Telemachus, "tells me I am son t'Ulysses, but it
is a wise child that knows his own father. Would that I were son t'one
wh'had grown old upon his own estates, for, since you ask me, there is
n'more ill-starred man under heaven than he wh'they tell me is my
father."
And Minerva said, "There is n'fear of your race dying out yet, while
Penelope has such a fine son as you are. But tell me, and tell me true,
what is the meaning of all this feasting, and wh'are these people?
What is it all about? Have you some banquet, or is there a wedding in
the family—for n'one seems t'be bringing any provisions of his own?
And the guests—how atrociously they are behaving; what riot they make
over the whole house; it is enough t'disgust any respectable person
wh'comes near them."
"Sir," said Telemachus, "as regards your question, s'long as my father
was here it was well with us and with the house, but the gods in their
displeasure have willed it otherwise, and have hidden him away more
closely than mortal man was ever yet hidden. I could have borne it
better even though he were dead, if he had fallen with his men before
Troy, or had died with friends around him when the days of his fighting
were done; for then the Achaeans would have built a mound over his
ashes, and I should myself have been heir t'his renown; but now the
storm-winds have spirited him away we know not whither; he is gone
without leaving s'much as a trace behind him, and I inherit nothing
but dismay. Nor does the matter end simply with grief for the loss of
my father; heaven has laid sorrows upon me of yet another kind; for the
chiefs from all our islands, Dulichium, Same, and the woodland island
of Zacynthus, as als'all the principal men of Ithaca itself, are
eating up my house under the pretext of paying their court t'my
mother, wh'will neither point blank say that she will not marry,7 nor
yet bring matters t'an end; s'they are making havoc of my estate, and
before long will d's'als'with myself."
"Is that so?" exclaimed Minerva, "then you d'indeed want Ulysses home
again. Give him his helmet, shield, and a couple of lances, and if he
is the man he was when I first knew him in our house, drinking and
making merry, he would soon lay his hands about these rascally suitors,
were he t'stand once more upon his own threshold. He was then coming
from Ephyra, where he had been t'beg poison for his arrows from Ilus,
son of Mermerus. Ilus feared the ever-living gods and would not give
him any, but my father let him have some, for he was very fond of him.
If Ulysses is the man he then was these suitors will have a short
shrift and a sorry wedding.
"But there! It rests with heaven t'determine whether he is t'return,
and take his revenge in his own house or no; I would, however, urge you
t'set about trying t'get rid of these suitors at once. Take my
advice, call the Achaean heroes in assembly to-morrow morning—lay your
case before them, and call heaven t'bear you witness. Bid the suitors
take themselves off, each t'his own place, and if your mother's mind
is set on marrying again, let her g'back t'her father, wh'will find
her a husband and provide her with all the marriage gifts that s'dear
a daughter may expect. As for yourself, let me prevail upon you t'take
the best ship you can get, with a crew of twenty men, and g'in quest
of your father wh'has s'long been missing. Some one may tell you
something, or (and people often hear things in this way) some
heaven-sent message may direct you. First g't'Pylos and ask Nestor;
thence g'on t'Sparta and visit Menelaus, for he got home last of all
the Achaeans; if you hear that your father is alive and on his way
home, you can put up with the waste these suitors will make for yet
another twelve months. If on the other hand you hear of his death, come
home at once, celebrate his funeral rites with all due pomp, build a
barrow t'his memory, and make your mother marry again. Then, having
done all this, think it well over in your mind how, by fair means or
foul, you may kill these suitors in your own house. You are to'old to
plead infancy any longer; have you not heard how people are singing
Orestes' praises for having killed his father's murderer Aegisthus? You
are a fine, smart looking fellow; show your mettle, then, and make
yourself a name in story. Now, however, I must g'back t'my ship and
t'my crew, wh'will be impatient if I keep them waiting longer; think
the matter over for yourself, and remember what I have said t'you."

characters.quote: I could have borne it better even though he were dead, if he had fallen with his men before Troy, or had died with friends around him when the days of his fighting were done; for then the Achaeans would have built a mound over his ashes, and I should myself have been heir t'his renown; but now the storm-winds have spirited him away we know not whither; he is gone without leaving s'much as a trace behind him, and I inherit nothing but dismay.

scenes.title: Penelope's Mourning
scenes.summary: Penelope mourns for Ulysses during the suitors' feast.
scenes.text:
"Sir," answered Telemachus, "it has been very kind of you t'talk t'me
in this way, as though I were your own son, and I will d'all you tell
me; I know you want t'be getting on with your voyage, but stay a
little longer till you have taken a bath and refreshed yourself. I will
then give you a present, and you shall g'on your way rejoicing; I will
give you one of great beauty and value—a keepsake such as only dear
friends give t'one another."
Minerva answered, "D'not try t'keep me, for I would be on my way at
once. As for any present you may be disposed t'make me, keep it till I
come again, and I will take it home with me. You shall give me a very
good one, and I will give you one of n'less value in return."
With these words she flew away like a bird int'the air, but she had
given Telemachus courage, and had made him think more than ever about
his father. He felt the change, wondered at it, and knew that the
stranger had been a god, s'he went straight t'where the suitors were
sitting.
Phemius was still singing, and his hearers sat rapt in silence as he
told the sad tale of the return from Troy, and the ills Minerva had
laid upon the Achaeans. Penelope, daughter of Icarius, heard his song
from her room upstairs, and came down by the great staircase, not
alone, but attended by tw'of her handmaids. When she reached the
suitors she stood by one of the bearing posts that supported the roof
of the cloisters8 with a staid maiden on either side of her. She held a
veil, moreover, before her face, and was weeping bitterly.
"Phemius," she cried, "you know many another feat of gods and heroes,
such as poets love t'celebrate. Sing the suitors some one of these,
and let them drink their wine in silence, but cease this sad tale, for
it breaks my sorrowful heart, and reminds me of my lost husband whom I
mourn ever without ceasing, and whose name was great over all Hellas
and middle Argos."9
"Mother," answered Telemachus, "let the bard sing what he has a mind
to; bards d'not make the ills they sing of; it is Jove, not they, who
makes them, and wh'sends weal or woe upon mankind according t'his own
good pleasure. This fellow means n'harm by singing the ill-fated
return of the Danaans, for people always applaud the latest songs most
warmly. Make up your mind t'it and bear it; Ulysses is not the only
man wh'never came back from Troy, but many another went down as well
as he. Go, then, within the house and busy yourself with your daily
duties, your loom, your distaff, and the ordering of your servants; for
speech is man's matter, and mine above all others 10—for it is I wh'am
master here."
She went wondering back int'the house, and laid her son's saying in
her heart. Then, going upstairs with her handmaids int'her room, she
mourned her dear husband till Minerva shed sweet sleep over her eyes.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Minerva provides Telemachus with courage and wisdom.
characters.quote: she had given Telemachus courage, and had made him think more than ever about his father.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.role: Penelope mourns for her husband, reflecting the theme of loss.
characters.quote: it breaks my sorrowful heart, and reminds me of my lost husband whom I mourn ever without ceasing.

characters.fake_quote: This theme reflects a defiant and assertive emotion as the character claims mastery over speech, emphasizing their dominance in the situation.

scenes.title: Telemachus' Confrontation
scenes.summary: Telemachus confronts the suitors about their behavior.
scenes.text:
But the suitors were clamorous throughout the covered cloisters11, and
prayed each one that he might be her bed fellow.
Then Telemachus spoke, "Shameless," he cried, "and insolent suitors,
let us feast at our pleasure now, and let there be n'brawling, for it
is a rare thing t'hear a man with such a divine voice as Phemius has;
but in the morning meet me in full assembly that I may give you formal
notice t'depart, and feast at one another's houses, turn and turn
about, at your own cost. If on the other hand you choose t'persist in
spunging upon one man, heaven help me, but Jove shall reckon with you
in full, and when you fall in my father's house there shall be n'man
t'avenge you."
The suitors bit their lips as they heard him, and marvelled at the

scenes.title: The Suitors' Response
scenes.summary: The suitors react to Telemachus' boldness.
scenes.text:
boldness of his speech. Then, Antinous, son of Eupeithes, said, "The
gods seem t'have given you lessons in bluster and tall talking; may
Jove never grant you t'be chief in Ithaca as your father was before
you."
Telemachus answered, "Antinous, d'not chide with me, but, god willing,
I will be chief to'if I can. Is this the worst fate you can think of
for me? It is n'bad thing t'be a chief, for it brings both riches and
honour. Still, now that Ulysses is dead there are many great men in
Ithaca both old and young, and some other may take the lead among them;
nevertheless I will be chief in my own house, and will rule those whom
Ulysses has won for me."
Then Eurymachus, son of Polybus, answered, "It rests with heaven to
decide wh'shall be chief among us, but you shall be master in your own
house and over your own possessions; n'one while there is a man in
Ithaca shall d'you violence nor rob you. And now, my good fellow, I
want t'know about this stranger. What country does he come from? Of
what family is he, and where is his estate? Has he brought you news
about the return of your father, or was he on business of his own? He
seemed a well t'd'man, but he hurried off s'suddenly that he was
gone in a moment before we could get t'know him."

scenes.title: Telemachus' Reflection
scenes.summary: Telemachus reflects on the stranger's visit and his father's fate.
scenes.text:
"My father is dead and gone," answered Telemachus, "and even if some
rumour reaches me I put n'more faith in it now. My mother does indeed
sometimes send for a soothsayer and question him, but I give his
prophecyings n'heed. As for the stranger, he was Mentes, son of
Anchialus, chief of the Taphians, an old friend of my father's." But in
his heart he knew that it had been the goddess.
The suitors then returned t'their singing and dancing until the
evening; but when night fell upon their pleasuring they went home to
bed each in his own abode.12 Telemachus's room was high up in a tower13
that looked on t'the outer court; hither, then, he hied, brooding and

scenes.title: Telemachus' Night
scenes.summary: Telemachus prepares for bed, contemplating his journey.
scenes.text:
full of thought. A good old woman, Euryclea, daughter of Ops, the son
of Pisenor, went before him with a couple of blazing torches. Laertes
had bought her with his own money when she was quite young; he gave the
worth of twenty oxen for her, and shewed as much respect t'her in his
household as he did t'his own wedded wife, but he did not take her to
his bed for he feared his wife's resentment.14 She it was wh'now
lighted Telemachus t'his room, and she loved him better than any of
the other women in the house did, for she had nursed him when he was a
baby. He opened the door of his bed room and sat down upon the bed; as
he took off his shirt15 he gave it t'the good old woman, wh'folded it
tidily up, and hung it for him over a peg by his bed side, after which
she went out, pulled the door t'by a silver catch, and drew the bolt
home by means of the strap.16 But Telemachus as he lay covered with a
woollen fleece kept thinking all night through of his intended voyage
and of the counsel that Minerva had given him.

scenes.title: Assembly of the People
scenes.summary: Telemachus calls the assembly to address the suitors.
scenes.text:
ASSEMBLY OF THE PEOPLE OF ITHACA—SPEECHES OF TELEMACHUS AND OF THE
SUITORS—TELEMACHUS MAKES HIS PREPARATIONS AND STARTS FOR PYLOS WITH
MINERVA DISGUISED AS MENTOR.
Now when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared Telemachus
rose and dressed himself. He bound his sandals on t'his comely feet,
girded his sword about his shoulder, and left his room looking like an
immortal god. He at once sent the criers round t'call the people in
assembly, s'they called them and the people gathered thereon; then,
when they were got together, he went t'the place of assembly spear in
hand—not alone, for his tw'hounds went with him. Minerva endowed him
with a presence of such divine comeliness that all marvelled at him as
he went by, and when he took his place in his father's seat even the
oldest councillors made way for him.
Aegyptius, a man bent double with age, and of infinite experience, was
the first t'speak. His son Antiphus had gone with Ulysses t'Ilius,
land of noble steeds, but the savage Cyclops had killed him when they
were all shut up in the cave, and had cooked his last dinner for him.17
He had three sons left, of whom tw'still worked on their father's
land, while the third, Eurynomus, was one of the suitors; nevertheless
their father could not get over the loss of Antiphus, and was still
weeping for him when he began his speech.
"Men of Ithaca," he said, "hear my words. From the day Ulysses left us
there has been n'meeting of our councillors until now; wh'then can it
be, whether old or young, that finds it s'necessary t'convene us? Has
he got wind of some host approaching, and does he wish t'warn us, or
would he speak upon some other matter of public moment? I am sure he is
an excellent person, and I hope Jove will grant him his heart's
desire."
Telemachus took this speech as of good omen and rose at once, for he
was bursting with what he had t'say. He stood in the middle of the
assembly and the good herald Pisenor brought him his staff. Then,
turning t'Aegyptius, "Sir," said he, "it is I, as you will shortly
learn, wh'have convened you, for it is I wh'am the most aggrieved. I
have not got wind of any host approaching about which I would warn you,
nor is there any matter of public moment on which I would speak. My
grievance is purely personal, and turns on tw'great misfortunes which
have fallen upon my house. The first of these is the loss of my
excellent father, wh'was chief among all you here present, and was
like a father t'every one of you; the second is much more serious, and
ere long will be the utter ruin of my estate. The sons of all the chief
men among you are pestering my mother t'marry them against her will.
They are afraid t'g't'her father Icarius, asking him t'choose the
one he likes best, and t'provide marriage gifts for his daughter, but
day by day they keep hanging about my father's house, sacrificing our
oxen, sheep, and fat goats for their banquets, and never giving s'much
as a thought t'the quantity of wine they drink. N'estate can stand
such recklessness; we have now n'Ulysses t'ward off harm from our
doors, and I cannot hold my own against them. I shall never all my days
be as good a man as he was, still I would indeed defend myself if I had
power t'd'so, for I cannot stand such treatment any longer; my house
is being disgraced and ruined. Have respect, therefore, t'your own
consciences and t'public opinion. Fear, too, the wrath of heaven, lest
the gods should be displeased and turn upon you. I pray you by Jove and
Themis, wh'is the beginning and the end of councils, [d'not] hold
back, my friends, and leave me singlehanded18—unless it be that my
brave father Ulysses did some wrong t'the Achaeans which you would now
avenge on me, by aiding and abetting these suitors. Moreover, if I am
t'be eaten out of house and home at all, I had rather you did the
eating yourselves, for I could then take action against you t'some
purpose, and serve you with notices from house t'house till I got paid
in full, whereas now I have n'remedy."19
With this Telemachus dashed his staff t'the ground and burst into
tears. Every one was very sorry for him, but they all sat still and no
one ventured t'make him an angry answer, save only Antinous, wh'spoke
thus:
"Telemachus, insolent braggart that you are, how dare you try t'throw
the blame upon us suitors? It is your mother's fault not ours, for she
is a very artful woman. This three years past, and close on four, she
had been driving us out of our minds, by encouraging each one of us,
and sending him messages without meaning one word of what she says. And
then there was that other trick she played us. She set up a great
tambour frame in her room, and began t'work on an enormous piece of
fine needlework. 'Sweet hearts,' said she, 'Ulysses is indeed dead,
still d'not press me t'marry again immediately, wait—for I would not
have skill in needlework perish unrecorded—till I have completed a pall
for the her'Laertes, t'be in readiness against the time when death
shall take him. He is very rich, and the women of the place will talk
if he is laid out without a pall.'
"This was what she said, and we assented; whereon we could see her
working on her great web all day long, but at night she would unpick
the stitches again by torchlight. She fooled us in this way for three
years and we never found her out, but as time wore on and she was now
in her fourth year, one of her maids wh'knew what she was doing told
us, and we caught her in the act of undoing her work, s'she had to
finish it whether she would or no. The suitors, therefore, make you
this answer, that both you and the Achaeans may understand—'Send your
mother away, and bid her marry the man of her own and of her father's
choice'; for I d'not know what will happen if she goes on plaguing us
much longer with the airs she gives herself on the score of the
accomplishments Minerva has taught her, and because she is s'clever.
We never yet heard of such a woman; we know all about Tyro, Alcmena,
Mycene, and the famous women of old, but they were nothing t'your
mother any one of them. It was not fair of her t'treat us in that way,
and as long as she continues in the mind with which heaven has now
endowed her, s'long shall we g'on eating up your estate; and I d'not
see why she should change, for she gets all the honour and glory, and
it is you wh'pay for it, not she. Understand, then, that we will not
g'back t'our lands, neither here nor elsewhere, till she has made her
choice and married some one or other of us."
Telemachus answered, "Antinous, how can I drive the mother wh'bore me
from my father's house? My father is abroad and we d'not know whether
he is alive or dead. It will be hard on me if I have t'pay Icarius the
large sum which I must give him if I insist on sending his daughter
back t'him. Not only will he deal rigorously with me, but heaven will
als'punish me; for my mother when she leaves the house will call on
the Erinyes t'avenge her; besides, it would not be a creditable thing
t'do, and I will have nothing t'say t'it. If you choose t'take
offence at this, leave the house and feast elsewhere at one another's
houses at your own cost turn and turn about. If, on the other hand, you
elect t'persist in spunging upon one man, heaven help me, but Jove
shall reckon with you in full, and when you fall in my father's house
there shall be n'man t'avenge you."
As he spoke Jove sent tw'eagles from the top of the mountain, and they
flew on and on with the wind, sailing side by side in their own lordly
flight. When they were right over the middle of the assembly they
wheeled and circled about, beating the air with their wings and glaring
death int'the eyes of them that were below; then, fighting fiercely
and tearing at one another, they flew off towards the right over the
town. The people wondered as they saw them, and asked each other what
all this might be; whereon Halitherses, wh'was the best prophet and
reader of omens among them, spoke t'them plainly and in all honesty,
saying:
"Hear me, men of Ithaca, and I speak more particularly t'the suitors,
for I see mischief brewing for them. Ulysses is not going t'be away
much longer; indeed he is close at hand t'deal out death and
destruction, not on them alone, but on many another of us wh'live in
Ithaca. Let us then be wise in time, and put a stop t'this wickedness
before he comes. Let the suitors d's'of their own accord; it will be
better for them, for I am not prophesying without due knowledge;
everything has happened t'Ulysses as I foretold when the Argives set
out for Troy, and he with them. I said that after going through much
hardship and losing all his men he should come home again in the
twentieth year and that n'one would know him; and now all this is
coming true."
Eurymachus son of Polybus then said, "G'home, old man, and prophesy to
your own children, or it may be worse for them. I can read these omens
myself much better than you can; birds are always flying about in the
sunshine somewhere or other, but they seldom mean anything. Ulysses has
died in a far country, and it is a pity you are not dead along with
him, instead of prating here about omens and adding fuel t'the anger
of Telemachus which is fierce enough as it is. I suppose you think he
will give you something for your family, but I tell you—and it shall
surely be—when an old man like you, wh'should know better, talks a
young one over till he becomes troublesome, in the first place his
young friend will only fare s'much the worse—he will take nothing by
it, for the suitors will prevent this—and in the next, we will lay a
heavier fine, sir, upon yourself than you will at all like paying, for
it will bear hardly upon you. As for Telemachus, I warn him in the
presence of you all t'send his mother back t'her father, wh'will
find her a husband and provide her with all the marriage gifts s'dear
a daughter may expect. Till then we shall g'on harassing him with our
suit; for we fear n'man, and care neither for him, with all his fine
speeches, nor for any fortune-telling of yours. You may preach as much
as you please, but we shall only hate you the more. We shall g'back
and continue t'eat up Telemachus's estate without paying him, till
such time as his mother leaves off tormenting us by keeping us day
after day on the tiptoe of expectation, each vying with the other in
his suit for a prize of such rare perfection. Besides we cannot go
after the other women whom we should marry in due course, but for the
way in which she treats us."
Then Telemachus said, "Eurymachus, and you other suitors, I shall say
n'more, and entreat you n'further, for the gods and the people of
Ithaca now know my story. Give me, then, a ship and a crew of twenty
men t'take me hither and thither, and I will g't'Sparta and t'Pylos
in quest of my father wh'has s'long been missing. Some one may tell
me something, or (and people often hear things in this way) some
heaven-sent message may direct me. If I can hear of him as alive and on
his way home I will put up with the waste you suitors will make for yet
another twelve months. If on the other hand I hear of his death, I will
return at once, celebrate his funeral rites with all due pomp, build a
barrow t'his memory, and make my mother marry again."
With these words he sat down, and Mentor20 wh'had been a friend of
Ulysses, and had been left in charge of everything with full authority
over the servants, rose t'speak. He, then, plainly and in all honesty
addressed them thus:
"Hear me, men of Ithaca, I hope that you may never have a kind and
well-disposed ruler any more, nor one wh'will govern you equitably; I
hope that all your chiefs henceforward may be cruel and unjust, for
there is not one of you but has forgotten Ulysses, wh'ruled you as
though he were your father. I am not half s'angry with the suitors,
for if they choose t'd'violence in the naughtiness of their hearts,
and wager their heads that Ulysses will not return, they can take the
high hand and eat up his estate, but as for you others I am shocked at
the way in which you all sit still without even trying t'stop such
scandalous goings on—which you could d'if you chose, for you are many
and they are few."
Leiocritus, son of Evenor, answered him saying, "Mentor, what folly is
all this, that you should set the people t'stay us? It is a hard thing
for one man t'fight with many about his victuals. Even though Ulysses
himself were t'set upon us while we are feasting in his house, and do
his best t'oust us, his wife, wh'wants him back s'very badly, would
have small cause for rejoicing, and his blood would be upon his own
head if he fought against such great odds. There is n'sense in what
you have been saying. Now, therefore, d'you people g'about your
business, and let his father's old friends, Mentor and Halitherses,
speed this boy on his journey, if he goes at all—which I d'not think
he will, for he is more likely t'stay where he is till some one comes
and tells him something."
On this he broke up the assembly, and every man went back t'his own
abode, while the suitors returned t'the house of Ulysses.

scenes.title: Telemachus's Departure
scenes.summary: Telemachus prepares to leave for Pylos and Sparta.
scenes.text:
Then Telemachus went all alone by the sea side, washed his hands in the
grey waves, and prayed t'Minerva.
"Hear me," he cried, "you god wh'visited me yesterday, and bade me
sail the seas in search of my father wh'has s'long been missing. I
would obey you, but the Achaeans, and more particularly the wicked
suitors, are hindering me that I cannot d'so."
As he thus prayed, Minerva came close up t'him in the likeness and
with the voice of Mentor. "Telemachus," said she, "if you are made of
the same stuff as your father you will be neither fool nor coward
henceforward, for Ulysses never broke his word nor left his work half
done. If, then, you take after him, your voyage will not be fruitless,
but unless you have the blood of Ulysses and of Penelope in your veins
I see n'likelihood of your succeeding. Sons are seldom as good men as
their fathers; they are generally worse, not better; still, as you are
not going t'be either fool or coward henceforward, and are not
entirely without some share of your father's wise discernment, I look
with hope upon your undertaking. But mind you never make common cause
with any of those foolish suitors, for they have neither sense nor
virtue, and give n'thought t'death and t'the doom that will shortly
fall on one and all of them, s'that they shall perish on the same day.
As for your voyage, it shall not be long delayed; your father was such
an old friend of mine that I will find you a ship, and will come with
you myself. Now, however, return home, and g'about among the suitors;
begin getting provisions ready for your voyage; see everything well
stowed, the wine in jars, and the barley meal, which is the staff of
life, in leathern bags, while I g'round the town and beat up
volunteers at once. There are many ships in Ithaca both old and new; I
will run my eye over them for you and will choose the best; we will get
her ready and will put out t'sea without delay."
Thus spoke Minerva daughter of Jove, and Telemachus lost n'time in
doing as the goddess told him. He went moodily home, and found the
suitors flaying goats and singeing pigs in the outer court. Antinous
came up t'him at once and laughed as he took his hand in his own,
saying, "Telemachus, my fine fire-eater, bear n'more ill blood neither
in word nor deed, but eat and drink with us as you used t'do. The
Achaeans will find you in everything—a ship and a picked crew to
boot—s'that you can set sail for Pylos at once and get news of your
noble father."
"Antinous," answered Telemachus, "I cannot eat in peace, nor take
pleasure of any kind with such men as you are. Was it not enough that
you should waste s'much good property of mine while I was yet a boy?
Now that I am older and know more about it, I am als'stronger, and
whether here among this people, or by going t'Pylos, I will d'you all
the harm I can. I shall go, and my going will not be in vain—though,
thanks t'you suitors, I have neither ship nor crew of my own, and must
be passenger not captain."
As he spoke he snatched his hand from that of Antinous. Meanwhile the
others went on getting dinner ready about the buildings,21 jeering at
him tauntingly as they did so.
"Telemachus," said one youngster, "means t'be the death of us; I
suppose he thinks he can bring friends t'help him from Pylos, or again
from Sparta, where he seems bent on going. Or will he g't'Ephyra as
well, for poison t'put in our wine and kill us?"
Another said, "Perhaps if Telemachus goes on board ship, he will be
like his father and perish far from his friends. In this case we should
have plenty t'do, for we could then divide up his property amongst us:
as for the house we can let his mother and the man wh'marries her have
that."
This was how they talked. But Telemachus went down int'the lofty and
spacious store-room where his father's treasure of gold and bronze lay
heaped up upon the floor, and where the linen and spare clothes were
kept in open chests. Here, too, there was a store of fragrant olive
oil, while casks of old, well-ripened wine, unblended and fit for a god
t'drink, were ranged against the wall in case Ulysses should come home
again after all. The room was closed with well-made doors opening in
the middle; moreover the faithful old house-keeper Euryclea, daughter
of Ops the son of Pisenor, was in charge of everything both night and
day. Telemachus called her t'the store-room and said:
"Nurse, draw me off some of the best wine you have, after what you are
keeping for my father's own drinking, in case, poor man, he should
escape death, and find his way home again after all. Let me have twelve
jars, and see that they all have lids; als'fill me some well-sewn
leathern bags with barley meal—about twenty measures in all. Get these
things put together at once, and say nothing about it. I will take
everything away this evening as soon as my mother has gone upstairs for
the night. I am going t'Sparta and t'Pylos t'see if I can hear
anything about the return of my dear father."
When Euryclea heard this she began t'cry, and spoke fondly t'him,
saying, "My dear child, what ever can have put such notion as that into
your head? Where in the world d'you want t'g'to—you, wh'are the one
hope of the house? Your poor father is dead and gone in some foreign
country nobody knows where, and as soon as your back is turned these
wicked ones here will be scheming t'get you put out of the way, and
will share all your possessions among themselves; stay where you are
among your own people, and d'not g'wandering and worrying your life
out on the barren ocean."
"Fear not, nurse," answered Telemachus, "my scheme is not without
heaven's sanction; but swear that you will say nothing about all this
t'my mother, till I have been away some ten or twelve days, unless she
hears of my having gone, and asks you; for I d'not want her t'spoil
her beauty by crying."
The old woman swore most solemnly that she would not, and when she had
completed her oath, she began drawing off the wine int'jars, and
getting the barley meal int'the bags, while Telemachus went back to
the suitors.
Then Minerva bethought her of another matter. She took his shape, and
went round the town t'each one of the crew, telling them t'meet at
the ship by sundown. She went als't'Noemon son of Phronius, and asked
him t'let her have a ship—which he was very ready t'do. When the sun
had set and darkness was over all the land, she got the ship int'the
water, put all the tackle on board her that ships generally carry, and
stationed her at the end of the harbour. Presently the crew came up,
and the goddess spoke encouragingly t'each of them.
Furthermore she went t'the house of Ulysses, and threw the suitors
int'a deep slumber. She caused their drink t'fuddle them, and made
them drop their cups from their hands, s'that instead of sitting over
their wine, they went back int'the town t'sleep, with their eyes
heavy and full of drowsiness. Then she took the form and voice of
Mentor, and called Telemachus t'come outside.
"Telemachus," said she, "the men are on board and at their oars,
waiting for you t'give your orders, s'make haste and let us be off."
On this she led the way, while Telemachus followed in her steps. When
they got t'the ship they found the crew waiting by the water side, and
Telemachus said, "Now my men, help me t'get the stores on board; they
are all put together in the cloister, and my mother does not know
anything about it, nor any of the maid servants except one."
With these words he led the way and the others followed after. When
they had brought the things as he told them, Telemachus went on board,
Minerva going before him and taking her seat in the stern of the
vessel, while Telemachus sat beside her. Then the men loosed the
hawsers and took their places on the benches. Minerva sent them a fair
wind from the West,22 that whistled over the deep blue waves23 whereon
Telemachus told them t'catch hold of the ropes and hoist sail, and
they did as he told them. They set the mast in its socket in the cross
plank, raised it, and made it fast with the forestays; then they
hoisted their white sails aloft with ropes of twisted ox hide. As the
sail bellied out with the wind, the ship flew through the deep blue
water, and the foam hissed against her bows as she sped onward. Then
they made all fast throughout the ship, filled the mixing bowls t'the
brim, and made drink offerings t'the immortal gods that are from
everlasting, but more particularly t'the grey-eyed daughter of Jove.
Thus, then, the ship sped on her way through the watches of the night

scenes.title: Telemachus Arrives at Pylos
scenes.summary: Telemachus and his crew reach Pylos and witness a sacrifice.
scenes.text:
TELEMACHUS VISITS NESTOR AT PYLOS.
but as the sun was rising from the fair sea24 int'the firmament of
heaven t'shed light on mortals and immortals, they reached Pylos the
city of Neleus. Now the people of Pylos were gathered on the sea shore
t'offer sacrifice of black bulls t'Neptune lord of the Earthquake.
There were nine guilds with five hundred men in each, and there were
nine bulls t'each guild. As they were eating the inward meats25 and
burning the thigh bones [on the embers] in the name of Neptune,
Telemachus and his crew arrived, furled their sails, brought their ship
t'anchor, and went ashore.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The theme highlights the importance of divine favor in human affairs.

characters.name: Community And Tradition
characters.role: The theme emphasizes the communal aspect of rituals and traditions.
characters.quote: There were nine guilds with five hundred men in each, and there were nine bulls t'each guild.

scenes.title: Meeting Nestor
scenes.summary: Telemachus meets Nestor and is welcomed to dinner.
scenes.text:
She then went quickly on, and Telemachus followed in her steps till
they reached the place where the guilds of the Pylian people were
assembled. There they found Nestor sitting with his sons, while his
company round him were busy getting dinner ready, and putting pieces of
meat on t'the spits26 while other pieces were cooking. When they saw
the strangers they crowded round them, took them by the hand and bade
them take their places. Nestor's son Pisistratus at once offered his
hand t'each of them, and seated them on some soft sheepskins that were
lying on the sands near his father and his brother Thrasymedes. Then he
gave them their portions of the inward meats and poured wine for them
int'a golden cup, handing it t'Minerva first, and saluting her at the
same time.
"Offer a prayer, sir," said he, "t'King Neptune, for it is his feast
that you are joining; when you have duly prayed and made your drink
offering, pass the cup t'your friend that he may d's'also. I doubt
not that he to'lifts his hands in prayer, for man cannot live without
God in the world. Still he is younger than you are, and is much of an
age with myself, s'I will give you the precedence."
As he spoke he handed her the cup. Minerva thought it very right and
proper of him t'have given it t'herself first;27 she accordingly
began praying heartily t'Neptune. "'thou," she cried, "that
encirclest the earth, vouchsafe t'grant the prayers of thy servants
that call upon thee. More especially we pray thee send down thy grace
on Nestor and on his sons; thereafter als'make the rest of the Pylian
people some handsome return for the goodly hecatomb they are offering
you. Lastly, grant Telemachus and myself a happy issue, in respect of
the matter that has brought us in our ship t'Pylos."
When she had thus made an end of praying, she handed the cup to
Telemachus and he prayed likewise. By and by, when the outer meats were
roasted and had been taken off the spits, the carvers gave every man
his portion and they all made an excellent dinner. As soon as they had
had enough t'eat and drink, Nestor, knight of Gerene, began t'speak.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.role: The theme of hospitality is central as the Pylian people warmly welcome Telemachus and Minerva.
characters.quote: When they saw the strangers they crowded round them, took them by the hand and bade them take their places.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The theme of seeking divine favor is evident as characters pray to Neptune for blessings.
characters.quote: 'thou,' she cried, 'that encirclest the earth, vouchsafe t'grant the prayers of thy servants that call upon thee.'

characters.name: Community And Tradition
characters.role: The theme of community and tradition is highlighted through the shared meal and rituals.
characters.quote: they all made an excellent dinner.

scenes.title: Advice from Nestor
scenes.summary: Nestor advises Telemachus on seeking Menelaus and dealing with suitors.
scenes.text:
from home, nor leave your property with such dangerous people in your
house; they will eat up everything you have among them, and you will
have been on a fool's errand. Still, I should advise you by all means
t'g'and visit Menelaus, wh'has lately come off a voyage among such
distant peoples as n'man could ever hope t'get back from, when the
winds had once carried him s'far out of his reckoning; even birds
cannot fly the distance in a twelve-month, s'vast and terrible are the
seas that they must cross. G't'him, therefore, by sea, and take your
own men with you; or if you would rather travel by land you can have a
chariot, you can have horses, and here are my sons wh'can escort you
t'Lacedaemon where Menelaus lives. Beg of him t'speak the truth, and

characters.name: Dangerous Company
characters.role: Warns against bad influences
characters.quote: they will eat up everything you have among them, and you will have been on a fool's errand.

characters.name: Heroic Journey
characters.role: Encourages exploration and seeking truth
characters.quote: G't'him, therefore, by sea, and take your own men with you; or if you would rather travel by land you can have a chariot, you can have horses, and here are my sons wh'can escort you t'Lacedaemon where Menelaus lives.

scenes.title: Nestor's Sacrifice
scenes.summary: Nestor prepares a sacrifice to Minerva for guidance.
scenes.text:
dwell in heaven than Jove's redoubtable daughter, the Trito-born, who
shewed such favour towards your brave father among the Argives. Holy
queen," he continued, "vouchsafe t'send down thy grace upon myself, my
good wife, and my children. In return, I will offer you in sacrifice a
broad-browed heifer of a year old, unbroken, and never yet brought by
man under the yoke. I will gild her horns, and will offer her up t'you
in sacrifice."
Thus did he pray, and Minerva heard his prayer. He then led the way to
his own house, followed by his sons and sons in law. When they had got
there and had taken their places on the benches and seats, he mixed
them a bowl of sweet wine that was eleven years old when the
housekeeper took the lid off the jar that held it. As he mixed the
wine, he prayed much and made drink offerings t'Minerva, daughter of
Aegis-bearing Jove. Then, when they had made their drink offerings and
had drunk each as much as he was minded, the others went home t'bed
each in his own abode; but Nestor put Telemachus t'sleep in the room
that was over the gateway along with Pisistratus, wh'was the only
unmarried son now left him. As for himself, he slept in an inner room
of the house, with the queen his wife by his side.
Now when the child of morning rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, Nestor left
his couch and took his seat on the benches of white and polished marble
that stood in front of his house. Here aforetime sat Neleus, peer of
gods in counsel, but he was now dead, and had gone t'the house of
Hades; s'Nestor sat in his seat sceptre in hand, as guardian of the
public weal. His sons as they left their rooms gathered round him,
Echephron, Stratius, Perseus, Aretus, and Thrasymedes; the sixth son
was Pisistratus, and when Telemachus joined them they made him sit with
them. Nestor then addressed them.
"My sons," said he, "make haste t'd'as I shall bid you. I wish first
and foremost t'propitiate the great goddess Minerva, wh'manifested
herself visibly t'me during yesterday's festivities. Go, then, one or
other of you t'the plain, tell the stockman t'look me out a heifer,
and come on here with it at once. Another must g't'Telemachus' ship,
and invite all the crew, leaving tw'men only in charge of the vessel.
Some one else will run and fetch Laerceus the goldsmith t'gild the
horns of the heifer. The rest, stay all of you where you are; tell the
maids in the house t'prepare an excellent dinner, and t'fetch seats,
and logs of wood for a burnt offering. Tell them als't'bring me some
clear spring water."
On this they hurried off on their several errands. The heifer was
brought in from the plain, and Telemachus's crew came from the ship;
the goldsmith brought the anvil, hammer, and tongs, with which he
worked his gold, and Minerva herself came t'accept the sacrifice.
Nestor gave out the gold, and the smith gilded the horns of the heifer
that the goddess might have pleasure in their beauty. Then Stratius and
Echephron brought her in by the horns; Aretus fetched water from the
house in a ewer that had a flower pattern on it, and in his other hand
he held a basket of barley meal; sturdy Thrasymedes stood by with a
sharp axe, ready t'strike the heifer, while Perseus held a bucket.
Then Nestor began with washing his hands and sprinkling the barley
meal, and he offered many a prayer t'Minerva as he threw a lock from
the heifer's head upon the fire.
When they had done praying and sprinkling the barley meal32 Thrasymedes
dealt his blow, and brought the heifer down with a stroke that cut
through the tendons at the base of her neck, whereon the daughters and
daughters in law of Nestor, and his venerable wife Eurydice (she was
eldest daughter t'Clymenus) screamed with delight. Then they lifted
the heifer's head from off the ground, and Pisistratus cut her throat.
When she had done bleeding and was quite dead, they cut her up. They

characters.role: The theme highlights the importance of seeking blessings from the gods, particularly Minerva.

scenes.title: Telemachus Departs
scenes.summary: Telemachus leaves Pylos with Pisistratus for Lacedaemon.
scenes.text:
the chariot that he may start at once."
Thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said, and yoked the
fleet horses t'the chariot. The housekeeper packed them up a provision
of bread, wine, and sweet meats fit for the sons of princes. Then
Telemachus got int'the chariot, while Pisistratus gathered up the
reins and took his seat beside him. He lashed the horses on and they
flew forward nothing loth int'the open country, leaving the high
citadel of Pylos behind them. All that day did they travel, swaying the
yoke upon their necks till the sun went down and darkness was over all
the land. Then they reached Pherae where Diocles lived, wh'was son to
Ortilochus and grandson t'Alpheus. Here they passed the night and
Diocles entertained them hospitably. When the child of morning,
rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, they again yoked their horses and drove
out through the gateway under the echoing gatehouse.34 Pisistratus
lashed the horses on and they flew forward nothing loth; presently they
came t'the corn lands of the open country, and in the course of time
completed their journey, s'well did their steeds take them.35

characters.name: Friendship
characters.role: The bond between Telemachus and Pisistratus is highlighted as they travel together.
characters.quote: Pisistratus gathered up the reins and took his seat beside him.

characters.quote: Diocles entertained them hospitably.

characters.name: Heroic Journey
characters.role: The journey signifies growth and adventure for Telemachus.
characters.quote: They flew forward nothing loth int'the open country.

scenes.title: Arrival at Menelaus' House
scenes.summary: Telemachus and Pisistratus arrive at Menelaus' home in Lacedaemon.
scenes.text:
they reached the low lying city of Lacedaemon, where they drove
straight t'the abode of Menelaus36 [and found him in his own house,
feasting with his many clansmen in honour of the wedding of his son,
and als'of his daughter, whom he was marrying t'the son of that
valiant warrior Achilles. He had given his consent and promised her to
him while he was still at Troy, and now the gods were bringing the
marriage about; s'he was sending her with chariots and horses t'the
city of the Myrmidons over whom Achilles' son was reigning. For his
only son he had found a bride from Sparta,37 the daughter of Alector.
This son, Megapenthes, was born t'him of a bondwoman, for heaven
vouchsafed Helen n'more children after she had borne Hermione, wh'was
fair as golden Venus herself.
S'the neighbours and kinsmen of Menelaus were feasting and making
merry in his house. There was a bard als't'sing t'them and play his
lyre, while tw'tumblers went about performing in the midst of them
when the man struck up with his tune.38
Telemachus and the son of Nestor stayed their horses at the gate,
whereon Eteoneus servant t'Menelaus came out, and as soon as he saw
them ran hurrying back int'the house t'tell his Master. He went close
up t'him and said, "Menelaus, there are some strangers come here, two
men, wh'look like sons of Jove. What are we t'do? Shall we take their
horses out, or tell them t'find friends elsewhere as they best can?"
Menelaus was very angry and said, "Eteoneus, son of Boethous, you never
used t'be a fool, but now you talk like a simpleton. Take their horses
out, of course, and show the strangers in that they may have supper;
you and I have staid often enough at other people's houses before we
got back here, where heaven grant that we may rest in peace
henceforward."
S'Eteoneus bustled back and bade the other servants come with him.
They took their sweating steeds from under the yoke, made them fast to
the mangers, and gave them a feed of oats and barley mixed. Then they
leaned the chariot against the end wall of the courtyard, and led the
way int'the house. Telemachus and Pisistratus were astonished when
they saw it, for its splendour was as that of the sun and moon; then,
when they had admired everything t'their heart's content, they went
int'the bath room and washed themselves.

scenes.title: Feast with Menelaus
scenes.summary: Menelaus welcomes Telemachus and Pisistratus to a feast.
scenes.text:
When the servants had washed them and anointed them with oil, they
brought them woollen cloaks and shirts, and the tw'took their seats by
the side of Menelaus. A maid-servant brought them water in a beautiful
golden ewer, and poured it int'a silver basin for them t'wash their
hands; and she drew a clean table beside them. An upper servant brought
them bread, and offered them many good things of what there was in the
house, while the carver fetched them plates of all manner of meats and
set cups of gold by their side.
Menelaus then greeted them saying, "Fall to, and welcome; when you have
done supper I shall ask wh'you are, for the lineage of such men as you
cannot have been lost. You must be descended from a line of
sceptre-bearing kings, for poor people d'not have such sons as you
are."
On this he handed them39 a piece of fat roast loin, which had been set
near him as being a prime part, and they laid their hands on the good
things that were before them; as soon as they had had enough t'eat and
drink, Telemachus said t'the son of Nestor, with his head s'close
that n'one might hear, "Look, Pisistratus, man after my own heart, see
the gleam of bronze and gold—of amber,40 ivory, and silver. Everything
is s'splendid that it is like seeing the palace of Olympian Jove. I am
lost in admiration."
Menelaus overheard him and said, "N'one, my sons, can hold his own
with Jove, for his house and everything about him is immortal; but
among mortal men—well, there may be another wh'has as much wealth as I
have, or there may not; but at all events I have travelled much and
have undergone much hardship, for it was nearly eight years before I
could get home with my fleet. I went t'Cyprus, Phoenicia and the
Egyptians; I went als't'the Ethiopians, the Sidonians, and the
Erembians, and t'Libya where the lambs have horns as soon as they are
born, and the sheep lamb down three times a year. Every one in that
country, whether master or man, has plenty of cheese, meat, and good
milk, for the ewes yield all the year round. But while I was travelling
and getting great riches among these people, my brother was secretly
and shockingly murdered through the perfidy of his wicked wife, s'that
I have n'pleasure in being lord of all this wealth. Whoever your
parents may be they must have told you about all this, and of my heavy
loss in the ruin41 of a stately mansion fully and magnificently
furnished. Would that I had only a third of what I now have s'that I
had stayed at home, and all those were living wh'perished on the plain
of Troy, far from Argos. I often grieve, as I sit here in my house, for
one and all of them. At times I cry aloud for sorrow, but presently I
leave off again, for crying is cold comfort and one soon tires of it.
Yet grieve for these as I may, I d's'for one man more than for them
all. I cannot even think of him without loathing both food and sleep,
s'miserable does he make me, for n'one of all the Achaeans worked so
hard or risked s'much as he did. He took nothing by it, and has left a
legacy of sorrow t'myself, for he has been gone a long time, and we
know not whether he is alive or dead. His old father, his
long-suffering wife Penelope, and his son Telemachus, whom he left
behind him an infant in arms, are plunged in grief on his account."
Thus spoke Menelaus, and the heart of Telemachus yearned as he
bethought him of his father. Tears fell from his eyes as he heard him
