characters.name: Independence And Responsibility
characters.role: Shows Nausicaa taking initiative in her tasks.
characters.quote: I want t'take all our dirty clothes t'the river and wash them.

scenes.title: The Washing Day
scenes.summary: Nausicaa and her maids wash clothes by the river.
scenes.text:
and her wash of clothes, but the maids als'wh'were with her.
When they reached the water side they went t'the washing cisterns,
through which there ran at all times enough pure water t'wash any
quantity of linen, n'matter how dirty. Here they unharnessed the mules
and turned them out t'feed on the sweet juicy herbage that grew by the
water side. They took the clothes out of the waggon, put them in the
water, and vied with one another in treading them in the pits t'get
the dirt out. After they had washed them and got them quite clean, they
laid them out by the sea side, where the waves had raised a high beach
of shingle, and set about washing themselves and anointing themselves
with olive oil. Then they got their dinner by the side of the stream,
and waited for the sun t'finish drying the clothes. When they had done
dinner they threw off the veils that covered their heads and began to
play at ball, while Nausicaa sang for them. As the huntress Diana goes
forth upon the mountains of Taygetus or Erymanthus t'hunt wild boars
or deer, and the wood nymphs, daughters of Aegis-bearing Jove, take
their sport along with her (then is Let'proud at seeing her daughter
stand a full head taller than the others, and eclipse the loveliest
amid a whole bevy of beauties), even s'did the girl outshine her
handmaids.

characters.name: Beauty And Pride
characters.role: Highlights Nausicaa's beauty compared to her maids
characters.quote: even s'did the girl outshine her handmaids.

characters.name: Joy And Playfulness
characters.role: Represents the carefree nature of the scene
characters.quote: they threw off the veils that covered their heads and began to play at ball, while Nausicaa sang for them.

characters.name: Nature And Abundance
characters.role: Emphasizes the setting and resources available
characters.quote: enough pure water t'wash any quantity of linen, n'matter how dirty.

scenes.title: Ulysses Awakens
scenes.summary: Ulysses wakes up to the noise of the maids.
scenes.text:
When it was time for them t'start home, and they were folding the
clothes and putting them int'the waggon, Minerva began t'consider how
Ulysses should wake up and see the handsome girl wh'was t'conduct him
t'the city of the Phaeacians. The girl, therefore, threw a ball at one
of the maids, which missed her and fell int'deep water. On this they
all shouted, and the noise they made woke Ulysses, wh'sat up in his
bed of leaves and began t'wonder what it might all be.
"Alas," said he t'himself, "what kind of people have I come amongst?
Are they cruel, savage, and uncivilised, or hospitable and humane? I
seem t'hear the voices of young women, and they sound like those of
the nymphs that haunt mountain tops, or springs of rivers and meadows
of green grass. At any rate I am among a race of men and women. Let me
try if I cannot manage t'get a look at them."
As he said this he crept from under his bush, and broke off a bough
covered with thick leaves t'hide his nakedness. He looked like some
lion of the wilderness that stalks about exulting in his strength and
defying both wind and rain; his eyes glare as he prowls in quest of
oxen, sheep, or deer, for he is famished, and will dare break even into
a well fenced homestead, trying t'get at the sheep—even such did
Ulysses seem t'the young women, as he drew near t'them all naked as
he was, for he was in great want. On seeing one s'unkempt and so
begrimed with salt water, the others scampered off along the spits that
jutted out int'the sea, but the daughter of Alcinous stood firm, for
Minerva put courage int'her heart and took away all fear from her. She
stood right in front of Ulysses, and he doubted whether he should g'up
t'her, throw himself at her feet, and embrace her knees as a
suppliant, or stay where he was and entreat her t'give him some
clothes and show him the way t'the town. In the end he deemed it best
t'entreat her from a distance in case the girl should take offence at
his coming near enough t'clasp her knees, s'he addressed her in

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.role: Ulysses questions the nature of the people he encounters.
characters.quote: What kind of people have I come amongst? Are they cruel, savage, and uncivilised, or hospitable and humane?

characters.name: Despair
characters.role: Ulysses is in a state of need and vulnerability.
characters.quote: he was in great want.

characters.name: Courage And Action
characters.role: The daughter of Alcinous shows bravery in facing Ulysses.
characters.quote: Minerva put courage int'her heart and took away all fear from her.

scenes.title: Nausicaa Meets Ulysses
scenes.summary: Nausicaa encounters Ulysses and offers help.
scenes.text:
honeyed and persuasive language.
"'queen," he said, "I implore your aid—but tell me, are you a goddess
or are you a mortal woman? If you are a goddess and dwell in heaven, I
can only conjecture that you are Jove's daughter Diana, for your face
and figure resemble none but hers; if on the other hand you are a
mortal and live on earth, thrice happy are your father and
mother—thrice happy, too, are your brothers and sisters; how proud and
delighted they must feel when they see s'fair a scion as yourself
going out t'a dance; most happy, however, of all will he be whose
wedding gifts have been the richest, and wh'takes you t'his own home.
I never yet saw any one s'beautiful, neither man nor woman, and am
lost in admiration as I behold you. I can only compare you t'a young
palm tree which I saw when I was at Delos growing near the altar of
Apollo—for I was there, too, with much people after me, when I was on
that journey which has been the source of all my troubles. Never yet
did such a young plant shoot out of the ground as that was, and I
admired and wondered at it exactly as I now admire and wonder at
yourself. I dare not clasp your knees, but I am in great distress;
yesterday made the twentieth day that I had been tossing about upon the
sea. The winds and waves have taken me all the way from the Ogygian
island,55 and now fate has flung me upon this coast that I may endure
still further suffering; for I d'not think that I have yet come t'the
end of it, but rather that heaven has still much evil in store for me.
"And now, 'queen, have pity upon me, for you are the first person I
have met, and I know n'one else in this country. Show me the way to
your town, and let me have anything that you may have brought hither to
wrap your clothes in. May heaven grant you in all things your heart's
desire—husband, house, and a happy, peaceful home; for there is nothing
better in this world than that man and wife should be of one mind in a
house. It discomfits their enemies, makes the hearts of their friends
glad, and they themselves know more about it than any one."
T'this Nausicaa answered, "Stranger, you appear t'be a sensible,
well-disposed person. There is n'accounting for luck; Jove gives
prosperity t'rich and poor just as he chooses, s'you must take what
he has seen fit t'send you, and make the best of it. Now, however,
that you have come t'this our country, you shall not want for clothes
nor for anything else that a foreigner in distress may reasonably look
for. I will show you the way t'the town, and will tell you the name of
our people; we are called Phaeacians, and I am daughter t'Alcinous, in
whom the whole power of the state is vested."
Then she called her maids and said, "Stay where you are, you girls. Can
you not see a man without running away from him? D'you take him for a
robber or a murderer? Neither he nor any one else can come here t'do
us Phaeacians any harm, for we are dear t'the gods, and live apart on
a land's end that juts int'the sounding sea, and have nothing t'do
with any other people. This is only some poor man wh'has lost his way,
and we must be kind t'him, for strangers and foreigners in distress
are under Jove's protection, and will take what they can get and be
thankful; so, girls, give the poor fellow something t'eat and drink,
and wash him in the stream at some place that is sheltered from the

characters.name: Divine Vs Mortal
characters.role: Explores the nature of the characters
characters.quote: 'queen,' he said, 'I implore your aid—but tell me, are you a goddess or are you a mortal woman? If you are a goddess and dwell in heaven, I can only conjecture that you are Jove's daughter Diana, for your face and figure resemble none but hers; if on the other hand you are a mortal and live on earth, thrice happy are your father and mother—thrice happy, too, are your brothers and sisters; how proud and delighted they must feel when they see s'fair a scion as yourself going out t'a dance; most happy, however, of all will he be whose wedding gifts have been the richest, and wh'takes you t'his own home.'

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.role: Highlights the importance of kindness to strangers
characters.quote: This is only some poor man wh'has lost his way, and we must be kind t'him, for strangers and foreigners in distress are under Jove's protection, and will take what they can get and be thankful; so, girls, give the poor fellow something t'eat and drink, and wash him in the stream at some place that is sheltered from the

scenes.title: Ulysses Cleans Up
scenes.summary: Ulysses washes and dresses with Nausicaa's help.
scenes.text:
wind."
On this the maids left off running away and began calling one another
back. They made Ulysses sit down in the shelter as Nausicaa had told
them, and brought him a shirt and cloak. They als'brought him the
little golden cruse of oil, and told him t'g'and wash in the stream.
But Ulysses said, "Young women, please t'stand a little on one side
that I may wash the brine from my shoulders and anoint myself with oil,
for it is long enough since my skin has had a drop of oil upon it. I
cannot wash as long as you all keep standing there. I am ashamed to
strip56 before a number of good looking young women."
Then they stood on one side and went t'tell the girl, while Ulysses
washed himself in the stream and scrubbed the brine from his back and
from his broad shoulders. When he had thoroughly washed himself, and
had got the brine out of his hair, he anointed himself with oil, and
put on the clothes which the girl had given him; Minerva then made him
look taller and stronger than before, she als'made the hair grow thick
on the top of his head, and flow down in curls like hyacinth blossoms;
she glorified him about the head and shoulders as a skilful workman who
has studied art of all kinds under Vulcan and Minerva enriches a piece
of silver plate by gilding it—and his work is full of beauty. Then he
went and sat down a little way off upon the beach, looking quite young
and handsome, and the girl gazed on him with admiration; then she said
t'her maids:
"Hush, my dears, for I want t'say something. I believe the gods who
live in heaven have sent this man t'the Phaeacians. When I first saw
him I thought him plain, but now his appearance is like that of the
gods wh'dwell in heaven. I should like my future husband t'be just
such another as he is, if he would only stay here and not want t'go
away. However, give him something t'eat and drink."
They did as they were told, and set food before Ulysses, wh'ate and
drank ravenously, for it was long since he had had food of any kind.
Meanwhile, Nausicaa bethought her of another matter. She got the linen

characters.name: Transformation And Identity
characters.role: Ulysses undergoes a physical transformation that enhances his appearance.
characters.quote: Minerva then made him look taller and stronger than before, she als'made the hair grow thick on the top of his head, and flow down in curls like hyacinth blossoms; she glorified him about the head and shoulders as a skilful workman who has studied art of all kinds under Vulcan and Minerva enriches a piece of silver plate by gilding it—and his work is full of beauty.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The gods play a crucial role in enhancing Ulysses' appearance and fate.
characters.quote: I believe the gods who live in heaven have sent this man t'the Phaeacians.

characters.name: Desire And Attraction
characters.role: Nausicaa expresses her attraction to Ulysses after his transformation.
characters.quote: I should like my future husband t'be just such another as he is, if he would only stay here and not want t'go away.

scenes.title: Journey to the Town
scenes.summary: Nausicaa leads Ulysses to her father's house.
scenes.text:
folded and placed in the waggon, she then yoked the mules, and, as she
took her seat, she called Ulysses:
"Stranger," said she, "rise and let us be going back t'the town; I
will introduce you at the house of my excellent father, where I can
tell you that you will meet all the best people among the Phaeacians.
But be sure and d'as I bid you, for you seem t'be a sensible person.
As long as we are going past the fields and farm lands, follow briskly
behind the waggon along with the maids and I will lead the way myself.
Presently, however, we shall come t'the town, where you will find a
high wall running all round it, and a good harbour on either side with
a narrow entrance int'the city, and the ships will be drawn up by the
road side, for every one has a place where his own ship can lie. You
will see the market place with a temple of Neptune in the middle of it,
and paved with large stones bedded in the earth. Here people deal in
ship's gear of all kinds, such as cables and sails, and here, too, are
the places where oars are made, for the Phaeacians are not a nation of
archers; they know nothing about bows and arrows, but are a sea-faring
folk, and pride themselves on their masts, oars, and ships, with which
they travel far over the sea.
"I am afraid of the gossip and scandal that may be set on foot against
me later on; for the people here are very ill-natured, and some low
fellow, if he met us, might say, 'Wh'is this fine-looking stranger
that is going about with Nausicaa? Where did she find him? I suppose
she is going t'marry him. Perhaps he is a vagabond sailor whom she has
taken from some foreign vessel, for we have n'neighbours; or some god
has at last come down from heaven in answer t'her prayers, and she is
going t'live with him all the rest of her life. It would be a good
thing if she would take herself off and find a husband somewhere else,
for she will not look at one of the many excellent young Phaeacians who
are in love with her.' This is the kind of disparaging remark that
would be made about me, and I could not complain, for I should myself
be scandalised at seeing any other girl d'the like, and g'about with
men in spite of everybody, while her father and mother were still
alive, and without having been married in the face of all the world.
"If, therefore, you want my father t'give you an escort and t'help
you home, d'as I bid you; you will see a beautiful grove of poplars by
the road side dedicated t'Minerva; it has a well in it and a meadow
all round it. Here my father has a field of rich garden ground, about
as far from the town as a man's voice will carry. Sit down there and
wait for a while till the rest of us can get int'the town and reach my
father's house. Then, when you think we must have done this, come into
the town and ask the way t'the house of my father Alcinous. You will
have n'difficulty in finding it; any child will point it out t'you,
for n'one else in the whole town has anything like such a fine house
as he has. When you have got past the gates and through the outer
court, g'right across the inner court till you come t'my mother. You
will find her sitting by the fire and spinning her purple wool by
firelight. It is a fine sight t'see her as she leans back against one
of the bearing-posts with her maids all ranged behind her. Close t'her
seat stands that of my father, on which he sits and topes like an
immortal god. Never mind him, but g'up t'my mother, and lay your
hands upon her knees if you would get home quickly. If you can gain her
over, you may hope t'see your own country again, n'matter how distant
it may be."
S'saying she lashed the mules with her whip and they left the river.
The mules drew well, and their hoofs went up and down upon the road.
She was careful not t'g'to'fast for Ulysses and the maids wh'were
following on foot along with the waggon, s'she plied her whip with
judgement. As the sun was going down they came t'the sacred grove of
Minerva, and there Ulysses sat down and prayed t'the mighty daughter
of Jove.
"Hear me," he cried, "daughter of Aegis-bearing Jove, unweariable, hear
me now, for you gave n'heed t'my prayers when Neptune was wrecking
me. Now, therefore, have pity upon me and grant that I may find friends
and be hospitably received by the Phaeacians."
Thus did he pray, and Minerva heard his prayer, but she would not show
herself t'him openly, for she was afraid of her uncle Neptune, wh'was
still furious in his endeavors t'prevent Ulysses from getting home.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.role: Nausicaa offers help to Ulysses
characters.quote: I will introduce you at the house of my excellent father, where I can tell you that you will meet all the best people among the Phaeacians.

characters.name: Fear Of Gossip
characters.role: Nausicaa worries about public perception
characters.quote: I am afraid of the gossip and scandal that may be set on foot against me later on; for the people here are very ill-natured...

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Ulysses prays for assistance
characters.quote: Hear me now, for you gave n'heed t'my prayers when Neptune was wrecking me.

scenes.title: Ulysses Arrives at the Palace
scenes.summary: Ulysses is received at King Alcinous' palace.
scenes.text:
RECEPTION OF ULYSSES AT THE PALACE OF KING ALCINOUS.
Thus, then, did Ulysses wait and pray; but the girl drove on t'the
town. When she reached her father's house she drew up at the gateway,
and her brothers—comely as the gods—gathered round her, took the mules
out of the waggon, and carried the clothes int'the house, while she
went t'her own room, where an old servant, Eurymedusa of Apeira, lit
the fire for her. This old woman had been brought by sea from Apeira,
and had been chosen as a prize for Alcinous because he was king over
the Phaeacians, and the people obeyed him as though he were a god.57
She had been nurse t'Nausicaa, and had now lit the fire for her, and
brought her supper for her int'her own room.
Presently Ulysses got up t'g'towards the town; and Minerva shed a
thick mist all round him t'hide him in case any of the proud
Phaeacians wh'met him should be rude t'him, or ask him wh'he was.
Then, as he was just entering the town, she came towards him in the
likeness of a little girl carrying a pitcher. She stood right in front
of him, and Ulysses said:
"My dear, will you be s'kind as t'show me the house of king Alcinous?
I am an unfortunate foreigner in distress, and d'not know one in your
town and country."
Then Minerva said, "Yes, father stranger, I will show you the house you
want, for Alcinous lives quite close t'my own father. I will g'before
you and show the way, but say not a word as you go, and d'not look at
any man, nor ask him questions; for the people here cannot abide
strangers, and d'not like men wh'come from some other place. They are
a sea-faring folk, and sail the seas by the grace of Neptune in ships
that glide along like thought, or as a bird in the air."
On this she led the way, and Ulysses followed in her steps; but not one
of the Phaeacians could see him as he passed through the city in the
midst of them; for the great goddess Minerva in her good will towards
him had hidden him in a thick cloud of darkness. He admired their
harbours, ships, places of assembly, and the lofty walls of the city,
which, with the palisade on top of them, were very striking, and when
they reached the king's house Minerva said:
"This is the house, father stranger, which you would have me show you.
You will find a number of great people sitting at table, but d'not be
afraid; g'straight in, for the bolder a man is the more likely he is
t'carry his point, even though he is a stranger. First find the queen.
Her name is Arete, and she comes of the same family as her husband
Alcinous. They both descend originally from Neptune, wh'was father to
Nausithous by Periboea, a woman of great beauty. Periboea was the
youngest daughter of Eurymedon, wh'at one time reigned over the
giants, but he ruined his ill-fated people and lost his own life to
boot.
"Neptune, however, lay with his daughter, and she had a son by him, the
great Nausithous, wh'reigned over the Phaeacians. Nausithous had two
sons Rhexenor and Alcinous;58 Apoll'killed the first of them while he
was still a bridegroom and without male issue; but he left a daughter
Arete, whom Alcinous married, and honours as n'other woman is honoured
of all those that keep house along with their husbands.
"Thus she both was, and still is, respected beyond measure by her
children, by Alcinous himself, and by the whole people, wh'look upon
her as a goddess, and greet her whenever she goes about the city, for
she is a thoroughly good woman both in head and heart, and when any
women are friends of hers, she will help their husbands als't'settle
their disputes. If you can gain her good will, you may have every hope
of seeing your friends again, and getting safely back t'your home and
country."
Then Minerva left Scheria and went away over the sea. She went to
Marathon59 and t'the spacious streets of Athens, where she entered the
abode of Erechtheus; but Ulysses went on t'the house of Alcinous, and
he pondered much as he paused a while before reaching the threshold of
bronze, for the splendour of the palace was like that of the sun or
moon. The walls on either side were of bronze from end t'end, and the
cornice was of blue enamel. The doors were gold, and hung on pillars of
silver that rose from a floor of bronze, while the lintel was silver
and the hook of the door was of gold.
On either side there stood gold and silver mastiffs which Vulcan, with
his consummate skill, had fashioned expressly t'keep watch over the
palace of king Alcinous; s'they were immortal and could never grow
old. Seats were ranged all along the wall, here and there from one end
t'the other, with coverings of fine woven work which the women of the
house had made. Here the chief persons of the Phaeacians used t'sit
and eat and drink, for there was abundance at all seasons; and there
were golden figures of young men with lighted torches in their hands,
raised on pedestals, t'give light by night t'those wh'were at table.
There are60 fifty maid servants in the house, some of whom are always
grinding rich yellow grain at the mill, while others work at the loom,
or sit and spin, and their shuttles g'backwards and forwards like the
fluttering of aspen leaves, while the linen is s'closely woven that it
will turn oil. As the Phaeacians are the best sailors in the world, so
their women excel all others in weaving, for Minerva has taught them
all manner of useful arts, and they are very intelligent.
Outside the gate of the outer court there is a large garden of about
four acres with a wall all round it. It is full of beautiful
trees—pears, pomegranates, and the most delicious apples. There are
luscious figs also, and olives in full growth. The fruits never rot nor
fail all the year round, neither winter nor summer, for the air is so
soft that a new crop ripens before the old has dropped. Pear grows on
pear, apple on apple, and fig on fig, and s'als'with the grapes, for
there is an excellent vineyard: on the level ground of a part of this,
the grapes are being made int'raisins; in another part they are being
gathered; some are being trodden in the wine tubs, others further on
have shed their blossom and are beginning t'show fruit, others again
are just changing colour. In the furthest part of the ground there are
beautifully arranged beds of flowers that are in bloom all the year
round. Tw'streams g'through it, the one turned in ducts throughout
the whole garden, while the other is carried under the ground of the
outer court t'the house itself, and the town's people draw water from
it. Such, then, were the splendours with which the gods had endowed the
house of king Alcinous.

characters.quote: Then, as he was just entering the town, she came towards him in the likeness of a little girl carrying a pitcher.

characters.quote: If you can gain her good will, you may have every hope of seeing your friends again, and getting safely back t'your home and country.

characters.name: Abundance
characters.role: Description of Alcinous' palace

characters.name: Artistry And Skill

scenes.title: Ulysses Meets Arete and Alcinous
scenes.summary: Ulysses meets Queen Arete and King Alcinous, seeking help.
scenes.text:
S'here Ulysses stood for a while and looked about him, but when he had
looked long enough he crossed the threshold and went within the
precincts of the house. There he found all the chief people among the
Phaeacians making their drink offerings t'Mercury, which they always
did the last thing before going away for the night.61 He went straight
through the court, still hidden by the cloak of darkness in which
Minerva had enveloped him, till he reached Arete and King Alcinous;
then he laid his hands upon the knees of the queen, and at that moment
the miraculous darkness fell away from him and he became visible. Every
one was speechless with surprise at seeing a man there, but Ulysses
began at once with his petition.
"Queen Arete," he exclaimed, "daughter of great Rhexenor, in my
distress I humbly pray you, as als'your husband and these your guests
(whom may heaven prosper with long life and happiness, and may they
leave their possessions t'their children, and all the honours
conferred upon them by the state) t'help me home t'my own country as
soon as possible; for I have been long in trouble and away from my
friends."
Then he sat down on the hearth among the ashes and they all held their
peace, till presently the old her'Echeneus, wh'was an excellent
speaker and an elder among the Phaeacians, plainly and in all honesty
addressed them thus:
"Alcinous," said he, "it is not creditable t'you that a stranger
should be seen sitting among the ashes of your hearth; every one is
waiting t'hear what you are about t'say; tell him, then, t'rise and
take a seat on a stool inlaid with silver, and bid your servants mix
some wine and water that we may make a drink offering t'Jove the lord
of thunder, wh'takes all well disposed suppliants under his
protection; and let the housekeeper give him some supper, of whatever
there may be in the house."
When Alcinous heard this he took Ulysses by the hand, raised him from
the hearth, and bade him take the seat of Laodamas, wh'had been
sitting beside him, and was his favourite son. A maid servant then
brought him water in a beautiful golden ewer and poured it int'a
silver basin for him t'wash his hands, and she drew a clean table
beside him; an upper servant brought him bread and offered him many
good things of what there was in the house, and Ulysses ate and drank.
Then Alcinous said t'one of the servants, "Pontonous, mix a cup of
wine and hand it round that we may make drink-offerings t'Jove the
lord of thunder, wh'is the protector of all well-disposed suppliants."
Pontonous then mixed wine and water, and handed it round after giving
every man his drink-offering. When they had made their offerings, and
had drunk each as much as he was minded, Alcinous said:
"Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, hear my words. You
have had your supper, s'now g'home t'bed. To-morrow morning I shall
invite a still larger number of aldermen, and will give a sacrificial
banquet in honour of our guest; we can then discuss the question of his
escort, and consider how we may at once send him back rejoicing t'his
own country without trouble or inconvenience t'himself, n'matter how
distant it may be. We must see that he comes t'n'harm while on his
homeward journey, but when he is once at home he will have t'take the
luck he was born with for better or worse like other people. It is
possible, however, that the stranger is one of the immortals wh'has
come down from heaven t'visit us; but in this case the gods are
departing from their usual practice, for hithert'they have made
themselves perfectly clear t'us when we have been offering them
hecatombs. They come and sit at our feasts just like one of our selves,
and if any solitary wayfarer happens t'stumble upon some one or other
of them, they affect n'concealment, for we are as near of kin t'the
gods as the Cyclopes and the savage giants are."62
Then Ulysses said: "Pray, Alcinous, d'not take any such notion into
your head. I have nothing of the immortal about me, neither in body nor
mind, and most resemble those among you wh'are the most afflicted.
Indeed, were I t'tell you all that heaven has seen fit t'lay upon me,
you would say that I was still worse off than they are. Nevertheless,
let me sup in spite of sorrow, for an empty stomach is a very
importunate thing, and thrusts itself on a man's notice n'matter how
dire is his distress. I am in great trouble, yet it insists that I
shall eat and drink, bids me lay aside all memory of my sorrows and
dwell only on the due replenishing of itself. As for yourselves, d'as
you propose, and at break of day set about helping me t'get home. I
shall be content t'die if I may first once more behold my property, my
bondsmen, and all the greatness of my house."63
Thus did he speak. Every one approved his saying, and agreed that he
should have his escort inasmuch as he had spoken reasonably. Then when
they had made their drink offerings, and had drunk each as much as he
was minded they went home t'bed every man in his own abode, leaving
Ulysses in the cloister with Arete and Alcinous while the servants were
taking the things away after supper. Arete was the first t'speak, for
she recognised the shirt, cloak, and good clothes that Ulysses was
wearing, as the work of herself and of her maids; s'she said,
"Stranger, before we g'any further, there is a question I should like
t'ask you. Who, and whence are you, and wh'gave you those clothes?
Did you not say you had come here from beyond the sea?"
And Ulysses answered, "It would be a long story Madam, were I t'relate
in full the tale of my misfortunes, for the hand of heaven has been
laid heavy upon me; but as regards your question, there is an island
far away in the sea which is called 'the Ogygian.' Here dwells the
cunning and powerful goddess Calypso, daughter of Atlas. She lives by
herself far from all neighbours human or divine. Fortune, however,
brought me t'her hearth all desolate and alone, for Jove struck my
ship with his thunderbolts, and broke it up in mid-ocean. My brave
comrades were drowned every man of them, but I stuck t'the keel and
was carried hither and thither for the space of nine days, till at last
during the darkness of the tenth night the gods brought me t'the
Ogygian island where the great goddess Calyps'lives. She took me in
and treated me with the utmost kindness; indeed she wanted t'make me
immortal that I might never grow old, but she could not persuade me to
let her d'so.
"I stayed with Calyps'seven years straight on end, and watered the
good clothes she gave me with my tears during the whole time; but at
last when the eighth year came round she bade me depart of her own free
will, either because Jove had told her she must, or because she had
changed her mind. She sent me from her island on a raft, which she
provisioned with abundance of bread and wine. Moreover she gave me good
stout clothing, and sent me a wind that blew both warm and fair. Days
seven and ten did I sail over the sea, and on the eighteenth I caught
sight of the first outlines of the mountains upon your coast—and glad
indeed was I t'set eyes upon them. Nevertheless there was still much
trouble in store for me, for at this point Neptune would let me g'no
further, and raised a great storm against me; the sea was s'terribly
high that I could n'longer keep t'my raft, which went t'pieces under
the fury of the gale, and I had t'swim for it, till wind and current
brought me t'your shores.
"There I tried t'land, but could not, for it was a bad place and the
waves dashed me against the rocks, s'I again took t'the sea and swam
on till I came t'a river that seemed the most likely landing place,
for there were n'rocks and it was sheltered from the wind. Here, then,
I got out of the water and gathered my senses together again. Night was
coming on, s'I left the river, and went int'a thicket, where I
covered myself all over with leaves, and presently heaven sent me off
int'a very deep sleep. Sick and sorry as I was I slept among the
leaves all night, and through the next day till afternoon, when I woke
as the sun was westering, and saw your daughter's maid servants playing
upon the beach, and your daughter among them looking like a goddess. I
besought her aid, and she proved t'be of an excellent disposition,
much more s'than could be expected from s'young a person—for young
people are apt t'be thoughtless. She gave me plenty of bread and wine,
and when she had had me washed in the river she als'gave me the
clothes in which you see me. Now, therefore, though it has pained me to
d'so, I have told you the whole truth."
Then Alcinous said, "Stranger, it was very wrong of my daughter not to
bring you on at once t'my house along with the maids, seeing that she
was the first person whose aid you asked."
"Pray d'not scold her," replied Ulysses; "she is not t'blame. She did
tell me t'follow along with the maids, but I was ashamed and afraid,
for I thought you might perhaps be displeased if you saw me. Every
human being is sometimes a little suspicious and irritable."
"Stranger," replied Alcinous, "I am not the kind of man t'get angry
about nothing; it is always better t'be reasonable; but by Father
Jove, Minerva, and Apollo, now that I see what kind of person you are,
and how much you think as I do, I wish you would stay here, marry my
daughter, and become my son-in-law. If you will stay I will give you a
house and an estate, but n'one (heaven forbid) shall keep you here
against your own wish, and that you may be sure of this I will attend
tomorrow t'the matter of your escort. You can sleep64 during the whole
voyage if you like, and the men shall sail you over smooth waters
either t'your own home, or wherever you please, even though it be a
long way further off than Euboea, which those of my people wh'saw it
when they took yellow-haired Rhadamanthus t'see Tityus the son of
Gaia, tell me is the furthest of any place—and yet they did the whole
voyage in a single day without distressing themselves, and came back
again afterwards. You will thus see how much my ships excel all others,
and what magnificent oarsmen my sailors are."
Then was Ulysses glad and prayed aloud saying, "Father Jove, grant that
Alcinous may d'all as he has said, for s'he will win an imperishable
name among mankind, and at the same time I shall return t'my country."
Thus did they converse. Then Arete told her maids t'set a bed in the
room that was in the gatehouse, and make it with good red rugs, and to
spread coverlets on the top of them with woollen cloaks for Ulysses to
wear. The maids thereon went out with torches in their hands, and when
they had made the bed they came up t'Ulysses and said, "Rise, sir
stranger, and come with us for your bed is ready," and glad indeed was
he t'g't'his rest.

scenes.title: Banquet Assembly
scenes.summary: Alcinous gathers the Phaeacians to welcome Ulysses.
scenes.text:
BANQUET IN THE HOUSE OF ALCINOUS—THE GAMES.
Now when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, Alcinous
and Ulysses both rose, and Alcinous led the way t'the Phaeacian place
of assembly, which was near the ships. When they got there they sat
down side by side on a seat of polished stone, while Minerva took the
form of one of Alcinous' servants, and went round the town in order to
help Ulysses t'get home. She went up t'the citizens, man by man, and
said, "Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, come t'the
assembly all of you and listen t'the stranger wh'has just come off a
long voyage t'the house of King Alcinous; he looks like an immortal
god."
With these words she made them all want t'come, and they flocked to
the assembly till seats and standing room were alike crowded. Every one
was struck with the appearance of Ulysses, for Minerva had beautified
him about the head and shoulders, making him look taller and stouter
than he really was, that he might impress the Phaeacians favourably as
being a very remarkable man, and might come off well in the many trials
of skill t'which they would challenge him. Then, when they were got
together, Alcinous spoke:
"Hear me," said he, "aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians,
that I may speak even as I am minded. This stranger, whoever he may be,
has found his way t'my house from somewhere or other either East or
West. He wants an escort and wishes t'have the matter settled. Let us
then get one ready for him, as we have done for others before him;
indeed, n'one wh'ever yet came t'my house has been able t'complain
of me for not speeding on his way soon enough. Let us draw a ship into
the sea—one that has never yet made a voyage—and man her with tw'and
fifty of our smartest young sailors. Then when you have made fast your
oars each by his own seat, leave the ship and come t'my house to
prepare a feast.65 I will find you in everything. I am giving these
instructions t'the young men wh'will form the crew, for as regards
you aldermen and town councillors, you will join me in entertaining our
guest in the cloisters. I can take n'excuses, and we will have
Demodocus t'sing t'us; for there is n'bard like him whatever he may
choose t'sing about."

scenes.title: Preparation for Games
scenes.summary: The Phaeacians prepare for athletic competitions after the feast.
scenes.text:
Alcinous then led the way, and the others followed after, while a
servant went t'fetch Demodocus. The fifty-tw'picked oarsmen went to
the sea shore as they had been told, and when they got there they drew
the ship int'the water, got her mast and sails inside her, bound the
oars t'the thole-pins with twisted thongs of leather, all in due
course, and spread the white sails aloft. They moored the vessel a
little way out from land, and then came on shore and went t'the house
of King Alcinous. The out houses,66 yards, and all the precincts were
filled with crowds of men in great multitudes both old and young; and
Alcinous killed them a dozen sheep, eight full grown pigs, and two
oxen. These they skinned and dressed s'as t'provide a magnificent
banquet.
A servant presently led in the famous bard Demodocus, whom the muse had
dearly loved, but t'whom she had given both good and evil, for though
she had endowed him with a divine gift of song, she had robbed him of
his eyesight. Pontonous set a seat for him among the guests, leaning it
up against a bearing-post. He hung the lyre for him on a peg over his
head, and showed him where he was t'feel for it with his hands. He
als'set a fair table with a basket of victuals by his side, and a cup
of wine from which he might drink whenever he was s'disposed.
The company then laid their hands upon the good things that were before
them, but as soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink, the muse
inspired Demodocus t'sing the feats of heroes, and more especially a
matter that was then in the mouths of all men, t'wit, the quarrel
between Ulysses and Achilles, and the fierce words that they heaped on
one another as they sat together at a banquet. But Agamemnon was glad
when he heard his chieftains quarrelling with one another, for Apollo
had foretold him this at Pyth'when he crossed the stone floor to
consult the oracle. Here was the beginning of the evil that by the will
of Jove fell both upon Danaans and Trojans.
Thus sang the bard, but Ulysses drew his purple mantle over his head
and covered his face, for he was ashamed t'let the Phaeacians see that
he was weeping. When the bard left off singing he wiped the tears from
his eyes, uncovered his face, and, taking his cup, made a
drink-offering t'the gods; but when the Phaeacians pressed Demodocus
t'sing further, for they delighted in his lays, then Ulysses again
drew his mantle over his head and wept bitterly. N'one noticed his
distress except Alcinous, wh'was sitting near him, and heard the heavy
sighs that he was heaving. S'he at once said, "Aldermen and town
councillors of the Phaeacians, we have had enough now, both of the
feast, and of the minstrelsy that is its due accompaniment; let us
proceed therefore t'the athletic sports, s'that our guest on his
return home may be able t'tell his friends how much we surpass all
other nations as boxers, wrestlers, jumpers, and runners."
With these words he led the way, and the others followed after. A

scenes.title: Athletic Competitions
scenes.summary: Ulysses is challenged to compete in the games.
scenes.text:
servant hung Demodocus's lyre on its peg for him, led him out of the
cloister, and set him on the same way as that along which all the chief
men of the Phaeacians were going t'see the sports; a crowd of several
thousands of people followed them, and there were many excellent
competitors for all the prizes. Acroneos, Ocyalus, Elatreus, Nauteus,
Prymneus, Anchialus, Eretmeus, Ponteus, Proreus, Thoon, Anabesineus,
and Amphialus son of Polyneus son of Tecton. There was als'Euryalus
son of Naubolus, wh'was like Mars himself, and was the best looking
man among the Phaeacians except Laodamas. Three sons of Alcinous,
Laodamas, Halios, and Clytoneus, competed also.
The foot races came first. The course was set out for them from the
starting post, and they raised a dust upon the plain as they all flew
forward at the same moment. Clytoneus came in first by a long way; he
left every one else behind him by the length of the furrow that a
couple of mules can plough in a fallow field.67 They then turned t'the
painful art of wrestling, and here Euryalus proved t'be the best man.
Amphialus excelled all the others in jumping, while at throwing the
disc there was n'one wh'could approach Elatreus. Alcinous's son
Laodamas was the best boxer, and he it was wh'presently said, when
they had all been diverted with the games, "Let us ask the stranger
whether he excels in any of these sports; he seems very powerfully
built; his thighs, calves, hands, and neck are of prodigious strength,
nor is he at all old, but he has suffered much lately, and there is
nothing like the sea for making havoc with a man, n'matter how strong
he is."
"You are quite right, Laodamas," replied Euryalus, "g'up t'your guest
and speak t'him about it yourself."
When Laodamas heard this he made his way int'the middle of the crowd
and said t'Ulysses, "I hope, Sir, that you will enter yourself for
some one or other of our competitions if you are skilled in any of
them—and you must have gone in for many a one before now. There is
nothing that does any one s'much credit all his life long as the
showing himself a proper man with his hands and feet. Have a try
therefore at something, and banish all sorrow from your mind. Your
return home will not be long delayed, for the ship is already drawn
int'the water, and the crew is found."
Ulysses answered, "Laodamas, why d'you taunt me in this way? my mind
is set rather on cares than contests; I have been through infinite
trouble, and am come among you now as a suppliant, praying your king
and people t'further me on my return home."
Then Euryalus reviled him outright and said, "I gather, then, that you
are unskilled in any of the many sports that men generally delight in.
I suppose you are one of those grasping traders that g'about in ships
as captains or merchants, and wh'think of nothing but of their outward
freights and homeward cargoes. There does not seem t'be much of the
athlete about you."
"For shame, Sir," answered Ulysses, fiercely, "you are an insolent
fellow—s'true is it that the gods d'not grace all men alike in
speech, person, and understanding. One man may be of weak presence, but
heaven has adorned this with such a good conversation that he charms
every one wh'sees him; his honeyed moderation carries his hearers with
him s'that he is leader in all assemblies of his fellows, and wherever
he goes he is looked up to. Another may be as handsome as a god, but
his good looks are not crowned with discretion. This is your case. No
god could make a finer looking fellow than you are, but you are a fool.
Your ill-judged remarks have made me exceedingly angry, and you are
quite mistaken, for I excel in a great many athletic exercises; indeed,
s'long as I had youth and strength, I was among the first athletes of
the age. Now, however, I am worn out by labour and sorrow, for I have
gone through much both on the field of battle and by the waves of the
weary sea; still, in spite of all this I will compete, for your taunts
have stung me t'the quick."
S'he hurried up without even taking his cloak off, and seized a disc,
larger, more massive and much heavier than those used by the Phaeacians
when disc-throwing among themselves.68 Then, swinging it back, he threw
it from his brawny hand, and it made a humming sound in the air as he
did so. The Phaeacians quailed beneath the rushing of its flight as it
sped gracefully from his hand, and flew beyond any mark that had been
made yet. Minerva, in the form of a man, came and marked the place
where it had fallen. "A blind man, Sir," said she, "could easily tell
your mark by groping for it—it is s'far ahead of any other. You may
make your mind easy about this contest, for n'Phaeacian can come near
t'such a throw as yours."
Ulysses was glad when he found he had a friend among the lookers-on, so
he began t'speak more pleasantly. "Young men," said he, "come up to
that throw if you can, and I will throw another disc as heavy or even
heavier. If anyone wants t'have a bout with me let him come on, for I
am exceedingly angry; I will box, wrestle, or run, I d'not care what
it is, with any man of you all except Laodamas, but not with him
because I am his guest, and one cannot compete with one's own personal
friend. At least I d'not think it a prudent or a sensible thing for a
guest t'challenge his host's family at any game, especially when he is
in a foreign country. He will cut the ground from under his own feet if
he does; but I make n'exception as regards any one else, for I want to
have the matter out and know which is the best man. I am a good hand at
every kind of athletic sport known among mankind. I am an excellent
archer. In battle I am always the first t'bring a man down with my
arrow, n'matter how many more are taking aim at him alongside of me.
Philoctetes was the only man wh'could shoot better than I could when
we Achaeans were before Troy and in practice. I far excel every one
else in the whole world, of those wh'still eat bread upon the face of
the earth, but I should not like t'shoot against the mighty dead, such
as Hercules, or Eurytus the Oechalian—men wh'could shoot against the
gods themselves. This in fact was how Eurytus came prematurely by his
end, for Apoll'was angry with him and killed him because he challenged
him as an archer. I can throw a dart farther than any one else can
shoot an arrow. Running is the only point in respect of which I am
afraid some of the Phaeacians might beat me, for I have been brought
down very low at sea; my provisions ran short, and therefore I am still
weak."

scenes.title: Demodocus's Song
scenes.summary: Demodocus sings of the Trojan War, stirring Ulysses's emotions.
scenes.text:
They all held their peace except King Alcinous, wh'began, "Sir, we
have had much pleasure in hearing all that you have told us, from which
I understand that you are willing t'show your prowess, as having been
displeased with some insolent remarks that have been made t'you by one
of our athletes, and which could never have been uttered by any one who
knows how t'talk with propriety. I hope you will apprehend my meaning,
and will explain t'any one of your chief men wh'may be dining with
yourself and your family when you get home, that we have an hereditary
aptitude for accomplishments of all kinds. We are not particularly
remarkable for our boxing, nor yet as wrestlers, but we are singularly
fleet of foot and are excellent sailors. We are extremely fond of good
dinners, music, and dancing; we als'like frequent changes of linen,
warm baths, and good beds, s'now, please, some of you wh'are the best
dancers set about dancing, that our guest on his return home may be
able t'tell his friends how much we surpass all other nations as
sailors, runners, dancers, and minstrels. Demodocus has left his lyre
at my house, s'run some one or other of you and fetch it for him."
On this a servant hurried off t'bring the lyre from the king's house,
and the nine men wh'had been chosen as stewards stood forward. It was
their business t'manage everything connected with the sports, s'they
made the ground smooth and marked a wide space for the dancers.
Presently the servant came back with Demodocus's lyre, and he took his
place in the midst of them, whereon the best young dancers in the town
began t'foot and trip it s'nimbly that Ulysses was delighted with the
merry twinkling of their feet.
Meanwhile the bard began t'sing the loves of Mars and Venus, and how
they first began their intrigue in the house of Vulcan. Mars made Venus
many presents, and defiled King Vulcan's marriage bed, s'the sun, who
saw what they were about, told Vulcan. Vulcan was very angry when he
heard such dreadful news, s'he went t'his smithy brooding mischief,
got his great anvil int'its place, and began t'forge some chains
which none could either unloose or break, s'that they might stay there
in that place.69 When he had finished his snare he went int'his
bedroom and festooned the bed-posts all over with chains like cobwebs;
he als'let many hang down from the great beam of the ceiling. Not even
a god could see them s'fine and subtle were they. As soon as he had
spread the chains all over the bed, he made as though he were setting
out for the fair state of Lemnos, which of all places in the world was
the one he was most fond of. But Mars kept n'blind look out, and as
soon as he saw him start, hurried off t'his house, burning with love
for Venus.
Now Venus was just come in from a visit t'her father Jove, and was
about sitting down when Mars came inside the house, and said as he took
her hand in his own, "Let us g't'the couch of Vulcan: he is not at
home, but is gone off t'Lemnos among the Sintians, whose speech is
barbarous."
She was nothing loth, s'they went t'the couch t'take their rest,
whereon they were caught in the toils which cunning Vulcan had spread
for them, and could neither get up nor stir hand or foot, but found too
late that they were in a trap. Then Vulcan came up t'them, for he had
turned back before reaching Lemnos, when his scout the sun told him
what was going on. He was in a furious passion, and stood in the
vestibule making a dreadful noise as he shouted t'all the gods.
"Father Jove," he cried, "and all you other blessed gods wh'live for
ever, come here and see the ridiculous and disgraceful sight that I
will show you. Jove's daughter Venus is always dishonouring me because
I am lame. She is in love with Mars, wh'is handsome and clean built,
whereas I am a cripple—but my parents are t'blame for that, not I;
they ought never t'have begotten me. Come and see the pair together
asleep on my bed. It makes me furious t'look at them. They are very
fond of one another, but I d'not think they will lie there longer than
they can help, nor d'I think that they will sleep much; there,
however, they shall stay till her father has repaid me the sum I gave
him for his baggage of a daughter, wh'is fair but not honest."
On this the gods gathered t'the house of Vulcan. Earth-encircling
Neptune came, and Mercury the bringer of luck, and King Apollo, but the
goddesses staid at home all of them for shame. Then the givers of all
good things stood in the doorway, and the blessed gods roared with
inextinguishable laughter, as they saw how cunning Vulcan had been,
whereon one would turn towards his neighbour saying:
"Ill deeds d'not prosper, and the weak confound the strong. See how
limping Vulcan, lame as he is, has caught Mars wh'is the fleetest god
in heaven; and now Mars will be cast in heavy damages."
Thus did they converse, but King Apoll'said t'Mercury, "Messenger
Mercury, giver of good things, you would not care how strong the chains
were, would you, if you could sleep with Venus?"
"King Apollo," answered Mercury, "I only wish I might get the chance,
though there were three times as many chains—and you might look on, all
of you, gods and goddesses, but I would sleep with her if I could."
The immortal gods burst out laughing as they heard him, but Neptune
took it all seriously, and kept on imploring Vulcan t'set Mars free
again. "Let him go," he cried, "and I will undertake, as you require,
that he shall pay you all the damages that are held reasonable among
the immortal gods."
"D'not," replied Vulcan, "ask me t'd'this; a bad man's bond is bad
security; what remedy could I enforce against you if Mars should go
away and leave his debts behind him along with his chains?"
"Vulcan," said Neptune, "if Mars goes away without paying his damages,
I will pay you myself." S'Vulcan answered, "In this case I cannot and
must not refuse you."
Thereon he loosed the bonds that bound them, and as soon as they were
free they scampered off, Mars t'Thrace and laughter-loving Venus to
Cyprus and t'Paphos, where is her grove and her altar fragrant with
burnt offerings. Here the Graces bathed her, and anointed her with oil
of ambrosia such as the immortal gods make use of, and they clothed her
in raiment of the most enchanting beauty.
Thus sang the bard, and both Ulysses and the seafaring Phaeacians were
charmed as they heard him.
Then Alcinous told Laodamas and Halius t'dance alone, for there was no
one t'compete with them. S'they took a red ball which Polybus had
made for them, and one of them bent himself backwards and threw it up
towards the clouds, while the other jumped from off the ground and
caught it with ease before it came down again. When they had done
throwing the ball straight up int'the air they began t'dance, and at
the same time kept on throwing it backwards and forwards t'one
another, while all the young men in the ring applauded and made a great
stamping with their feet. Then Ulysses said:
"King Alcinous, you said your people were the nimblest dancers in the
world, and indeed they have proved themselves t'be so. I was
astonished as I saw them."
The king was delighted at this, and exclaimed t'the Phaeacians,
"Aldermen and town councillors, our guest seems t'be a person of
singular judgement; let us give him such proof of our hospitality as he
may reasonably expect. There are twelve chief men among you, and
counting myself there are thirteen; contribute, each of you, a clean
cloak, a shirt, and a talent of fine gold; let us give him all this in
a lump down at once, s'that when he gets his supper he may d's'with
a light heart. As for Euryalus he will have t'make a formal apology
and a present too, for he has been rude."
Thus did he speak. The others all of them applauded his saying, and
sent their servants t'fetch the presents. Then Euryalus said, "King
Alcinous, I will give the stranger all the satisfaction you require. He
shall have my sword, which is of bronze, all but the hilt, which is of
silver. I will als'give him the scabbard of newly sawn ivory into
which it fits. It will be worth a great deal t'him."
As he spoke he placed the sword in the hands of Ulysses and said, "Good
luck t'you, father stranger; if anything has been said amiss may the
winds blow it away with them, and may heaven grant you a safe return,
for I understand you have been long away from home, and have gone
through much hardship."
T'which Ulysses answered, "Good luck t'you to'my friend, and may the
gods grant you every happiness. I hope you will not miss the sword you
have given me along with your apology."
With these words he girded the sword about his shoulders and towards
sundown the presents began t'make their appearance, as the servants of
the donors kept bringing them t'the house of King Alcinous; here his
sons received them, and placed them under their mother's charge. Then
Alcinous led the way t'the house and bade his guests take their seats.
"Wife," said he, turning t'Queen Arete, "Go, fetch the best chest we
have, and put a clean cloak and shirt in it. Also, set a copper on the
fire and heat some water; our guest will take a warm bath; see als'to
the careful packing of the presents that the noble Phaeacians have made
him; he will thus better enjoy both his supper and the singing that
will follow. I shall myself give him this golden goblet—which is of
exquisite workmanship—that he may be reminded of me for the rest of his
life whenever he makes a drink offering t'Jove, or t'any of the
gods."70
Then Arete told her maids t'set a large tripod upon the fire as fast
as they could, whereon they set a tripod full of bath water on t'a
clear fire; they threw on sticks t'make it blaze, and the water became
hot as the flame played about the belly of the tripod.71 Meanwhile
Arete brought a magnificent chest from her own room, and inside it she
packed all the beautiful presents of gold and raiment which the
Phaeacians had brought. Lastly she added a cloak and a good shirt from
Alcinous, and said t'Ulysses:
"See t'the lid yourself, and have the whole bound round at once, for
fear any one should rob you by the way when you are asleep in your
ship." 72
When Ulysses heard this he put the lid on the chest and made it fast
with a bond that Circe had taught him. He had done s'before an upper
servant told him t'come t'the bath and wash himself. He was very glad
of a warm bath, for he had had n'one t'wait upon him ever since he
left the house of Calypso, wh'as long as he remained with her had
taken as good care of him as though he had been a god. When the
servants had done washing and anointing him with oil, and had given him
a clean cloak and shirt, he left the bath room and joined the guests
wh'were sitting over their wine. Lovely Nausicaa stood by one of the
bearing-posts supporting the roof of the cloister, and admired him as
she saw him pass. "Farewell stranger," said she, "d'not forget me when
you are safe at home again, for it is t'me first that you owe a ransom
for having saved your life."
And Ulysses said, "Nausicaa, daughter of great Alcinous, may Jove the
mighty husband of Juno, grant that I may reach my home; s'shall I
bless you as my guardian angel all my days, for it was you wh'saved
me."
When he had said this, he seated himself beside Alcinous. Supper was
then served, and the wine was mixed for drinking. A servant led in the
favourite bard Demodocus, and set him in the midst of the company, near
one of the bearing-posts supporting the cloister, that he might lean
against it. Then Ulysses cut off a piece of roast pork with plenty of
fat (for there was abundance left on the joint) and said t'a servant,
"Take this piece of pork over t'Demodocus and tell him t'eat it; for
all the pain his lays may cause me I will salute him none the less;
bards are honoured and respected throughout the world, for the muse
teaches them their songs and loves them."
The servant carried the pork in his fingers over t'Demodocus, wh'took
it and was very much pleased. They then laid their hands on the good
things that were before them, and as soon as they had had t'eat and
drink, Ulysses said t'Demodocus, "Demodocus, there is n'one in the
world whom I admire more than I d'you. You must have studied under the
Muse, Jove's daughter, and under Apollo, s'accurately d'you sing the
return of the Achaeans with all their sufferings and adventures. If you
were not there yourself, you must have heard it all from some one who
was. Now, however, change your song and tell us of the wooden horse
which Epeus made with the assistance of Minerva, and which Ulysses got
by stratagem int'the fort of Troy after freighting it with the men who
afterwards sacked the city. If you will sing this tale aright I will
tell all the world how magnificently heaven has endowed you."
The bard inspired of heaven took up the story at the point where some
of the Argives set fire t'their tents and sailed away while others,
hidden within the horse,73 were waiting with Ulysses in the Trojan
place of assembly. For the Trojans themselves had drawn the horse into
their fortress, and it stood there while they sat in council round it,
and were in three minds as t'what they should do. Some were for
breaking it up then and there; others would have it dragged t'the top
of the rock on which the fortress stood, and then thrown down the
precipice; while yet others were for letting it remain as an offering
and propitiation for the gods. And this was how they settled it in the
end, for the city was doomed when it took in that horse, within which
were all the bravest of the Argives waiting t'bring death and
destruction on the Trojans. Anon he sang how the sons of the Achaeans
issued from the horse, and sacked the town, breaking out from their
ambuscade. He sang how they overran the city hither and thither and
ravaged it, and how Ulysses went raging like Mars along with Menelaus
t'the house of Deiphobus. It was there that the fight raged most
furiously, nevertheless by Minerva's help he was victorious.
All this he told, but Ulysses was overcome as he heard him, and his
cheeks were wet with tears. He wept as a woman weeps when she throws
herself on the body of her husband wh'has fallen before his own city
and people, fighting bravely in defence of his home and children. She
screams aloud and flings her arms about him as he lies gasping for
breath and dying, but her enemies beat her from behind about the back
and shoulders, and carry her off int'slavery, t'a life of labour and
sorrow, and the beauty fades from her cheeks—even s'piteously did
Ulysses weep, but none of those present perceived his tears except
Alcinous, wh'was sitting near him, and could hear the sobs and sighs

characters.quote: Let us give him such proof of our hospitality as he may reasonably expect.

characters.quote: the best young dancers in the town began t'foot and trip it s'nimbly that Ulysses was delighted with the merry twinkling of their feet.

characters.role: Illustrates the themes of love and infidelity through the story of Mars and Venus.

scenes.title: Gifts and Farewell
scenes.summary: Alcinous and the Phaeacians present gifts to Ulysses before his departure.
scenes.text:
that he was heaving. The king, therefore, at once rose and said:
"Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, let Demodocus cease
his song, for there are those present wh'd'not seem t'like it. From
the moment that we had done supper and Demodocus began t'sing, our
guest has been all the time groaning and lamenting. He is evidently in
great trouble, s'let the bard leave off, that we may all enjoy
ourselves, hosts and guest alike. This will be much more as it should
be, for all these festivities, with the escort and the presents that we
are making with s'much good will are wholly in his honour, and any one
with even a moderate amount of right feeling knows that he ought to
treat a guest and a suppliant as though he were his own brother.
"Therefore, Sir, d'you on your part affect n'more concealment nor
reserve in the matter about which I shall ask you; it will be more
polite in you t'give me a plain answer; tell me the name by which your
father and mother over yonder used t'call you, and by which you were
known among your neighbours and fellow-citizens. There is n'one,
neither rich nor poor, wh'is absolutely without any name whatever, for
people's fathers and mothers give them names as soon as they are born.
Tell me als'your country, nation, and city, that our ships may shape
their purpose accordingly and take you there. For the Phaeacians have
n'pilots; their vessels have n'rudders as those of other nations
have, but the ships themselves understand what it is that we are
thinking about and want; they know all the cities and countries in the
whole world, and can traverse the sea just as well even when it is
covered with mist and cloud, s'that there is n'danger of being
wrecked or coming t'any harm. Still I d'remember hearing my father
say that Neptune was angry with us for being to'easy-going in the
matter of giving people escorts. He said that one of these days he
should wreck a ship of ours as it was returning from having escorted
some one,74 and bury our city under a high mountain. This is what my
father used t'say, but whether the god will carry out his threat or no
is a matter which he will decide for himself.
"And now, tell me and tell me true. Where have you been wandering, and
in what countries have you travelled? Tell us of the peoples
themselves, and of their cities—wh'were hostile, savage and
uncivilised, and who, on the other hand, hospitable and humane. Tell us
als'why you are made s'unhappy on hearing about the return of the
Argive Danaans from Troy. The gods arranged all this, and sent them
their misfortunes in order that future generations might have something
t'sing about. Did you lose some brave kinsman of your wife's when you
were before Troy? a son-in-law or father-in-law—which are the nearest
relations a man has outside his own flesh and blood? or was it some
brave and kindly-natured comrade—for a good friend is as dear t'a man
as his own brother?"

scenes.title: Ulysses Begins His Tale
scenes.summary: Ulysses introduces himself and begins recounting his adventures.
scenes.text:
And Ulysses answered, "King Alcinous, it is a good thing t'hear a bard
with such a divine voice as this man has. There is nothing better or
more delightful than when a whole people make merry together, with the
guests sitting orderly t'listen, while the table is loaded with bread
and meats, and the cup-bearer draws wine and fills his cup for every
man. This is indeed as fair a sight as a man can see. Now, however,
since you are inclined t'ask the story of my sorrows, and rekindle my
own sad memories in respect of them, I d'not know how t'begin, nor
yet how t'continue and conclude my tale, for the hand of heaven has
been laid heavily upon me.
"Firstly, then, I will tell you my name that you to'may know it, and
one day, if I outlive this time of sorrow, may become my guests though
I live s'far away from all of you. I am Ulysses son of Laertes,
renowned among mankind for all manner of subtlety, s'that my fame
ascends t'heaven. I live in Ithaca, where there is a high mountain
called Neritum, covered with forests; and not far from it there is a
group of islands very near t'one another—Dulichium, Same, and the
wooded island of Zacynthus. It lies squat on the horizon, all highest
up in the sea towards the sunset, while the others lie away from it
towards dawn.75 It is a rugged island, but it breeds brave men, and my
eyes know none that they better love t'look upon. The goddess Calypso
kept me with her in her cave, and wanted me t'marry her, as did also
the cunning Aeaean goddess Circe; but they could neither of them
persuade me, for there is nothing dearer t'a man than his own country
and his parents, and however splendid a home he may have in a foreign
country, if it be far from father or mother, he does not care about it.
Now, however, I will tell you of the many hazardous adventures which by
Jove's will I met with on my return from Troy.

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.role: Ulysses expresses longing for his homeland.
characters.quote: there is nothing dearer t'a man than his own country and his parents

characters.name: Memory And Loss
characters.role: Ulysses reflects on his past sorrows.
characters.quote: the hand of heaven has been laid heavily upon me

characters.name: The Value Of Companionship
characters.role: Ulysses appreciates shared joy with others.
characters.quote: there is nothing better or more delightful than when a whole people make merry together

scenes.title: The Cicones Encounter
scenes.summary: Ulysses describes the attack on the Cicones and their subsequent defeat.
scenes.text:
"When I had set sail thence the wind took me first t'Ismarus, which is
the city of the Cicons. There I sacked the town and put the people to
the sword. We took their wives and als'much booty, which we divided
equitably amongst us, s'that none might have reason t'complain. I
then said that we had better make off at once, but my men very
foolishly would not obey me, s'they staid there drinking much wine and
killing great numbers of sheep and oxen on the sea shore. Meanwhile the
Cicons cried out for help t'other Cicons wh'lived inland. These were
more in number, and stronger, and they were more skilled in the art of
war, for they could fight, either from chariots or on foot as the
occasion served; in the morning, therefore, they came as thick as
leaves and bloom in summer, and the hand of heaven was against us, so
that we were hard pressed. They set the battle in array near the ships,
and the hosts aimed their bronze-shod spears at one another.76 S'long
as the day waxed and it was still morning, we held our own against
them, though they were more in number than we; but as the sun went
down, towards the time when men loose their oxen, the Cicons got the
better of us, and we lost half a dozen men from every ship we had; so
we got away with those that were left.

characters.name: Folly And Consequences
characters.role: The theme illustrates the repercussions of the crew's greed and disobedience.
characters.quote: my men very foolishly would not obey me, s'they staid there drinking much wine and killing great numbers of sheep and oxen on the sea shore.

characters.name: War And Violence
characters.role: The theme highlights the brutality of war and its impact on both sides.
characters.quote: the Cicons cried out for help t'other Cicons wh'lived inland.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The theme suggests the influence of fate or divine forces in the outcome of the battle.
characters.quote: the hand of heaven was against us, so that we were hard pressed.

scenes.title: The Lotus-Eaters
scenes.summary: Ulysses recounts the encounter with the Lotus-Eaters and the effects of the lotus.
scenes.text:
"Thence we sailed onward with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have
escaped death though we had lost our comrades, nor did we leave till we
had thrice invoked each one of the poor fellows wh'had perished by the
hands of the Cicons. Then Jove raised the North wind against us till it
blew a hurricane, s'that land and sky were hidden in thick clouds, and
night sprang forth out of the heavens. We let the ships run before the
gale, but the force of the wind tore our sails t'tatters, s'we took
them down for fear of shipwreck, and rowed our hardest towards the
land. There we lay tw'days and tw'nights suffering much alike from
toil and distress of mind, but on the morning of the third day we again
raised our masts, set sail, and took our places, letting the wind and
steersmen direct our ship. I should have got home at that time unharmed
had not the North wind and the currents been against me as I was
doubling Cape Malea, and set me off my course hard by the island of
Cythera.
"I was driven thence by foul winds for a space of nine days upon the
sea, but on the tenth day we reached the land of the Lotus-eaters, who
live on a food that comes from a kind of flower. Here we landed t'take
in fresh water, and our crews got their mid-day meal on the shore near
the ships. When they had eaten and drunk I sent tw'of my company to
see what manner of men the people of the place might be, and they had a
third man under them. They started at once, and went about among the
Lotus-eaters, wh'did them n'hurt, but gave them t'eat of the lotus,
which was s'delicious that those wh'ate of it left off caring about
home, and did not even want t'g'back and say what had happened to
them, but were for staying and munching lotus77 with the Lotus-eaters
without thinking further of their return; nevertheless, though they
wept bitterly I forced them back t'the ships and made them fast under
the benches. Then I told the rest t'g'on board at once, lest any of
them should taste of the lotus and leave off wanting t'get home, so
they took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.role: The crew mourns their lost comrades while feeling relief at their own survival.
characters.quote: Thence we sailed onward with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have escaped death though we had lost our comrades.

characters.name: Temptation And Distraction
characters.role: The Lotus-eaters represent a temptation that distracts the crew from their goal of returning home.
characters.quote: those wh'ate of it left off caring about home, and did not even want t'g'back and say what had happened to them

characters.name: Journey And Suffering
characters.role: The crew faces physical and emotional challenges but continues to strive towards their goal.
characters.quote: we took them down for fear of shipwreck, and rowed our hardest towards the land.

scenes.title: The Cyclopes' Land
scenes.summary: Ulysses describes the land of the Cyclopes and their way of life.
scenes.text:
"We sailed hence, always in much distress, till we came t'the land of
the lawless and inhuman Cyclopes. Now the Cyclopes neither plant nor
plough, but trust in providence, and live on such wheat, barley, and
grapes as grow wild without any kind of tillage, and their wild grapes
yield them wine as the sun and the rain may grow them. They have no
laws nor assemblies of the people, but live in caves on the tops of
high mountains; each is lord and master in his family, and they take no
account of their neighbours.
"Now off their harbour there lies a wooded and fertile island not quite
close t'the land of the Cyclopes, but still not far. It is over-run
with wild goats, that breed there in great numbers and are never
disturbed by foot of man; for sportsmen—wh'as a rule will suffer so
much hardship in forest or among mountain precipices—d'not g'there,
nor yet again is it ever ploughed or fed down, but it lies a wilderness
untilled and unsown from year t'year, and has n'living thing upon it
but only goats. For the Cyclopes have n'ships, nor yet shipwrights who
could make ships for them; they cannot therefore g'from city t'city,
or sail over the sea t'one another's country as people wh'have ships
can do; if they had had these they would have colonised the island,78
for it is a very good one, and would yield everything in due season.
There are meadows that in some places come right down t'the sea shore,
well watered and full of luscious grass; grapes would d'there
excellently; there is level land for ploughing, and it would always
yield heavily at harvest time, for the soil is deep. There is a good
harbour where n'cables are wanted, nor yet anchors, nor need a ship be
moored, but all one has t'd'is t'beach one's vessel and stay there
till the wind becomes fair for putting out t'sea again. At the head of
the harbour there is a spring of clear water coming out of a cave, and

characters.role: Describes the societal structure of the Cyclopes
characters.quote: They have no laws nor assemblies of the people, but live in caves on the tops of high mountains; each is lord and master in his family, and they take no account of their neighbours.

characters.role: Highlights the Cyclopes' separation from other societies

characters.fake_quote: Loneliness and disconnection are felt as the character reflects on the missed opportunities for colonization, emphasizing their isolation.
