scenes.title: Elpenor's Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks with the ghost of Elpenor.
scenes.text:
"The first ghost that came was that of my comrade Elpenor, for he had
not yet been laid beneath the earth. We had left his body unwaked and
unburied in Circe's house, for we had had to'much else t'do. I was
very sorry for him, and cried when I saw him: 'Elpenor,' said I, 'how
did you come down here int'this gloom and darkness? You have got here
on foot quicker than I have with my ship.'
"'Sir,' he answered with a groan, 'it was all bad luck, and my own
unspeakable drunkenness. I was lying asleep on the top of Circe's
house, and never thought of coming down again by the great staircase
but fell right off the roof and broke my neck, s'my soul came down to
the house of Hades. And now I beseech you by all those whom you have
left behind you, though they are not here, by your wife, by the father
wh'brought you up when you were a child, and by Telemachus wh'is the
one hope of your house, d'what I shall now ask you. I know that when
you leave this limb'you will again hold your ship for the Aeaean
island. D'not g'thence leaving me unwaked and unburied behind you, or
I may bring heaven's anger upon you; but burn me with whatever armour I
have, build a barrow for me on the sea shore, that may tell people in
days t'come what a poor unlucky fellow I was, and plant over my grave
the oar I used t'row with when I was yet alive and with my messmates.'
And I said, 'My poor fellow, I will d'all that you have asked of me.'

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.role: Elpenor's ghost represents the theme of loss and the mourning of those left behind.
characters.quote: I was very sorry for him, and cried when I saw him: 'Elpenor,' said I, 'how did you come down here int'this gloom and darkness?

characters.name: Remembrance And Burial
characters.role: Elpenor's plea for burial highlights the importance of remembrance and proper burial rites.
characters.quote: D'not g'thence leaving me unwaked and unburied behind you, or I may bring heaven's anger upon you; but burn me with whatever armour I have, build a barrow for me on the sea shore...

characters.name: Consequences Of Actions
characters.role: Elpenor's story illustrates the theme of consequences stemming from one's actions, particularly his drunkenness.
characters.quote: Sir,' he answered with a groan, 'it was all bad luck, and my own unspeakable drunkenness.

scenes.title: Anticlea's Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses encounters his mother, Anticlea.
scenes.text:
ghost of my dead mother Anticlea, daughter t'Autolycus. I had left her
alive when I set out for Troy and was moved t'tears when I saw her,
but even so, for all my sorrow I would not let her come near the blood
till I had asked my questions of Teiresias.
"Then came als'the ghost of Theban Teiresias, with his golden sceptre
in his hand. He knew me and said, 'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, why,
poor man, have you left the light of day and come down t'visit the
dead in this sad place? Stand back from the trench and withdraw your
sword that I may drink of the blood and answer your questions truly.'
"S'I drew back, and sheathed my sword, whereon when he had drank of
the blood he began with his prophecy.
"'You want t'know,' said he, 'about your return home, but heaven will
make this hard for you. I d'not think that you will escape the eye of
Neptune, wh'still nurses his bitter grudge against you for having
blinded his son. Still, after much suffering you may get home if you
can restrain yourself and your companions when your ship reaches the
Thrinacian island, where you will find the sheep and cattle belonging
t'the sun, wh'sees and gives ear t'everything. If you leave these
flocks unharmed and think of nothing but of getting home, you may yet
after much hardship reach Ithaca; but if you harm them, then I forewarn
you of the destruction both of your ship and of your men. Even though
you may yourself escape, you will return in bad plight after losing all
your men, [in another man's ship, and you will find trouble in your
house, which will be overrun by high-handed people, wh'are devouring
your substance under the pretext of paying court and making presents to
your wife.
"'When you get home you will take your revenge on these suitors; and
after you have killed them by force or fraud in your own house, you
must take a well made oar and carry it on and on, till you come t'a
country where the people have never heard of the sea and d'not even
mix salt with their food, nor d'they know anything about ships, and
oars that are as the wings of a ship. I will give you this certain
token which cannot escape your notice. A wayfarer will meet you and
will say it must be a winnowing shovel that you have got upon your
shoulder; on this you must fix the oar in the ground and sacrifice a
ram, a bull, and a boar t'Neptune.90 Then g'home and offer hecatombs
t'all the gods in heaven one after the other. As for yourself, death
shall come t'you from the sea, and your life shall ebb away very
gently when you are full of years and peace of mind, and your people
shall bless you. All that I have said will come true].'91
"'This,' I answered, 'must be as it may please heaven, but tell me and
tell me and tell me true, I see my poor mother's ghost close by us; she
is sitting by the blood without saying a word, and though I am her own
son she does not remember me and speak t'me; tell me, Sir, how I can
make her know me.'
"'That,' said he, 'I can soon do. Any ghost that you let taste of the
blood will talk with you like a reasonable being, but if you d'not let
them have any blood they will g'away again.'
"On this the ghost of Teiresias went back t'the house of Hades, for
his prophecyings had now been spoken, but I sat still where I was until
my mother came up and tasted the blood. Then she knew me at once and
spoke fondly t'me, saying, 'My son, how did you come down t'this
abode of darkness while you are still alive? It is a hard thing for the
living t'see these places, for between us and them there are great and
terrible waters, and there is Oceanus, which n'man can cross on foot,
but he must have a good ship t'take him. Are you all this time trying
t'find your way home from Troy, and have you never yet got back to
Ithaca nor seen your wife in your own house?'
"'Mother,' said I, 'I was forced t'come here t'consult the ghost of
the Theban prophet Teiresias. I have never yet been near the Achaean
land nor set foot on my native country, and I have had nothing but one
long series of misfortunes from the very first day that I set out with
Agamemnon for Ilius, the land of noble steeds, t'fight the Trojans.
But tell me, and tell me true, in what way did you die? Did you have a
long illness, or did heaven vouchsafe you a gentle easy passage to
eternity? Tell me als'about my father, and the son whom I left behind
me, is my property still in their hands, or has some one else got hold
of it, wh'thinks that I shall not return t'claim it? Tell me again
what my wife intends doing, and in what mind she is; does she live with
my son and guard my estate securely, or has she made the best match she
could and married again?'
"My mother answered, 'Your wife still remains in your house, but she is
in great distress of mind and spends her whole time in tears both night
and day. N'one as yet has got possession of your fine property, and
Telemachus still holds your lands undisturbed. He has t'entertain
largely, as of course he must, considering his position as a
magistrate,92 and how every one invites him; your father remains at his
old place in the country and never goes near the town. He has no
comfortable bed nor bedding; in the winter he sleeps on the floor in
front of the fire with the men and goes about all in rags, but in
summer, when the warm weather comes on again, he lies out in the
vineyard on a bed of vine leaves thrown any how upon the ground. He
grieves continually about your never having come home, and suffers more
and more as he grows older. As for my own end it was in this wise:
heaven did not take me swiftly and painlessly in my own house, nor was
I attacked by any illness such as those that generally wear people out
and kill them, but my longing t'know what you were doing and the force
of my affection for you—this it was that was the death of me.'93
"Then I tried t'find some way of embracing my poor mother's ghost.
Thrice I sprang towards her and tried t'clasp her in my arms, but each
time she flitted from my embrace as it were a dream or phantom, and
being touched t'the quick I said t'her, 'Mother, why d'you not stay
still when I would embrace you? If we could throw our arms around one
another we might find sad comfort in the sharing of our sorrows even in
the house of Hades; does Proserpine want t'lay a still further load of
grief upon me by mocking me with a phantom only?'
"'My son,' she answered, 'most ill-fated of all mankind, it is not
Proserpine that is beguiling you, but all people are like this when
they are dead. The sinews n'longer hold the flesh and bones together;
these perish in the fierceness of consuming fire as soon as life has
left the body, and the soul flits away as though it were a dream. Now,
however, g'back t'the light of day as soon as you can, and note all
these things that you may tell them t'your wife hereafter.'
"Thus did we converse, and anon Proserpine sent up the ghosts of the

characters.role: Expresses the sorrow of separation from loved ones
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The poignant question about the living's journey to the realm of the dead encapsulates the deep sorrow and longing for lost connections.

characters.quote: 'You want t'know,' said he, 'about your return home, but heaven will make this hard for you.'

characters.role: Odysseus seeks to connect with his mother through memory
characters.quote: 'Tell me, Sir, how I can make her know me.'

characters.role: Odysseus's journey is marked by hardship and perseverance
characters.quote: 'I have had nothing but one long series of misfortunes from the very first day that I set out with Agamemnon for Ilius.'

scenes.title: Ghosts of the Women
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks to the ghosts of famous women.
scenes.text:
wives and daughters of all the most famous men. They gathered in crowds
about the blood, and I considered how I might question them severally.
In the end I deemed that it would be best t'draw the keen blade that
hung by my sturdy thigh, and keep them from all drinking the blood at
once. S'they came up one after the other, and each one as I questioned
her told me her race and lineage.
"The first I saw was Tyro. She was daughter of Salmoneus and wife of
Cretheus the son of Aeolus.94 She fell in love with the river Enipeus
wh'is much the most beautiful river in the whole world. Once when she
was taking a walk by his side as usual, Neptune, disguised as her
lover, lay with her at the mouth of the river, and a huge blue wave
arched itself like a mountain over them t'hide both woman and god,
whereon he loosed her virgin girdle and laid her in a deep slumber.
When the god had accomplished the deed of love, he took her hand in his
own and said, 'Tyro, rejoice in all good will; the embraces of the gods
are not fruitless, and you will have fine twins about this time twelve
months. Take great care of them. I am Neptune, s'now g'home, but hold
your tongue and d'not tell any one.'
"Then he dived under the sea, and she in due course bore Pelias and
Neleus, wh'both of them served Jove with all their might. Pelias was a
great breeder of sheep and lived in Iolcus, but the other lived in
Pylos. The rest of her children were by Cretheus, namely, Aeson,
Pheres, and Amythaon, wh'was a mighty warrior and charioteer.
"Next t'her I saw Antiope, daughter t'Asopus, wh'could boast of
having slept in the arms of even Jove himself, and wh'bore him two
sons Amphion and Zethus. These founded Thebes with its seven gates, and
built a wall all round it; for strong though they were they could not
hold Thebes till they had walled it.
"Then I saw Alcmena, the wife of Amphitryon, wh'als'bore t'Jove
indomitable Hercules; and Megara wh'was daughter t'great King Creon,
and married the redoubtable son of Amphitryon.
"I als'saw fair Epicaste mother of king Oedipodes whose awful lot it
was t'marry her own son without suspecting it. He married her after
having killed his father, but the gods proclaimed the whole story to
the world; whereon he remained king of Thebes, in great grief for the
spite the gods had borne him; but Epicaste went t'the house of the
mighty jailor Hades, having hanged herself for grief, and the avenging
spirits haunted him as for an outraged mother—t'his ruing bitterly
thereafter.
"Then I saw Chloris, whom Neleus married for her beauty, having given
priceless presents for her. She was youngest daughter t'Amphion son of
Iasus and king of Minyan Orchomenus, and was Queen in Pylos. She bore
Nestor, Chromius, and Periclymenus, and she als'bore that marvellously
lovely woman Pero, wh'was wooed by all the country round; but Neleus
would only give her t'him wh'should raid the cattle of Iphicles from
the grazing grounds of Phylace, and this was a hard task. The only man
wh'would undertake t'raid them was a certain excellent seer,95 but
the will of heaven was against him, for the rangers of the cattle
caught him and put him in prison; nevertheless when a full year had
passed and the same season came round again, Iphicles set him at
liberty, after he had expounded all the oracles of heaven. Thus, then,
was the will of Jove accomplished.
"And I saw Leda the wife of Tyndarus, wh'bore him tw'famous sons,
Castor breaker of horses, and Pollux the mighty boxer. Both these
heroes are lying under the earth, though they are still alive, for by a
special dispensation of Jove, they die and come t'life again, each one
of them every other day throughout all time, and they have the rank of
gods.
"After her I saw Iphimedeia wife of Aloeus wh'boasted the embrace of
Neptune. She bore tw'sons Otus and Ephialtes, but both were short
lived. They were the finest children that were ever born in this world,
and the best looking, Orion only excepted; for at nine years old they
were nine fathoms high, and measured nine cubits round the chest. They
threatened t'make war with the gods in Olympus, and tried t'set Mount
Ossa on the top of Mount Olympus, and Mount Pelion on the top of Ossa,
that they might scale heaven itself, and they would have done it to'if
they had been grown up, but Apollo, son of Leto, killed both of them,
before they had got s'much as a sign of hair upon their cheeks or
chin.
"Then I saw Phaedra, and Procris, and fair Ariadne daughter of the
magician Minos, whom Theseus was carrying off from Crete t'Athens, but
he did not enjoy her, for before he could d's'Diana killed her in the
island of Dia on account of what Bacchus had said against her.
"I als'saw Maera and Clymene and hateful Eriphyle, wh'sold her own
husband for gold. But it would take me all night if I were t'name
every single one of the wives and daughters of heroes whom I saw, and
it is time for me t'g't'bed, either on board ship with my crew, or

characters.role: Highlights the influence of gods on mortal lives
characters.quote: 'the embraces of the gods are not fruitless, and you will have fine twins about this time twelve months.'

characters.name: Tragic Fate
characters.role: Illustrates the consequences of divine actions on mortals
characters.quote: 'Epicaste went t'the house of the mighty jailor Hades, having hanged herself for grief'

characters.role: Emphasizes the legacy of heroes and their divine parentage

characters.name: Female Suffering
characters.role: Depicts the struggles and sacrifices of women in myth

scenes.title: Agamemnon's Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses meets Agamemnon and discusses their fates.
scenes.text:
ghost of Agamemnon son of Atreus came sadly up t'me, surrounded by
those wh'had perished with him in the house of Aegisthus. As soon as
he had tasted the blood, he knew me, and weeping bitterly stretched out
his arms towards me t'embrace me; but he had n'strength nor substance
any more, and I to'wept and pitied him as I beheld him. 'How did you
come by your death,' said I, 'King Agamemnon? Did Neptune raise his
winds and waves against you when you were at sea, or did your enemies
make an end of you on the main land when you were cattle-lifting or
sheep-stealing, or while they were fighting in defence of their wives
and city?'
"'Ulysses,' he answered, 'noble son of Laertes, I was not lost at sea
in any storm of Neptune's raising, nor did my foes despatch me upon the
mainland, but Aegisthus and my wicked wife were the death of me between
them. He asked me t'his house, feasted me, and then butchered me most
miserably as though I were a fat beast in a slaughter house, while all
around me my comrades were slain like sheep or pigs for the wedding
breakfast, or picnic, or gorgeous banquet of some great nobleman. You
must have seen numbers of men killed either in a general engagement, or
in single combat, but you never saw anything s'truly pitiable as the
way in which we fell in that cloister, with the mixing bowl and the
loaded tables lying all about, and the ground reeking with our blood. I
heard Priam's daughter Cassandra scream as Clytemnestra killed her
close beside me. I lay dying upon the earth with the sword in my body,
and raised my hands t'kill the slut of a murderess, but she slipped
away from me; she would not even close my lips nor my eyes when I was
dying, for there is nothing in this world s'cruel and s'shameless as
a woman when she has fallen int'such guilt as hers was. Fancy
murdering her own husband! I thought I was going t'be welcomed home by
my children and my servants, but her abominable crime has brought
disgrace on herself and all women wh'shall come after—even on the good
ones.'
"And I said, 'In truth Jove has hated the house of Atreus from first to
last in the matter of their women's counsels. See how many of us fell
for Helen's sake, and now it seems that Clytemnestra hatched mischief
against you to'during your absence.'
"'Be sure, therefore,' continued Agamemnon, 'and not be to'friendly
even with your own wife. D'not tell her all that you know perfectly
well yourself. Tell her a part only, and keep your own counsel about
the rest. Not that your wife, Ulysses, is likely t'murder you, for
Penelope is a very admirable woman, and has an excellent nature. We
left her a young bride with an infant at her breast when we set out for
Troy. This child n'doubt is now grown up happily t'man's estate,96
and he and his father will have a joyful meeting and embrace one
another as it is right they should do, whereas my wicked wife did not
even allow me the happiness of looking upon my son, but killed me ere I
could d'so. Furthermore I say—and lay my saying t'your heart—d'not
tell people when you are bringing your ship t'Ithaca, but steal a
march upon them, for after all this there is n'trusting women. But now
tell me, and tell me true, can you give me any news of my son Orestes?
Is he in Orchomenus, or at Pylos, or is he at Sparta with Menelaus—for
I presume that he is still living.'
"And I said, 'Agamemnon, why d'you ask me? I d'not know whether your
son is alive or dead, and it is not right t'talk when one does not
know.'
"As we tw'sat weeping and talking thus sadly with one another the

characters.name: Betrayal
characters.role: Highlights the treachery of Clytemnestra
characters.quote: 'Fancy murdering her own husband!'

characters.name: Grief
characters.role: Expresses the sorrow of lost lives
characters.quote: 'I to'wept and pitied him as I beheld him.'

characters.name: Fate And Free Will
characters.role: Discusses the tragic fate of Agamemnon
characters.quote: 'In truth Jove has hated the house of Atreus from first to last'

characters.name: Trust
characters.role: Warns against trusting women due to betrayal
characters.quote: 'But now tell me, and tell me true, can you give me any news of my son Orestes?'

scenes.title: Achilles' Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses converses with Achilles about his son.
scenes.text:
ghost of Achilles came up t'us with Patroclus, Antilochus, and Ajax
wh'was the finest and goodliest man of all the Danaans after the son
of Peleus. The fleet descendant of Aeacus knew me and spoke piteously,
saying, 'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, what deed of daring will you
undertake next, that you venture down t'the house of Hades among us
silly dead, wh'are but the ghosts of them that can labour n'more?'
"And I said, 'Achilles, son of Peleus, foremost champion of the
Achaeans, I came t'consult Teiresias, and see if he could advise me
about my return home t'Ithaca, for I have never yet been able t'get
near the Achaean land, nor t'set foot in my own country, but have been
in trouble all the time. As for you, Achilles, n'one was ever yet so
fortunate as you have been, nor ever will be, for you were adored by
all us Argives as long as you were alive, and now that you are here you
are a great prince among the dead. D'not, therefore, take it s'much
t'heart even if you are dead.'
"'Say not a word,' he answered, 'in death's favour; I would rather be a
paid servant in a poor man's house and be above ground than king of
kings among the dead. But give me news about my son; is he gone t'the
wars and will he be a great soldier, or is this not so? Tell me als'if
you have heard anything about my father Peleus—does he still rule among
the Myrmidons, or d'they show him n'respect throughout Hellas and
Phthia now that he is old and his limbs fail him? Could I but stand by
his side, in the light of day, with the same strength that I had when I
killed the bravest of our foes upon the plain of Troy—could I but be as
I then was and g'even for a short time t'my father's house, any one
wh'tried t'd'him violence or supersede him would soon rue it.'
"'I have heard nothing,' I answered, 'of Peleus, but I can tell you all
about your son Neoptolemus, for I took him in my own ship from Scyros
with the Achaeans. In our councils of war before Troy he was always
first t'speak, and his judgement was unerring. Nestor and I were the
only tw'wh'could surpass him; and when it came t'fighting on the
plain of Troy, he would never remain with the body of his men, but
would dash on far in front, foremost of them all in valour. Many a man
did he kill in battle—I cannot name every single one of those whom he
slew while fighting on the side of the Argives, but will only say how
he killed that valiant her'Eurypylus son of Telephus, wh'was the
handsomest man I ever saw except Memnon; many others als'of the
Ceteians fell around him by reason of a woman's bribes. Moreover, when
all the bravest of the Argives went inside the horse that Epeus had
made, and it was left t'me t'settle when we should either open the
door of our ambuscade, or close it, though all the other leaders and
chief men among the Danaans were drying their eyes and quaking in every
limb, I never once saw him turn pale nor wipe a tear from his cheek; he
was all the time urging me t'break out from the horse—grasping the
handle of his sword and his bronze-shod spear, and breathing fury
against the foe. Yet when we had sacked the city of Priam he got his
handsome share of the prize money and went on board (such is the
fortune of war) without a wound upon him, neither from a thrown spear
nor in close combat, for the rage of Mars is a matter of great chance.'
"When I had told him this, the ghost of Achilles strode off across a
meadow full of asphodel, exulting over what I had said concerning the
prowess of his son.

characters.name: Heroism And Sacrifice
characters.role: Demonstrates the valor of Achilles and his son Neoptolemus
characters.quote: 'I would rather be a paid servant in a poor man's house and be above ground than king of kings among the dead.'

characters.name: Immortality Vs Mortality
characters.role: Explores the nature of life and death
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The desire to live a humble life rather than reign among the dead illustrates a profound reflection on the value of life.

characters.name: Legacy
characters.role: Focuses on the importance of one's legacy and family
characters.quote: 'But give me news about my son; is he gone t'the wars and will he be a great soldier, or is this not so?'

scenes.title: Other Ghosts
scenes.summary: Ulysses sees various other notable ghosts.
scenes.text:
"The ghosts of other dead men stood near me and told me each his own
melancholy tale; but that of Ajax son of Telamon alone held aloof—still
angry with me for having won the cause in our dispute about the armour
of Achilles. Thetis had offered it as a prize, but the Trojan prisoners
and Minerva were the judges. Would that I had never gained the day in
such a contest, for it cost the life of Ajax, wh'was foremost of all
the Danaans after the son of Peleus, alike in stature and prowess.
"When I saw him I tried t'pacify him and said, 'Ajax, will you not
forget and forgive even in death, but must the judgement about that
hateful armour still rankle with you? It cost us Argives dear enough to
lose such a tower of strength as you were t'us. We mourned you as much
as we mourned Achilles son of Peleus himself, nor can the blame be laid
on anything but on the spite which Jove bore against the Danaans, for
it was this that made him counsel your destruction—come hither,
therefore, bring your proud spirit int'subjection, and hear what I can
tell you.'
"He would not answer, but turned away t'Erebus and t'the other
ghosts; nevertheless, I should have made him talk t'me in spite of his
being s'angry, or I should have gone on talking t'him,97 only that
there were still others among the dead whom I desired t'see.
"Then I saw Minos son of Jove with his golden sceptre in his hand
sitting in judgement on the dead, and the ghosts were gathered sitting
and standing round him in the spacious house of Hades, t'learn his
sentences upon them.
"After him I saw huge Orion in a meadow full of asphodel driving the
ghosts of the wild beasts that he had killed upon the mountains, and he
had a great bronze club in his hand, unbreakable for ever and ever.
"And I saw Tityus son of Gaia stretched upon the plain and covering
some nine acres of ground. Tw'vultures on either side of him were
digging their beaks int'his liver, and he kept on trying t'beat them
off with his hands, but could not; for he had violated Jove's mistress
Let'as she was going through Panopeus on her way t'Pytho.
"I saw als'the dreadful fate of Tantalus, wh'stood in a lake that
reached his chin; he was dying t'quench his thirst, but could never
reach the water, for whenever the poor creature stooped t'drink, it
dried up and vanished, s'that there was nothing but dry ground—parched
by the spite of heaven. There were tall trees, moreover, that shed
their fruit over his head—pears, pomegranates, apples, sweet figs and
juicy olives, but whenever the poor creature stretched out his hand to
take some, the wind tossed the branches back again t'the clouds.
"And I saw Sisyphus at his endless task raising his prodigious stone
with both his hands. With hands and feet he tried t'roll it up t'the
top of the hill, but always, just before he could roll it over on to
the other side, its weight would be to'much for him, and the pitiless
stone98 would come thundering down again on t'the plain. Then he would
begin trying t'push it up hill again, and the sweat ran off him and
the steam rose after him.
"After him I saw mighty Hercules, but it was his phantom only, for he
is feasting ever with the immortal gods, and has lovely Hebe t'wife,
wh'is daughter of Jove and Juno. The ghosts were screaming round him
like scared birds flying all whithers. He looked black as night with
his bare bow in his hands and his arrow on the string, glaring around
as though ever on the point of taking aim. About his breast there was a
wondrous golden belt adorned in the most marvellous fashion with bears,
wild boars, and lions with gleaming eyes; there was als'war, battle,
and death. The man wh'made that belt, d'what he might, would never be
able t'make another like it. Hercules knew me at once when he saw me,
and spoke piteously, saying, 'My poor Ulysses, noble son of Laertes,
are you to'leading the same sorry kind of life that I did when I was
above ground? I was son of Jove, but I went through an infinity of
suffering, for I became bondsman t'one wh'was far beneath me—a low
fellow wh'set me all manner of labours. He once sent me here t'fetch
the hell-hound—for he did not think he could find anything harder for
me than this, but I got the hound out of Hades and brought him t'him,
for Mercury and Minerva helped me.'
"On this Hercules went down again int'the house of Hades, but I stayed
where I was in case some other of the mighty dead should come t'me.
And I should have seen still other of them that are gone before, whom I

scenes.title: Departure from Hades
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men leave the land of the dead.
scenes.text:
this I hastened back t'my ship and ordered my men t'g'on board at
once and loose the hawsers; s'they embarked and took their places,
whereon the ship went down the stream of the river Oceanus. We had to
row at first, but presently a fair wind sprang up.

characters.name: Urgency
characters.role: The theme of urgency is present as the speaker hastens to return to the ship and prepare for departure.
characters.quote: I hastened back t'my ship and ordered my men t'g'on board at once and loose the hawsers; s'they embarked and took their places.

scenes.title: Arrival at Aeaean Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men arrive at Aeaean Island and mourn Elpenor.
scenes.text:
THE SIRENS, SCYLLA AND CHARYBDIS, THE CATTLE OF THE SUN.
"After we were clear of the river Oceanus, and had got out int'the
open sea, we went on till we reached the Aeaean island where there is
dawn and sun-rise as in other places. We then drew our ship on t'the
sands and got out of her on t'the shore, where we went t'sleep and
waited till day should break.
"Then, when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, I sent
some men t'Circe's house t'fetch the body of Elpenor. We cut firewood
from a wood where the headland jutted out int'the sea, and after we
had wept over him and lamented him we performed his funeral rites. When
his body and armour had been burned t'ashes, we raised a cairn, set a
stone over it, and at the top of the cairn we fixed the oar that he had
been used t'row with.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.role: Expressing sorrow for a fallen comrade
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The shared mourning over a loved one emphasizes the deep sorrow and the emotional weight of loss.

characters.name: Ritual And Memory
characters.role: Honoring the dead through rituals
characters.quote: we performed his funeral rites

characters.name: Friendship
characters.role: Commemorating a fallen friend
characters.quote: we raised a cairn, set a stone over it

scenes.title: Circe's Feast and Prophecy
scenes.summary: Circe welcomes Ulysses and shares vital information about their journey.
scenes.text:
"While we were doing all this, Circe, wh'knew that we had got back
from the house of Hades, dressed herself and came t'us as fast as she
could; and her maid servants came with her bringing us bread, meat, and
wine. Then she stood in the midst of us and said, 'You have done a bold
thing in going down alive t'the house of Hades, and you will have died
twice, t'other people's once; now, then, stay here for the rest of the
day, feast your fill, and g'on with your voyage at daybreak tomorrow
morning. In the meantime I will tell Ulysses about your course, and
will explain everything t'him s'as t'prevent your suffering from
misadventure either by land or sea.'
"We agreed t'd'as she had said, and feasted through the livelong day
t'the going down of the sun, but when the sun had set and it came on
dark, the men laid themselves down t'sleep by the stern cables of the
ship. Then Circe took me by the hand and bade me be seated away from
the others, while she reclined by my side and asked me all about our
adventures.
"'S'far s'good,' said she, when I had ended my story, 'and now pay
attention t'what I am about t'tell you—heaven itself, indeed, will
recall it t'your recollection. First you will come t'the Sirens who
enchant all wh'come near them. If any one unwarily draws in to'close
and hears the singing of the Sirens, his wife and children will never
welcome him home again, for they sit in a green field and warble him to
death with the sweetness of their song. There is a great heap of dead
men's bones lying all around, with the flesh still rotting off them.
Therefore pass these Sirens by, and stop your men's ears with wax that
none of them may hear; but if you like you can listen yourself, for you
may get the men t'bind you as you stand upright on a cross piece half
way up the mast,99 and they must lash the rope's ends t'the mast
itself, that you may have the pleasure of listening. If you beg and
pray the men t'unloose you, then they must bind you faster.
"'When your crew have taken you past these Sirens, I cannot give you
coherent directions100 as t'which of tw'courses you are t'take; I
will lay the tw'alternatives before you, and you must consider them
for yourself. On the one hand there are some overhanging rocks against
which the deep blue waves of Amphitrite beat with terrific fury; the
blessed gods call these rocks the Wanderers. Here not even a bird may
pass, no, not even the timid doves that bring ambrosia t'Father Jove,
but the sheer rock always carries off one of them, and Father Jove has
t'send another t'make up their number; n'ship that ever yet came to
these rocks has got away again, but the waves and whirlwinds of fire
are freighted with wreckage and with the bodies of dead men. The only
vessel that ever sailed and got through, was the famous Arg'on her way
from the house of Aetes, and she to'would have gone against these
great rocks, only that Jun'piloted her past them for the love she bore
t'Jason.
"'Of these tw'rocks the one reaches heaven and its peak is lost in a
dark cloud. This never leaves it, s'that the top is never clear not
even in summer and early autumn. N'man though he had twenty hands and
twenty feet could get a foothold on it and climb it, for it runs sheer
up, as smooth as though it had been polished. In the middle of it there
is a large cavern, looking West and turned towards Erebus; you must
take your ship this way, but the cave is s'high up that not even the
stoutest archer could send an arrow int'it. Inside it Scylla sits and
yelps with a voice that you might take t'be that of a young hound, but
in truth she is a dreadful monster and n'one—not even a god—could face
her without being terror-struck. She has twelve mis-shapen feet, and
six necks of the most prodigious length; and at the end of each neck
she has a frightful head with three rows of teeth in each, all set very
close together, s'that they would crunch any one t'death in a moment,
and she sits deep within her shady cell thrusting out her heads and
peering all round the rock, fishing for dolphins or dogfish or any
larger monster that she can catch, of the thousands with which
Amphitrite teems. N'ship ever yet got past her without losing some
men, for she shoots out all her heads at once, and carries off a man in
each mouth.
"'You will find the other rock lie lower, but they are s'close
together that there is not more than a bow-shot between them. [A large
fig tree in full leaf101 grows upon it], and under it lies the sucking
whirlpool of Charybdis. Three times in the day does she vomit forth her
waters, and three times she sucks them down again; see that you be not
there when she is sucking, for if you are, Neptune himself could not
save you; you must hug the Scylla side and drive ship by as fast as you
can, for you had better lose six men than your whole crew.'
"'Is there n'way,' said I, 'of escaping Charybdis, and at the same
time keeping Scylla off when she is trying t'harm my men?'
"'You dare devil,' replied the goddess, 'you are always wanting to
fight somebody or something; you will not let yourself be beaten even
by the immortals. For Scylla is not mortal; moreover she is savage,
extreme, rude, cruel and invincible. There is n'help for it; your best
chance will be t'get by her as fast as ever you can, for if you dawdle
about her rock while you are putting on your armour, she may catch you
with a second cast of her six heads, and snap up another half dozen of
your men; s'drive your ship past her at full speed, and roar out
lustily t'Crataiis wh'is Scylla's dam, bad luck t'her; she will then
stop her from making a second raid upon you.'
"'You will now come t'the Thrinacian island, and here you will see
many herds of cattle and flocks of sheep belonging t'the sun-god—seven
herds of cattle and seven flocks of sheep, with fifty head in each
flock. They d'not breed, nor d'they become fewer in number, and they
are tended by the goddesses Phaethusa and Lampetie, wh'are children of
the sun-god Hyperion by Neaera. Their mother when she had borne them
and had done suckling them sent them t'the Thrinacian island, which
was a long way off, t'live there and look after their father's flocks
and herds. If you leave these flocks unharmed, and think of nothing but
getting home, you may yet after much hardship reach Ithaca; but if you
harm them, then I forewarn you of the destruction both of your ship and
of your comrades; and even though you may yourself escape, you will
return late, in bad plight, after losing all your men.'

characters.name: Temptation And Distraction
characters.role: The allure of the Sirens' song poses a danger to Ulysses and his crew.
characters.quote: 'If any one unwarily draws in to'close and hears the singing of the Sirens, his wife and children will never welcome him home again.'

characters.role: Ulysses faces critical decisions that will affect his journey and crew's fate.
characters.quote: No quote available

characters.quote: 'Now, then, stay here for the rest of the day, feast your fill, and g'on with your voyage at daybreak tomorrow morning.'

characters.name: Survival Instinct
characters.role: The need to navigate dangerous waters and threats to ensure the crew's survival.
characters.quote: 'You had better lose six men than your whole crew.'

scenes.title: Preparation for Sirens
scenes.summary: Ulysses prepares his men for the encounter with the Sirens.
scenes.text:
"Here she ended, and dawn enthroned in gold began t'show in heaven,
whereon she returned inland. I then went on board and told my men to
loose the ship from her moorings; s'they at once got int'her, took
their places, and began t'smite the grey sea with their oars.
Presently the great and cunning goddess Circe befriended us with a fair
wind that blew dead aft, and staid steadily with us, keeping our sails
well filled, s'we did whatever wanted doing t'the ship's gear, and
let her g'as wind and helmsman headed her.
"Then, being much troubled in mind, I said t'my men, 'My friends, it
is not right that one or tw'of us alone should know the prophecies
that Circe has made me, I will therefore tell you about them, s'that
whether we live or die we may d's'with our eyes open. First she said
we were t'keep clear of the Sirens, wh'sit and sing most beautifully
in a field of flowers; but she said I might hear them myself s'long as
n'one else did. Therefore, take me and bind me t'the crosspiece half
way up the mast; bind me as I stand upright, with a bond s'fast that I
cannot possibly break away, and lash the rope's ends t'the mast
itself. If I beg and pray you t'set me free, then bind me more tightly
still.'

characters.name: Prophecy Fulfillment
characters.role: The theme highlights the importance of sharing knowledge for survival.
characters.quote: 'My friends, it is not right that one or tw'of us alone should know the prophecies that Circe has made me, I will therefore tell you about them, s'that whether we live or die we may d's'with our eyes open.'

characters.name: Temptation And Distraction
characters.role: The theme illustrates the struggle against temptation represented by the Sirens.
characters.quote: 'First she said we were t'keep clear of the Sirens, wh'sit and sing most beautifully in a field of flowers.'

characters.name: Sacrifice And Bondage
characters.role: The theme emphasizes the need for self-sacrifice and restraint in the face of danger.
characters.quote: 'Therefore, take me and bind me t'the crosspiece half way up the mast; bind me as I stand upright, with a bond s'fast that I cannot possibly break away.'

scenes.title: Encounter with the Sirens
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men face the Sirens' enchanting song.
scenes.text:
"I had hardly finished telling everything t'the men before we reached
the island of the tw'Sirens,102 for the wind had been very favourable.
Then all of a sudden it fell dead calm; there was not a breath of wind
nor a ripple upon the water, s'the men furled the sails and stowed
them; then taking t'their oars they whitened the water with the foam
they raised in rowing. Meanwhile I look a large wheel of wax and cut it
up small with my sword. Then I kneaded the wax in my strong hands till
it became soft, which it soon did between the kneading and the rays of
the sun-god son of Hyperion. Then I stopped the ears of all my men, and
they bound me hands and feet t'the mast as I stood upright on the
cross piece; but they went on rowing themselves. When we had got within
earshot of the land, and the ship was going at a good rate, the Sirens
saw that we were getting in shore and began with their singing.
"'Come here,' they sang, 'renowned Ulysses, honour t'the Achaean name,
and listen t'our tw'voices. N'one ever sailed past us without
staying t'hear the enchanting sweetness of our song—and he wh'listens
will g'on his way not only charmed, but wiser, for we know all the
ills that the gods laid upon the Argives and Trojans before Troy, and
can tell you everything that is going t'happen over the whole world.'
"They sang these words most musically, and as I longed t'hear them
further I made signs by frowning t'my men that they should set me
free; but they quickened their stroke, and Eurylochus and Perimedes
bound me with still stronger bonds till we had got out of hearing of
the Sirens' voices. Then my men took the wax from their ears and
unbound me.

characters.name: Temptation And Distraction
characters.role: The Sirens' song represents temptation that Ulysses must resist.
characters.quote: 'Come here,' they sang, 'renowned Ulysses, honour t'the Achaean name, and listen t'our tw'voices.'

characters.name: Control
characters.role: Ulysses' binding symbolizes the need for self-control in the face of temptation.
characters.quote: They bound me hands and feet t'the mast as I stood upright on the cross piece; but they went on rowing themselves.

characters.name: Wisdom
characters.role: The Sirens claim to offer wisdom, highlighting the allure of knowledge.
characters.quote: '...for we know all the ills that the gods laid upon the Argives and Trojans before Troy, and can tell you everything that is going t'happen over the whole world.'

scenes.title: Scylla and Charybdis
scenes.summary: Ulysses navigates the treacherous straits between Scylla and Charybdis.
scenes.text:
"Immediately after we had got past the island I saw a great wave from
which spray was rising, and I heard a loud roaring sound. The men were
s'frightened that they loosed hold of their oars, for the whole sea
resounded with the rushing of the waters,103 but the ship stayed where
it was, for the men had left off rowing. I went round, therefore, and
exhorted them man by man not t'lose heart.
"'My friends,' said I, 'this is not the first time that we have been in
danger, and we are in nothing like s'bad a case as when the Cyclops
shut us up in his cave; nevertheless, my courage and wise counsel saved
us then, and we shall live t'look back on all this as well. Now,
therefore, let us all d'as I say, trust in Jove and row on with might
and main. As for you, coxswain, these are your orders; attend t'them,
for the ship is in your hands; turn her head away from these steaming
rapids and hug the rock, or she will give you the slip and be over
yonder before you know where you are, and you will be the death of us.'
"S'they did as I told them; but I said nothing about the awful monster
Scylla, for I knew the men would not g'on rowing if I did, but would
huddle together in the hold. In one thing only did I disobey Circe's
strict instructions—I put on my armour. Then seizing tw'strong spears
I took my stand on the ship's bows, for it was there that I expected
first t'see the monster of the rock, wh'was t'd'my men s'much
harm; but I could not make her out anywhere, though I strained my eyes
with looking the gloomy rock all over and over.
"Then we entered the Straits in great fear of mind, for on the one hand
was Scylla, and on the other dread Charybdis kept sucking up the salt
water. As she vomited it up, it was like the water in a cauldron when
it is boiling over upon a great fire, and the spray reached the top of
the rocks on either side. When she began t'suck again, we could see
the water all inside whirling round and round, and it made a deafening
sound as it broke against the rocks. We could see the bottom of the
whirlpool all black with sand and mud, and the men were at their wits
ends for fear. While we were taken up with this, and were expecting
each moment t'be our last, Scylla pounced down suddenly upon us and
snatched up my six best men. I was looking at once after both ship and
men, and in a moment I saw their hands and feet ever s'high above me,
struggling in the air as Scylla was carrying them off, and I heard them
call out my name in one last despairing cry. As a fisherman, seated,
spear in hand, upon some jutting rock104 throws bait int'the water to
deceive the poor little fishes, and spears them with the ox's horn with
which his spear is shod, throwing them gasping on t'the land as he
catches them one by one—even s'did Scylla land these panting creatures
on her rock and munch them up at the mouth of her den, while they
screamed and stretched out their hands t'me in their mortal agony.
This was the most sickening sight that I saw throughout all my voyages.
"When we had passed the [Wandering] rocks, with Scylla and terrible

characters.name: Fear And Despair
characters.role: The men are terrified and hopeless as they face Scylla and Charybdis.
characters.quote: the men were at their wits ends for fear

characters.name: Courage And Action
characters.role: Odysseus tries to inspire his men to keep rowing despite their fear.
characters.quote: let us all d'as I say, trust in Jove and row on with might and main

characters.name: Loss And Sacrifice
characters.role: The scene depicts the loss of Odysseus's men to Scylla, highlighting the cost of their journey.
characters.quote: I saw their hands and feet ever s'high above me, struggling in the air as Scylla was carrying them off

scenes.title: Arrival at Thrinacian Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses warns his men about the sun-god's cattle on Thrinacian Island.
scenes.text:
Charybdis, we reached the noble island of the sun-god, where were the
goodly cattle and sheep belonging t'the sun Hyperion. While still at
sea in my ship I could bear the cattle lowing as they came home t'the
yards, and the sheep bleating. Then I remembered what the blind Theban
prophet Teiresias had told me, and how carefully Aeaean Circe had
warned me t'shun the island of the blessed sun-god. S'being much
troubled I said t'the men, 'My men, I know you are hard pressed, but
listen while I tell you the prophecy that Teiresias made me, and how
carefully Aeaean Circe warned me t'shun the island of the blessed
sun-god, for it was here, she said, that our worst danger would lie.
Head the ship, therefore, away from the island.'

characters.name: Divine Warning
characters.role: The theme highlights the importance of heeding divine warnings.
characters.quote: I remembered what the blind Theban prophet Teiresias had told me, and how carefully Aeaean Circe had warned me t'shun the island of the blessed sun-god.

characters.name: Temptation And Distraction
characters.role: The theme illustrates the temptation presented by the island despite the warnings.
characters.quote: I could bear the cattle lowing as they came home t'the yards, and the sheep bleating.

characters.name: Leadership
characters.role: The theme emphasizes the responsibility of leadership in guiding the crew.
characters.quote: I said t'the men, 'My men, I know you are hard pressed, but listen while I tell you the prophecy that Teiresias made me.'

scenes.title: Eurylochus's Insurrection
scenes.summary: Eurylochus persuades the men to eat the sun-god's cattle.
scenes.text:
"The men were in despair at this, and Eurylochus at once gave me an
insolent answer. 'Ulysses,' said he, 'you are cruel; you are very
strong yourself and never get worn out; you seem t'be made of iron,
and now, though your men are exhausted with toil and want of sleep, you
will not let them land and cook themselves a good supper upon this
island, but bid them put out t'sea and g'faring fruitlessly on
through the watches of the flying night. It is by night that the winds
blow hardest and d's'much damage; how can we escape should one of
those sudden squalls spring up from South West or West, which s'often
wreck a vessel when our lords the gods are unpropitious? Now,
therefore, let us obey the behests of night and prepare our supper here
hard by the ship; to-morrow morning we will g'on board again and put
out t'sea.'
"Thus spoke Eurylochus, and the men approved his words. I saw that
heaven meant us a mischief and said, 'You force me t'yield, for you
are many against one, but at any rate each one of you must take his
solemn oath that if he meet with a herd of cattle or a large flock of
sheep, he will not be s'mad as t'kill a single head of either, but
will be satisfied with the food that Circe has given us.'
"They all swore as I bade them, and when they had completed their oath
we made the ship fast in a harbour that was near a stream of fresh

characters.name: Despair And Exhaustion
characters.role: Reflects the men's emotional state and their struggle against fatigue.
characters.quote: The men were in despair at this, and Eurylochus at once gave me an insolent answer.

characters.name: Leadership And Authority
characters.role: Highlights Ulysses' struggle to maintain control over his men.
characters.quote: You force me t'yield, for you are many against one.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Indicates the belief in the gods' control over their fate.
characters.quote: I saw that heaven meant us a mischief

characters.name: Oath And Commitment
characters.role: Demonstrates the importance of promises among the crew.
characters.quote: each one of you must take his solemn oath that if he meet with a herd of cattle or a large flock of sheep, he will not be s'mad as t'kill a single head of either.

scenes.title: Divine Retribution
scenes.summary: The sun-god seeks revenge for the slaughter of his cattle.
scenes.text:
water, and the men went ashore and cooked their suppers. As soon as
they had had enough t'eat and drink, they began talking about their
poor comrades whom Scylla had snatched up and eaten; this set them
weeping and they went on crying till they fell off int'a sound sleep.
"In the third watch of the night when the stars had shifted their
places, Jove raised a great gale of wind that flew a hurricane s'that
land and sea were covered with thick clouds, and night sprang forth out
of the heavens. When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn,
appeared, we brought the ship t'land and drew her int'a cave wherein
the sea-nymphs hold their courts and dances, and I called the men
together in council.
"'My friends,' said I, 'we have meat and drink in the ship, let us
mind, therefore, and not touch the cattle, or we shall suffer for it;
for these cattle and sheep belong t'the mighty sun, wh'sees and gives
ear t'everything.' And again they promised that they would obey.
"For a whole month the wind blew steadily from the South, and there was
n'other wind, but only South and East.105 As long as corn and wine
held out the men did not touch the cattle when they were hungry; when,
however, they had eaten all there was in the ship, they were forced to
g'further afield, with hook and line, catching birds, and taking
whatever they could lay their hands on; for they were starving. One
day, therefore, I went up inland that I might pray heaven t'show me
some means of getting away. When I had gone far enough t'be clear of
all my men, and had found a place that was well sheltered from the
wind, I washed my hands and prayed t'all the gods in Olympus till by
and by they sent me off int'a sweet sleep.
"Meanwhile Eurylochus had been giving evil counsel t'the men, 'Listen
t'me,' said he, 'my poor comrades. All deaths are bad enough but there
is none s'bad as famine. Why should not we drive in the best of these
cows and offer them in sacrifice t'the immortal gods? If we ever get
back t'Ithaca, we can build a fine temple t'the sun-god and enrich it
with every kind of ornament; if, however, he is determined t'sink our
ship out of revenge for these horned cattle, and the other gods are of
the same mind, I for one would rather drink salt water once for all and
have done with it, than be starved t'death by inches in such a desert
island as this is.'
"Thus spoke Eurylochus, and the men approved his words. Now the cattle,
s'fair and goodly, were feeding not far from the ship; the men,
therefore, drove in the best of them, and they all stood round them
saying their prayers, and using young oak-shoots instead of
barley-meal, for there was n'barley left. When they had done praying
they killed the cows and dressed their carcasses; they cut out the
thigh bones, wrapped them round in tw'layers of fat, and set some
pieces of raw meat on top of them. They had n'wine with which t'make
drink-offerings over the sacrifice while it was cooking, s'they kept
pouring on a little water from time t'time while the inward meats were
being grilled; then, when the thigh bones were burned and they had
tasted the inward meats, they cut the rest up small and put the pieces
upon the spits.
"By this time my deep sleep had left me, and I turned back t'the ship
and t'the sea shore. As I drew near I began t'smell hot roast meat,
s'I groaned out a prayer t'the immortal gods. 'Father Jove,' I
exclaimed, 'and all you other gods wh'live in everlasting bliss, you
have done me a cruel mischief by the sleep int'which you have sent me;
see what fine work these men of mine have been making in my absence.'
"Meanwhile Lampetie went straight off t'the sun and told him we had
been killing his cows, whereon he flew int'a great rage, and said to
the immortals, 'Father Jove, and all you other gods wh'live in
everlasting bliss, I must have vengeance on the crew of Ulysses' ship:
they have had the insolence t'kill my cows, which were the one thing I
loved t'look upon, whether I was going up heaven or down again. If
they d'not square accounts with me about my cows, I will g'down to
Hades and shine there among the dead.'
"'Sun,' said Jove, 'g'on shining upon us gods and upon mankind over
the fruitful earth. I will shiver their ship int'little pieces with a
bolt of white lightning as soon as they get out t'sea.'
"I was told all this by Calypso, wh'said she had heard it from the
mouth of Mercury.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The consequences of disobeying the gods.
characters.quote: 'they have had the insolence t'kill my cows, which were the one thing I loved t'look upon'

characters.name: Despair
characters.role: The men's struggle against starvation leads to poor choices.
characters.quote: 'All deaths are bad enough but there is none s'bad as famine.'

characters.name: Leadership
characters.role: Odysseus's role as a leader is challenged by his men's actions.
characters.quote: 'you have done me a cruel mischief by the sleep int'which you have sent me'

scenes.title: Ulysses's Survival
scenes.summary: Ulysses survives the storm and is cast ashore on Ogygian Island.
scenes.text:
"As soon as I got down t'my ship and t'the sea shore I rebuked each
one of the men separately, but we could see n'way out of it, for the
cows were dead already. And indeed the gods began at once t'show signs
and wonders among us, for the hides of the cattle crawled about, and
the joints upon the spits began t'low like cows, and the meat, whether
cooked or raw, kept on making a noise just as cows do.
"For six days my men kept driving in the best cows and feasting upon
them, but when Jove the son of Saturn had added a seventh day, the fury
of the gale abated; we therefore went on board, raised our masts,
spread sail, and put out t'sea. As soon as we were well away from the
island, and could see nothing but sky and sea, the son of Saturn raised
a black cloud over our ship, and the sea grew dark beneath it. We did
not get on much further, for in another moment we were caught by a
terrific squall from the West that snapped the forestays of the mast so
that it fell aft, while all the ship's gear tumbled about at the bottom
of the vessel. The mast fell upon the head of the helmsman in the
ship's stern, s'that the bones of his head were crushed t'pieces, and
he fell overboard as though he were diving, with n'more life left in
him.
"Then Jove let fly with his thunderbolts, and the ship went round and
round, and was filled with fire and brimstone as the lightning struck
it. The men all fell int'the sea; they were carried about in the water
round the ship, looking like s'many sea-gulls, but the god presently
deprived them of all chance of getting home again.
"I stuck t'the ship till the sea knocked her sides from her keel
(which drifted about by itself) and struck the mast out of her in the
direction of the keel; but there was a backstay of stout ox-thong still
hanging about it, and with this I lashed the mast and keel together,
and getting astride of them was carried wherever the winds chose to
take me.
"[The gale from the West had now spent its force, and the wind got into
the South again, which frightened me lest I should be taken back t'the
terrible whirlpool of Charybdis. This indeed was what actually
happened, for I was borne along by the waves all night, and by sunrise
had reached the rock of Scylla, and the whirlpool. She was then sucking
down the salt sea water,106 but I was carried aloft toward the fig
tree, which I caught hold of and clung on t'like a bat. I could not
plant my feet anywhere s'as t'stand securely, for the roots were a
long way off and the boughs that overshadowed the whole pool were too
high, to'vast, and to'far apart for me t'reach them; s'I hung
patiently on, waiting till the pool should discharge my mast and raft
again—and a very long while it seemed. A jury-man is not more glad to
get home t'supper, after having been long detained in court by
troublesome cases, than I was t'see my raft beginning t'work its way
out of the whirlpool again. At last I let g'with my hands and feet,
and fell heavily int'the sea, hard by my raft on t'which I then got,
and began t'row with my hands. As for Scylla, the father of gods and
men would not let her get further sight of me—otherwise I should have
certainly been lost.107
"Hence I was carried along for nine days till on the tenth night the
gods stranded me on the Ogygian island, where dwells the great and
powerful goddess Calypso. She took me in and was kind t'me, but I need
say n'more about this, for I told you and your noble wife all about it
yesterday, and I hate saying the same thing over and over again."

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: The gods punish the men for their actions.
characters.quote: the gods began at once t'show signs and wonders among us, for the hides of the cattle crawled about, and the joints upon the spits began t'low like cows, and the meat, whether cooked or raw, kept on making a noise just as cows do.

characters.name: Survival Instinct
characters.role: The struggle to survive against overwhelming odds.
characters.quote: I lashed the mast and keel together, and getting astride of them was carried wherever the winds chose to take me.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.role: The loss of crew members and the impact of tragedy.
characters.quote: the bones of his head were crushed t'pieces, and he fell overboard as though he were diving, with n'more life left in him.

characters.name: Isolation And Captivity
characters.role: The feeling of being alone in a vast and dangerous world.
characters.quote: I could not plant my feet anywhere s'as t'stand securely, for the roots were a long way off and the boughs that overshadowed the whole pool were too high, to'vast, and to'far apart for me t'reach them; s'I hung patiently on, waiting till the pool should discharge my mast and raft again.

scenes.title: Ulysses' Farewell
scenes.summary: Ulysses bids farewell to the Phaeacians.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES LEAVES SCHERIA AND RETURNS T'ITHACA.
Thus did he speak, and they all held their peace throughout the covered
cloister, enthralled by the charm of his story, till presently Alcinous
began t'speak.
"Ulysses," said he, "now that you have reached my house I doubt not you
will get home without further misadventure n'matter how much you have
suffered in the past. T'you others, however, wh'come here night after
night t'drink my choicest wine and listen t'my bard, I would insist
as follows. Our guest has already packed up the clothes, wrought
gold,108 and other valuables which you have brought for his acceptance;
let us now, therefore, present him further, each one of us, with a
large tripod and a cauldron. We will recoup ourselves by the levy of a
general rate; for private individuals cannot be expected t'bear the
burden of such a handsome present."
Every one approved of this, and then they went home t'bed each in his
own abode. When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared they
hurried down t'the ship and brought their cauldrons with them.
Alcinous went on board and saw everything s'securely stowed under the
ship's benches that nothing could break adrift and injure the rowers.
Then they went t'the house of Alcinous t'get dinner, and he
sacrificed a bull for them in honour of Jove wh'is the lord of all.
They set the steaks t'grill and made an excellent dinner, after which
the inspired bard, Demodocus, wh'was a favourite with every one, sang
t'them; but Ulysses kept on turning his eyes towards the sun, as
though t'hasten his setting, for he was longing t'be on his way. As
one wh'has been all day ploughing a fallow field with a couple of oxen
keeps thinking about his supper and is glad when night comes that he
may g'and get it, for it is all his legs can d't'carry him, even so
did Ulysses rejoice when the sun went down, and he at once said t'the
Phaeacians, addressing himself more particularly t'King Alcinous:
"Sir, and all of you, farewell. Make your drink-offerings and send me
on my way rejoicing, for you have fulfilled my heart's desire by giving
me an escort, and making me presents, which heaven grant that I may
turn t'good account; may I find my admirable wife living in peace
among friends,109 and may you whom I leave behind me give satisfaction
t'your wives and children;110 may heaven vouchsafe you every good
grace, and may n'evil thing come among your people."
Thus did he speak. His hearers all of them approved his saying and
agreed that he should have his escort inasmuch as he had spoken
reasonably. Alcinous therefore said t'his servant, "Pontonous, mix

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.role: Ulysses expresses his longing to return home after his adventures.
characters.quote: ...for he was longing t'be on his way.

characters.name: Generosity
characters.role: The Phaeacians show their hospitality and generosity towards Ulysses.
characters.quote: ...let us now, therefore, present him further, each one of us, with a large tripod and a cauldron.

characters.name: Farewell
characters.role: Ulysses bids farewell to the Phaeacians, marking the end of his stay.
characters.quote: Sir, and all of you, farewell.

scenes.title: Journey to Ithaca
scenes.summary: Ulysses sails home and falls asleep.
scenes.text:
some wine and hand it round t'everybody, that we may offer a prayer to
father Jove, and speed our guest upon his way."
Pontonous mixed the wine and handed it t'every one in turn; the others
each from his own seat made a drink-offering t'the blessed gods that
live in heaven, but Ulysses rose and placed the double cup in the hands
of queen Arete.
"Farewell, queen," said he, "henceforward and for ever, till age and
death, the common lot of mankind, lay their hands upon you. I now take
my leave; be happy in this house with your children, your people, and
with king Alcinous."
As he spoke he crossed the threshold, and Alcinous sent a man to
conduct him t'his ship and t'the sea shore. Arete als'sent some
maidservants with him—one with a clean shirt and cloak, another to
carry his strong box, and a third with corn and wine. When they got to
the water side the crew took these things and put them on board, with
all the meat and drink; but for Ulysses they spread a rug and a linen
sheet on deck that he might sleep soundly in the stern of the ship.
Then he to'went on board and lay down without a word, but the crew
took every man his place and loosed the hawser from the pierced stone
t'which it had been bound. Thereon, when they began rowing out t'sea,
Ulysses fell int'a deep, sweet, and almost deathlike slumber.111
The ship bounded forward on her way as a four in hand chariot flies
over the course when the horses feel the whip. Her prow curvetted as it
were the neck of a stallion, and a great wave of dark blue water
seethed in her wake. She held steadily on her course, and even a
falcon, swiftest of all birds, could not have kept pace with her. Thus,
then, she cut her way through the water, carrying one wh'was as
cunning as the gods, but wh'was now sleeping peacefully, forgetful of
all that he had suffered both on the field of battle and by the waves
of the weary sea.

characters.name: Farewell
characters.role: Signifies Ulysses' departure and the end of a chapter in his journey.
characters.quote: Farewell, queen, said he, henceforward and for ever, till age and death, the common lot of mankind, lay their hands upon you.

characters.name: Rest And Refuge
characters.role: Highlights Ulysses' need for rest after his long journey.
characters.quote: Ulysses fell int'a deep, sweet, and almost deathlike slumber.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Represents the blessings and support from the gods as Ulysses departs.
characters.quote: the others each from his own seat made a drink-offering t'the blessed gods that live in heaven

scenes.title: Arrival at Ithaca
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives at Ithaca and is confused.
scenes.text:
When the bright star that heralds the approach of dawn began t'show,
the ship drew near t'land.112 Now there is in Ithaca a haven of the
old merman Phorcys, which lies between tw'points that break the line
of the sea and shut the harbour in. These shelter it from the storms of
wind and sea that rage outside, s'that, when once within it, a ship
may lie without being even moored. At the head of this harbour there is
a large olive tree, and at n'great distance a fine overarching cavern
sacred t'the nymphs wh'are called Naiads.113 There are mixing bowls
within it and wine-jars of stone, and the bees hive there. Moreover,
there are great looms of stone on which the nymphs weave their robes of
sea purple—very curious t'see—and at all times there is water within
it. It has tw'entrances, one facing North by which mortals can g'down
int'the cave, while the other comes from the South and is more
mysterious; mortals cannot possibly get in by it, it is the way taken
by the gods.
Int'this harbour, then, they took their ship, for they knew the
place.114 She had s'much way upon her that she ran half her own length
on t'the shore;115 when, however, they had landed, the first thing
they did was t'lift Ulysses with his rug and linen sheet out of the
ship, and lay him down upon the sand still fast asleep. Then they took
out the presents which Minerva had persuaded the Phaeacians t'give him
when he was setting out on his voyage homewards. They put these all
together by the root of the olive tree, away from the road, for fear
some passer by116 might come and steal them before Ulysses awoke; and
then they made the best of their way home again.

characters.role: Highlights the safety provided by the gods
characters.quote: there is in Ithaca a haven of the old merman Phorcys, which lies between tw'points that break the line of the sea and shut the harbour in.

characters.role: Signifies a moment of peace for Ulysses

characters.name: Generosity

characters.quote: the presents which Minerva had persuaded the Phaeacians t'give him when he was setting out on his voyage homewards.

scenes.title: Neptune's Wrath 2
scenes.summary: Neptune plots against the Phaeacians.
scenes.text:
But Neptune did not forget the threats with which he had already
threatened Ulysses, s'he took counsel with Jove. "Father Jove," said
he, "I shall n'longer be held in any sort of respect among you gods,
if mortals like the Phaeacians, wh'are my own flesh and blood, show
such small regard for me. I said I would let Ulysses get home when he
had suffered sufficiently. I did not say that he should never get home
at all, for I knew you had already nodded your head about it, and
promised that he should d'so; but now they have brought him in a ship
fast asleep and have landed him in Ithaca after loading him with more
magnificent presents of bronze, gold, and raiment than he would ever
have brought back from Troy, if he had had his share of the spoil and
got home without misadventure."
And Jove answered, "What, 'Lord of the Earthquake, are you talking
about? The gods are by n'means wanting in respect for you. It would be
monstrous were they t'insult one s'old and honoured as you are. As
regards mortals, however, if any of them is indulging in insolence and
treating you disrespectfully, it will always rest with yourself t'deal
with him as you may think proper, s'd'just as you please."
"I should have done s'at once," replied Neptune, "if I were not
anxious t'avoid anything that might displease you; now, therefore, I
should like t'wreck the Phaeacian ship as it is returning from its
escort. This will stop them from escorting people in future; and I
should als'like t'bury their city under a huge mountain."
"My good friend," answered Jove, "I should recommend you at the very
moment when the people from the city are watching the ship on her way,
t'turn it int'a rock near the land and looking like a ship. This will
astonish everybody, and you can then bury their city under the
mountain."
When earth-encircling Neptune heard this he went t'Scheria where the
Phaeacians live, and stayed there till the ship, which was making rapid
way, had got close in. Then he went up t'it, turned it int'stone, and
drove it down with the flat of his hand s'as t'root it in the ground.
After this he went away.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Neptune seeks revenge on the Phaeacians for disrespecting him.
characters.quote: I should like t'wreck the Phaeacian ship as it is returning from its escort.

characters.role: Neptune expresses concern about losing respect among the gods.

characters.name: Power And Control
characters.role: Neptune demonstrates his power over mortals and the sea.
characters.quote: This will stop them from escorting people in future; and I should als'like t'bury their city under a huge mountain.

scenes.title: Ulysses Awakens 2
scenes.summary: Ulysses wakes up on his homeland.
scenes.text:
standing round his altar; and at the same time118 Ulysses woke up once
more upon his own soil. He had been s'long away that he did not know
it again; moreover, Jove's daughter Minerva had made it a foggy day, so
that people might not know of his having come, and that she might tell
him everything without either his wife or his fellow citizens and
friends recognising him119 until he had taken his revenge upon the
wicked suitors. Everything, therefore, seemed quite different to
him—the long straight tracks, the harbours, the precipices, and the
goodly trees, appeared all changed as he started up and looked upon his
native land. S'he smote his thighs with the flat of his hands and
cried aloud despairingly.
"Alas," he exclaimed, "among what manner of people am I fallen? Are
they savage and uncivilised or hospitable and humane? Where shall I put
all this treasure, and which way shall I go? I wish I had staid over
there with the Phaeacians; or I could have gone t'some other great
chief wh'would have been good t'me and given me an escort. As it is I
d'not know where t'put my treasure, and I cannot leave it here for
fear somebody else should get hold of it. In good truth the chiefs and
rulers of the Phaeacians have not been dealing fairly by me, and have
left me in the wrong country; they said they would take me back to
Ithaca and they have not done so: may Jove the protector of suppliants
chastise them, for he watches over everybody and punishes those wh'do
wrong. Still, I suppose I must count my goods and see if the crew have
gone off with any of them."
He counted his goodly coppers and cauldrons, his gold and all his
clothes, but there was nothing missing; still he kept grieving about
not being in his own country, and wandered up and down by the shore of
the sounding sea bewailing his hard fate. Then Minerva came up t'him

characters.name: Identity
characters.role: Ulysses struggles to recognize his homeland and himself after a long absence.
characters.quote: Alas, he exclaimed, "among what manner of people am I fallen?"

characters.name: Betrayal
characters.role: Ulysses feels betrayed by the Phaeacians for not returning him home as promised.
characters.quote: In good truth the chiefs and rulers of the Phaeacians have not been dealing fairly by me, and have left me in the wrong country; they said they would take me back to Ithaca and they have not done so.

characters.name: Isolation And Captivity
characters.role: Ulysses feels alone and uncertain in his own land, highlighting his isolation.
characters.quote: Still, he kept grieving about not being in his own country, and wandered up and down by the shore of the sounding sea bewailing his hard fate.

scenes.title: Meeting Minerva
scenes.summary: Ulysses meets Minerva disguised as a shepherd.
scenes.text:
disguised as a young shepherd of delicate and princely mien, with a
good cloak folded double about her shoulders; she had sandals on her
comely feet and held a javelin in her hand. Ulysses was glad when he
saw her, and went straight up t'her.
"My friend," said he, "you are the first person whom I have met with in
this country; I salute you, therefore, and beg you t'be well disposed
towards me. Protect these my goods, and myself too, for I embrace your
knees and pray t'you as though you were a god. Tell me, then, and tell
me truly, what land and country is this? Wh'are its inhabitants? Am I
on an island, or is this the sea board of some continent?"
Minerva answered, "Stranger, you must be very simple, or must have come
from somewhere a long way off, not t'know what country this is. It is
a very celebrated place, and everybody knows it East and West. It is
rugged and not a good driving country, but it is by n'means a bad
island for what there is of it. It grows any quantity of corn and also
wine, for it is watered both by rain and dew; it breeds cattle als'and
goats; all kinds of timber grow here, and there are watering places
where the water never runs dry; so, sir, the name of Ithaca is known
even as far as Troy, which I understand t'be a long way off from this
Achaean country."
Ulysses was glad at finding himself, as Minerva told him, in his own
country, and he began t'answer, but he did not speak the truth, and
made up a lying story in the instinctive wiliness of his heart.
"I heard of Ithaca," said he, "when I was in Crete beyond the seas, and
now it seems I have reached it with all these treasures. I have left as
much more behind me for my children, but am flying because I killed
Orsilochus son of Idomeneus, the fleetest runner in Crete. I killed him
because he wanted t'rob me of the spoils I had got from Troy with so
much trouble and danger both on the field of battle and by the waves of
the weary sea; he said I had not served his father loyally at Troy as
vassal, but had set myself up as an independent ruler, s'I lay in wait
for him with one of my followers by the road side, and speared him as
he was coming int'town from the country. It was a very dark night and
nobody saw us; it was not known, therefore, that I had killed him, but
as soon as I had done s'I went t'a ship and besought the owners, who
were Phoenicians, t'take me on board and set me in Pylos or in Elis
where the Epeans rule, giving them as much spoil as satisfied them.
They meant n'guile, but the wind drove them off their course, and we
sailed on till we came hither by night. It was all we could d't'get
inside the harbour, and none of us said a word about supper though we
wanted it badly, but we all went on shore and lay down just as we were.
I was very tired and fell asleep directly, s'they took my goods out of
the ship, and placed them beside me where I was lying upon the sand.
Then they sailed away t'Sidonia, and I was left here in great distress
of mind."
Such was his story, but Minerva smiled and caressed him with her hand.

characters.role: Ulysses conceals his true identity while seeking help.

characters.fake_quote: The act of crafting a lie showcases the character's cunning nature and the anxiety that accompanies deception.

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.role: Ulysses expresses relief at being back in his homeland.
characters.quote: Ulysses was glad at finding himself, as Minerva told him, in his own country.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Minerva provides assistance and information to Ulysses.
