scenes.title: Recognition of Ulysses
scenes.summary: Penelope learns of Ulysses' return from Euryclea.
scenes.text:
PENELOPE EVENTUALLY RECOGNISES HER HUSBAND—EARLY IN THE MORNING
ULYSSES, TELEMACHUS, EUMAEUS, AND PHILOETIUS LEAVE THE TOWN.
Euryclea now went upstairs laughing t'tell her mistress that her dear
husband had come home. Her aged knees became young again and her feet
were nimble for joy as she went up t'her mistress and bent over her
head t'speak t'her. "Wake up Penelope, my dear child," she exclaimed,
"and see with your own eyes something that you have been wanting this
long time past. Ulysses has at last indeed come home again, and has
killed the suitors wh'were giving s'much trouble in his house, eating
up his estate and ill treating his son."
"My good nurse," answered Penelope, "you must be mad. The gods
sometimes send some very sensible people out of their minds, and make
foolish people become sensible. This is what they must have been doing
t'you; for you always used t'be a reasonable person. Why should you
thus mock me when I have trouble enough already—talking such nonsense,
and waking me up out of a sweet sleep that had taken possession of my
eyes and closed them? I have never slept s'soundly from the day my
poor husband went t'that city with the ill-omened name. G'back again
int'the women's room; if it had been any one else wh'had woke me up
t'bring me such absurd news I should have sent her away with a severe
scolding. As it is your age shall protect you."
"My dear child," answered Euryclea, "I am not mocking you. It is quite
true as I tell you that Ulysses is come home again. He was the stranger
whom they all kept on treating s'badly in the cloister. Telemachus
knew all the time that he was come back, but kept his father's secret
that he might have his revenge on all these wicked people."
Then Penelope sprang up from her couch, threw her arms round Euryclea,
and wept for joy. "But my dear nurse," said she, "explain this t'me;
if he has really come home as you say, how did he manage t'overcome
the wicked suitors single handed, seeing what a number of them there
always were?"
"I was not there," answered Euryclea, "and d'not know; I only heard
them groaning while they were being killed. We sat crouching and
huddled up in a corner of the women's room with the doors closed, till
your son came t'fetch me because his father sent him. Then I found
Ulysses standing over the corpses that were lying on the ground all
round him, one on top of the other. You would have enjoyed it if you
could have seen him standing there all bespattered with blood and
filth, and looking just like a lion. But the corpses are now all piled
up in the gatehouse that is in the outer court, and Ulysses has lit a
great fire t'purify the house with sulphur. He has sent me t'call
you, s'come with me that you may both be happy together after all; for
now at last the desire of your heart has been fulfilled; your husband
is come home t'find both wife and son alive and well, and t'take his
revenge in his own house on the suitors wh'behaved s'badly t'him."

characters.name: Joyful Reunion
characters.role: Penelope's emotional response to Ulysses' return
characters.quote: Then Penelope sprang up from her couch, threw her arms round Euryclea, and wept for joy.

characters.name: Skepticism
characters.role: Penelope's initial disbelief about Ulysses' return
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Doubt and confusion arise from the unpredictable nature of divine influence, leading to a questioning of reality.

characters.name: Revenge
characters.role: Ulysses' actions against the suitors
characters.quote: Ulysses has at last indeed come home again, and has killed the suitors wh'were giving s'much trouble in his house.

scenes.title: Penelope's Doubts 2
scenes.summary: Penelope expresses skepticism about Ulysses' return.
scenes.text:
"My dear nurse," said Penelope, "d'not exult to'confidently over all
this. You know how delighted every one would be t'see Ulysses come
home—more particularly myself, and the son wh'has been born t'both of
us; but what you tell me cannot be really true. It is some god wh'is
angry with the suitors for their great wickedness, and has made an end
of them; for they respected n'man in the whole world, neither rich nor
poor, wh'came near them, and they have come t'a bad end in
consequence of their iniquity; Ulysses is dead far away from the
Achaean land; he will never return home again."
Then nurse Euryclea said, "My child, what are you talking about? but
you were all hard of belief and have made up your mind that your
husband is never coming, although he is in the house and by his own
fire side at this very moment. Besides I can give you another proof;
when I was washing him I perceived the scar which the wild boar gave
him, and I wanted t'tell you about it, but in his wisdom he would not
let me, and clapped his hands over my mouth; s'come with me and I will
make this bargain with you—if I am deceiving you, you may have me
killed by the most cruel death you can think of."
"My dear nurse," said Penelope, "however wise you may be you can hardly
fathom the counsels of the gods. Nevertheless, we will g'in search of
my son, that I may see the corpses of the suitors, and the man wh'has
killed them."
On this she came down from her upper room, and while doing s'she
considered whether she should keep at a distance from her husband and
question him, or whether she should at once g'up t'him and embrace
him. When, however, she had crossed the stone floor of the cloister,
she sat down opposite Ulysses by the fire, against the wall at right
angles180 [t'that by which she had entered], while Ulysses sat near
one of the bearing-posts, looking upon the ground, and waiting t'see
what his brave wife would say t'him when she saw him. For a long time
she sat silent and as one lost in amazement. At one moment she looked
him full in the face, but then again directly, she was misled by his
shabby clothes and failed t'recognise him,181 till Telemachus began to
reproach her and said:
"Mother—but you are s'hard that I cannot call you by such a name—why
d'you keep away from my father in this way? Why d'you not sit by his
side and begin talking t'him and asking him questions? N'other woman
could bear t'keep away from her husband when he had come back t'her
after twenty years of absence, and after having gone through s'much;
but your heart always was as hard as a stone."
Penelope answered, "My son, I am s'lost in astonishment that I can
find n'words in which either t'ask questions or t'answer them. I
cannot even look him straight in the face. Still, if he really is
Ulysses come back t'his own home again, we shall get t'understand one
another better by and by, for there are tokens with which we tw'are
alone acquainted, and which are hidden from all others."

characters.name: Doubt And Recognition
characters.role: Penelope struggles to recognize Ulysses due to disbelief and confusion.
characters.quote: I cannot even look him straight in the face.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Penelope believes the gods are involved in the fate of Ulysses and the suitors.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The interplay of skepticism and hope reflects the uncertainty surrounding divine promises and their fulfillment.

characters.name: Longing And Reunion
characters.role: The theme of longing for Ulysses and the hope for reunion is central to Penelope's character.
characters.quote: if he really is Ulysses come back t'his own home again, we shall get t'understand one another better by and by.

scenes.title: Penelope Meets Ulysses
scenes.summary: Penelope approaches Ulysses but hesitates to embrace him.
scenes.text:
Ulysses smiled at this, and said t'Telemachus, "Let your mother put me
t'any proof she likes; she will make up her mind about it presently.
She rejects me for the moment and believes me t'be somebody else,
because I am covered with dirt and have such bad clothes on; let us,
however, consider what we had better d'next. When one man has killed
another—even though he was not one wh'would leave many friends t'take
up his quarrel—the man wh'has killed him must still say good bye to
his friends and fly the country; whereas we have been killing the stay
of a whole town, and all the picked youth of Ithaca. I would have you
consider this matter."
"Look t'it yourself, father," answered Telemachus, "for they say you
are the wisest counsellor in the world, and that there is n'other
mortal man wh'can compare with you. We will follow you with right good
will, nor shall you find us fail you in s'far as our strength holds
out."
"I will say what I think will be best," answered Ulysses. "First wash
and put your shirts on; tell the maids als't'g't'their own room and
dress; Phemius shall then strike up a dance tune on his lyre, s'that
if people outside hear, or any of the neighbours, or some one going
along the street happens t'notice it, they may think there is a
wedding in the house, and n'rumours about the death of the suitors
will get about in the town, before we can escape t'the woods upon my
own land. Once there, we will settle which of the courses heaven
vouchsafes us shall seem wisest."
Thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said. First they washed
and put their shirts on, while the women got ready. Then Phemius took
his lyre and set them all longing for sweet song and stately dance. The
house re-echoed with the sound of men and women dancing, and the people
outside said, "I suppose the queen has been getting married at last.
She ought t'be ashamed of herself for not continuing t'protect her
husband's property until he comes home."182
This was what they said, but they did not know what it was that had
been happening. The upper servant Eurynome washed and anointed Ulysses
in his own house and gave him a shirt and cloak, while Minerva made him
look taller and stronger than before; she als'made the hair grow thick
on the top of his head, and flow down in curls like hyacinth blossoms;
she glorified him about the head and shoulders just as a skilful
workman wh'has studied art of all kinds under Vulcan or Minerva—and
his work is full of beauty—enriches a piece of silver plate by gilding
it. He came from the bath looking like one of the immortals, and sat
down opposite his wife on the seat he had left. "My dear," said he,
"heaven has endowed you with a heart more unyielding than woman ever
yet had. N'other woman could bear t'keep away from her husband when
he had come back t'her after twenty years of absence, and after having
gone through s'much. But come, nurse, get a bed ready for me; I will
sleep alone, for this woman has a heart as hard as iron."
"My dear," answered Penelope, "I have n'wish t'set myself up, nor to
depreciate you; but I am not struck by your appearance, for I very well
remember what kind of a man you were when you set sail from Ithaca.
Nevertheless, Euryclea, take his bed outside the bed chamber that he

characters.name: Recognition Of Identity
characters.role: Ulysses struggles to be recognized by Penelope after his long absence.
characters.quote: heaven has endowed you with a heart more unyielding than woman ever yet had.

characters.name: Deception And Strategy
characters.role: Ulysses devises a plan to mislead the townspeople about the suitors' deaths.
characters.quote: they may think there is a wedding in the house, and n'rumours about the death of the suitors will get about in the town.

characters.name: Homecoming And Reunion
characters.role: The scene highlights the emotional weight of Ulysses' return home after many years.
characters.quote: I will sleep alone, for this woman has a heart as hard as iron.

scenes.title: The Test of the Bed
scenes.summary: Ulysses proves his identity through the bed's secret.
scenes.text:
himself built. Bring the bed outside this room, and put bedding upon it
with fleeces, good coverlets, and blankets."
She said this t'try him, but Ulysses was very angry and said, "Wife, I
am much displeased at what you have just been saying. Wh'has been
taking my bed from the place in which I left it? He must have found it
a hard task, n'matter how skilled a workman he was, unless some god
came and helped him t'shift it. There is n'man living, however strong
and in his prime, wh'could move it from its place, for it is a
marvellous curiosity which I made with my very own hands. There was a
young olive growing within the precincts of the house, in full vigour,
and about as thick as a bearing-post. I built my room round this with
strong walls of stone and a roof t'cover them, and I made the doors
strong and well-fitting. Then I cut off the top boughs of the olive
tree and left the stump standing. This I dressed roughly from the root
upwards and then worked with carpenter's tools well and skilfully,
straightening my work by drawing a line on the wood, and making it into
a bed-prop. I then bored a hole down the middle, and made it the
centre-post of my bed, at which I worked till I had finished it,
inlaying it with gold and silver; after this I stretched a hide of
crimson leather from one side of it t'the other. S'you see I know all
about it, and I desire t'learn whether it is still there, or whether
any one has been removing it by cutting down the olive tree at its
roots."
When she heard the sure proofs Ulysses now gave her, she fairly broke
down. She flew weeping t'his side, flung her arms about his neck, and
kissed him. "D'not be angry with me Ulysses," she cried, "you, wh'are
the wisest of mankind. We have suffered, both of us. Heaven has denied
us the happiness of spending our youth, and of growing old, together;
d'not then be aggrieved or take it amiss that I did not embrace you
thus as soon as I saw you. I have been shuddering all the time through
fear that someone might come here and deceive me with a lying story;
for there are many very wicked people going about. Jove's daughter
Helen would never have yielded herself t'a man from a foreign country,
if she had known that the sons of Achaeans would come after her and
bring her back. Heaven put it in her heart t'd'wrong, and she gave no
thought t'that sin, which has been the source of all our sorrows. Now,
however, that you have convinced me by showing that you know all about
our bed (which n'human being has ever seen but you and I and a single
maidservant, the daughter of Actor, wh'was given me by my father on my
marriage, and wh'keeps the doors of our room) hard of belief though I
have been I can mistrust n'longer."

characters.name: Trust And Deception
characters.role: Ulysses seeks to prove his identity to Penelope.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The relief and joy that come from recognizing genuine trust highlight the importance of honesty in relationships.

characters.name: Memory And Loss
characters.role: Ulysses reflects on their shared past and the bed's significance.
characters.quote: Heaven has denied us the happiness of spending our youth, and of growing old, together;

characters.name: Craftsmanship And Identity
characters.role: Ulysses describes the bed he built, symbolizing his identity and skills.
characters.quote: There is n'man living, however strong and in his prime, wh'could move it from its place, for it is a marvellous curiosity which I made with my very own hands.

scenes.title: Emotional Reunion
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Penelope embrace after confirming their identities.
scenes.text:
Then Ulysses in his turn melted, and wept as he clasped his dear and
faithful wife t'his bosom. As the sight of land is welcome t'men who
are swimming towards the shore, when Neptune has wrecked their ship
with the fury of his winds and waves; a few alone reach the land, and
these, covered with brine, are thankful when they find themselves on
firm ground and out of danger—even s'was her husband welcome t'her as
she looked upon him, and she could not tear her tw'fair arms from
about his neck. Indeed they would have gone on indulging their sorrow
till rosy-fingered morn appeared, had not Minerva determined otherwise,
and held night back in the far west, while she would not suffer Dawn to
leave Oceanus, nor t'yoke the tw'steeds Lampus and Phaethon that bear
her onward t'break the day upon mankind.

characters.name: Love And Reunion
characters.role: Central theme of the scene
characters.quote: Then Ulysses in his turn melted, and wept as he clasped his dear and faithful wife t'his bosom.

characters.name: Longing And Relief
characters.role: Describes the emotional state of the characters
characters.quote: As the sight of land is welcome t'men who are swimming towards the shore, when Neptune has wrecked their ship with the fury of his winds and waves; a few alone reach the land, and these, covered with brine, are thankful when they find themselves on firm ground and out of danger—even s'was her husband welcome t'her as she looked upon him, and she could not tear her tw'fair arms from about his neck.

scenes.title: Plans for the Future
scenes.summary: Ulysses discusses future plans with Penelope.
scenes.text:
At last, however, Ulysses said, "Wife, we have not yet reached the end
of our troubles. I have an unknown amount of toil still t'undergo. It
is long and difficult, but I must g'through with it, for thus the
shade of Teiresias prophesied concerning me, on the day when I went
down int'Hades t'ask about my return and that of my companions. But
now let us g't'bed, that we may lie down and enjoy the blessed boon
of sleep."
"You shall g't'bed as soon as you please," replied Penelope, "now
that the gods have sent you home t'your own good house and t'your
country. But as heaven has put it in your mind t'speak of it, tell me
about the task that lies before you. I shall have t'hear about it
later, s'it is better that I should be told at once."
"My dear," answered Ulysses, "why should you press me t'tell you?
Still, I will not conceal it from you, though you will not like it. I
d'not like it myself, for Teiresias bade me travel far and wide,
carrying an oar, till I came t'a country where the people have never
heard of the sea, and d'not even mix salt with their food. They know
nothing about ships, nor oars that are as the wings of a ship. He gave
me this certain token which I will not hide from you. He said that a
wayfarer should meet me and ask me whether it was a winnowing shovel
that I had on my shoulder. On this, I was t'fix my oar in the ground
and sacrifice a ram, a bull, and a boar t'Neptune; after which I was
t'g'home and offer hecatombs t'all the gods in heaven, one after the
other. As for myself, he said that death should come t'me from the
sea, and that my life should ebb away very gently when I was full of
years and peace of mind, and my people should bless me. All this, he
said, should surely come t'pass."
And Penelope said, "If the gods are going t'vouchsafe you a happier
time in your old age, you may hope then t'have some respite from
misfortune."
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile Eurynome and the nurse took torches
and made the bed ready with soft coverlets; as soon as they had laid
them, the nurse went back int'the house t'g't'her rest, leaving the
bed chamber woman Eurynome183 t'show Ulysses and Penelope t'bed by
torch light. When she had conducted them t'their room she went back,
and they then came joyfully t'the rites of their own old bed.
Telemachus, Philoetius, and the swineherd now left off dancing, and
made the women leave off also. They then laid themselves down t'sleep
in the cloisters.
When Ulysses and Penelope had had their fill of love they fell talking
with one another. She told him how much she had had t'bear in seeing
the house filled with a crowd of wicked suitors wh'had killed s'many
sheep and oxen on her account, and had drunk s'many casks of wine.
Ulysses in his turn told her what he had suffered, and how much trouble
he had himself given t'other people. He told her everything, and she
was s'delighted t'listen that she never went t'sleep till he had
ended his whole story.
He began with his victory over the Cicons, and how he thence reached
the fertile land of the Lotus-eaters. He told her all about the Cyclops
and how he had punished him for having s'ruthlessly eaten his brave
comrades; how he then went on t'Aeolus, wh'received him hospitably
and furthered him on his way, but even s'he was not t'reach home, for
t'his great grief a hurricane carried him out t'sea again; how he
went on t'the Laestrygonian city Telepylos, where the people destroyed
all his ships with their crews, save himself and his own ship only.
Then he told of cunning Circe and her craft, and how he sailed t'the
chill house of Hades, t'consult the ghost of the Theban prophet
Teiresias, and how he saw his old comrades in arms, and his mother who
bore him and brought him up when he was a child; how he then heard the
wondrous singing of the Sirens, and went on t'the wandering rocks and
terrible Charybdis and t'Scylla, whom n'man had ever yet passed in
safety; how his men then ate the cattle of the sun-god, and how Jove
therefore struck the ship with his thunderbolts, s'that all his men
perished together, himself alone being left alive; how at last he
reached the Ogygian island and the nymph Calypso, wh'kept him there in
a cave, and fed him, and wanted him t'marry her, in which case she
intended making him immortal s'that he should never grow old, but she
could not persuade him t'let her d'so; and how after much suffering
he had found his way t'the Phaeacians, wh'had treated him as though
he had been a god, and sent him back in a ship t'his own country after
having given him gold, bronze, and raiment in great abundance. This was
the last thing about which he told her, for here a deep sleep took hold
upon him and eased the burden of his sorrows.
Then Minerva bethought her of another matter. When she deemed that
Ulysses had had both of his wife and of repose, she bade gold-enthroned
Dawn rise out of Oceanus that she might shed light upon mankind. On
this, Ulysses rose from his comfortable bed and said t'Penelope,
"Wife, we have both of us had our full share of troubles, you, here, in
lamenting my absence, and I in being prevented from getting home though
I was longing all the time t'd'so. Now, however, that we have at last
come together, take care of the property that is in the house. As for
the sheep and goats which the wicked suitors have eaten, I will take
many myself by force from other people, and will compel the Achaeans to
make good the rest till they shall have filled all my yards. I am now
going t'the wooded lands out in the country t'see my father wh'has
s'long been grieved on my account, and t'yourself I will give these
instructions, though you have little need of them. At sunrise it will
at once get abroad that I have been killing the suitors; g'upstairs,
therefore,184 and stay there with your women. See nobody and ask no
questions."185

characters.name: Endurance
characters.role: Ulysses reflects on his long journey and the trials he has faced.
characters.quote: I have an unknown amount of toil still t'undergo. It is long and difficult, but I must g'through with it, for thus the shade of Teiresias prophesied concerning me.

characters.name: Love And Reunion
characters.role: The emotional connection between Ulysses and Penelope is highlighted as they share their experiences.
characters.quote: She was s'delighted t'listen that she never went t'sleep till he had ended his whole story.

characters.name: Fate And Prophecy
characters.role: Ulysses discusses the prophecy given to him by Teiresias, indicating his future challenges and destiny.
characters.quote: He said that death should come t'me from the sea, and that my life should ebb away very gently when I was full of years and peace of mind.

characters.name: Loss And Suffering
characters.role: Ulysses recounts the hardships he faced during his journey, emphasizing the theme of loss.
characters.quote: how much trouble he had himself given t'other people.

characters.name: Restoration
characters.role: Ulysses plans to restore his household and reclaim what was lost due to the suitors.
characters.quote: I will take many myself by force from other people, and will compel the Achaeans to make good the rest till they shall have filled all my yards.

scenes.title: Preparation for Departure
scenes.summary: Ulysses prepares to leave the house with his allies.
scenes.text:
As he spoke he girded on his armour. Then he roused Telemachus,
Philoetius, and Eumaeus, and told them all t'put on their armour also.
This they did, and armed themselves. When they had done so, they opened
the gates and sallied forth, Ulysses leading the way. It was now
daylight, but Minerva nevertheless concealed them in darkness and led
them quickly out of the town.

characters.name: Preparation For Battle
characters.role: The act of arming themselves signifies readiness for conflict.
characters.quote: As he spoke he girded on his armour.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.role: Minerva's concealment indicates divine support in their endeavor.
characters.quote: Minerva nevertheless concealed them in darkness

scenes.title: Ghosts in Hades
scenes.summary: Mercury leads the ghosts of the suitors to Hades.
scenes.text:
THE GHOSTS OF THE SUITORS IN HADES—ULYSSES AND HIS MEN G'T'THE HOUSE
OF LAERTES—THE PEOPLE OF ITHACA COME OUT T'ATTACK ULYSSES, BUT MINERVA
CONCLUDES A PEACE.
Then Mercury of Cyllene summoned the ghosts of the suitors, and in his
hand he held the fair golden wand with which he seals men's eyes in
sleep or wakes them just as he pleases; with this he roused the ghosts
and led them, while they followed whining and gibbering behind him. As
bats fly squealing in the hollow of some great cave, when one of them
has fallen out of the cluster in which they hang, even s'did the
ghosts whine and squeal as Mercury the healer of sorrow led them down
int'the dark abode of death. When they had passed the waters of
Oceanus and the rock Leucas, they came t'the gates of the sun and the
land of dreams, whereon they reached the meadow of asphodel where dwell
the souls and shadows of them that can labour n'more.
Here they found the ghost of Achilles son of Peleus, with those of
Patroclus, Antilochus, and Ajax, wh'was the finest and handsomest man
of all the Danaans after the son of Peleus himself.
They gathered round the ghost of the son of Peleus, and the ghost of
Agamemnon joined them, sorrowing bitterly. Round him were gathered also
the ghosts of those wh'had perished with him in the house of
Aegisthus; and the ghost of Achilles spoke first.
"Son of Atreus," it said, "we used t'say that Jove had loved you
better from first t'last than any other hero, for you were captain
over many and brave men, when we were all fighting together before
Troy; yet the hand of death, which n'mortal can escape, was laid upon
you all to'early. Better for you had you fallen at Troy in the hey-day
of your renown, for the Achaeans would have built a mound over your
ashes, and your son would have been heir t'your good name, whereas it
has now been your lot t'come t'a most miserable end."
"Happy son of Peleus," answered the ghost of Agamemnon, "for having
died at Troy far from Argos, while the bravest of the Trojans and the
Achaeans fell round you fighting for your body. There you lay in the
whirling clouds of dust, all huge and hugely, heedless now of your
chivalry. We fought the whole of the livelong day, nor should we ever
have left off if Jove had not sent a hurricane t'stay us. Then, when
we had borne you t'the ships out of the fray, we laid you on your bed
and cleansed your fair skin with warm water and with ointments. The
Danaans tore their hair and wept bitterly round about you. Your mother,
when she heard, came with her immortal nymphs from out of the sea, and
the sound of a great wailing went forth over the waters s'that the
Achaeans quaked for fear. They would have fled panic-stricken t'their
ships had not wise old Nestor whose counsel was ever truest checked
them saying, 'Hold, Argives, fly not sons of the Achaeans, this is his
mother coming from the sea with her immortal nymphs t'view the body of
her son.'
"Thus he spoke, and the Achaeans feared n'more. The daughters of the
old man of the sea stood round you weeping bitterly, and clothed you in
immortal raiment. The nine muses als'came and lifted up their sweet
voices in lament—calling and answering one another; there was not an
Argive but wept for pity of the dirge they chaunted. Days and nights
seven and ten we mourned you, mortals and immortals, but on the
eighteenth day we gave you t'the flames, and many a fat sheep with
many an ox did we slay in sacrifice around you. You were burnt in
raiment of the gods, with rich resins and with honey, while heroes,
horse and foot, clashed their armour round the pile as you were
burning, with the tramp as of a great multitude. But when the flames of
heaven had done their work, we gathered your white bones at daybreak
and laid them in ointments and in pure wine. Your mother brought us a
golden vase t'hold them—gift of Bacchus, and work of Vulcan himself;
in this we mingled your bleached bones with those of Patroclus wh'had
gone before you, and separate we enclosed als'those of Antilochus, who
had been closer t'you than any other of your comrades now that
Patroclus was n'more.
"Over these the host of the Argives built a noble tomb, on a point
jutting out over the open Hellespont, that it might be seen from far
out upon the sea by those now living and by them that shall be born
hereafter. Your mother begged prizes from the gods, and offered them to
be contended for by the noblest of the Achaeans. You must have been
present at the funeral of many a hero, when the young men gird
themselves and make ready t'contend for prizes on the death of some
great chieftain, but you never saw such prizes as silver-footed Thetis
offered in your honour; for the gods loved you well. Thus even in death
your fame, Achilles, has not been lost, and your name lives evermore
among all mankind. But as for me, what solace had I when the days of my
fighting were done? For Jove willed my destruction on my return, by the
hands of Aegisthus and those of my wicked wife."
Thus did they converse, and presently Mercury came up t'them with the
ghosts of the suitors wh'had been killed by Ulysses. The ghosts of
Agamemnon and Achilles were astonished at seeing them, and went up to
them at once. The ghost of Agamemnon recognised Amphimedon son of
Melaneus, wh'lived in Ithaca and had been his host, s'it began to
talk t'him.
"Amphimedon," it said, "what has happened t'all you fine young men—all
of an age too—that you are come down here under the ground? One could
pick n'finer body of men from any city. Did Neptune raise his winds
and waves against you when you were at sea, or did your enemies make an
end of you on the mainland when you were cattle-lifting or
sheep-stealing, or while fighting in defence of their wives and city?
Answer my question, for I have been your guest. D'you not remember how
I came t'your house with Menelaus, t'persuade Ulysses t'join us with
his ships against Troy? It was a whole month ere we could resume our
voyage, for we had hard work t'persuade Ulysses t'come with us."
And the ghost of Amphimedon answered, "Agamemnon, son of Atreus, king
of men, I remember everything that you have said, and will tell you
fully and accurately about the way in which our end was brought about.
Ulysses had been long gone, and we were courting his wife, wh'did not
say point blank that she would not marry, nor yet bring matters t'an
end, for she meant t'compass our destruction: this, then, was the
trick she played us. She set up a great tambour frame in her room and
began t'work on an enormous piece of fine needlework. 'Sweethearts,'
said she, 'Ulysses is indeed dead, still, d'not press me t'marry
again immediately; wait—for I would not have my skill in needlework
perish unrecorded—till I have completed a pall for the her'Laertes,
against the time when death shall take him. He is very rich, and the
women of the place will talk if he is laid out without a pall.' This is
what she said, and we assented; whereupon we could see her working upon
her great web all day long, but at night she would unpick the stitches
again by torchlight. She fooled us in this way for three years without
our finding it out, but as time wore on and she was now in her fourth
year, in the waning of moons and many days had been accomplished, one
of her maids wh'knew what she was doing told us, and we caught her in
the act of undoing her work, s'she had t'finish it whether she would
or no; and when she showed us the robe she had made, after she had had
it washed,186 its splendour was as that of the sun or moon.
"Then some malicious god conveyed Ulysses t'the upland farm where his
swineherd lives. Thither presently came als'his son, returning from a
voyage t'Pylos, and the tw'came t'the town when they had hatched
their plot for our destruction. Telemachus came first, and then after
him, accompanied by the swineherd, came Ulysses, clad in rags and
leaning on a staff as though he were some miserable old beggar. He came
s'unexpectedly that none of us knew him, not even the older ones among
us, and we reviled him and threw things at him. He endured both being
struck and insulted without a word, though he was in his own house; but
when the will of Aegis-bearing Jove inspired him, he and Telemachus
took the armour and hid it in an inner chamber, bolting the doors
behind them. Then he cunningly made his wife offer his bow and a
quantity of iron t'be contended for by us ill-fated suitors; and this
was the beginning of our end, for not one of us could string the
bow—nor nearly d'so. When it was about t'reach the hands of Ulysses,
we all of us shouted out that it should not be given him, n'matter
what he might say, but Telemachus insisted on his having it. When he
had got it in his hands he strung it with ease and sent his arrow
through the iron. Then he stood on the floor of the cloister and poured
his arrows on the ground, glaring fiercely about him. First he killed
Antinous, and then, aiming straight before him, he let fly his deadly
darts and they fell thick on one another. It was plain that some one of
the gods was helping them, for they fell upon us with might and main
throughout the cloisters, and there was a hideous sound of groaning as
our brains were being battered in, and the ground seethed with our
blood. This, Agamemnon, is how we came by our end, and our bodies are
lying still uncared for in the house of Ulysses, for our friends at
home d'not yet know what has happened, s'that they cannot lay us out
and wash the black blood from our wounds, making moan over us according
t'the offices due t'the departed."
"Happy Ulysses, son of Laertes," replied the ghost of Agamemnon, "you
are indeed blessed in the possession of a wife endowed with such rare
excellence of understanding, and s'faithful t'her wedded lord as
Penelope the daughter of Icarius. The fame, therefore, of her virtue
shall never die, and the immortals shall compose a song that shall be
welcome t'all mankind in honour of the constancy of Penelope. How far
otherwise was the wickedness of the daughter of Tyndareus wh'killed
her lawful husband; her song shall be hateful among men, for she has
brought disgrace on all womankind even on the good ones."
Thus did they converse in the house of Hades deep down within the

characters.name: Death And Mourning
characters.role: Explores the consequences of death and the mourning of heroes.
characters.quote: We fought the whole of the livelong day, nor should we ever have left off if Jove had not sent a hurricane t'stay us.

characters.name: Betrayal And Deceit
characters.role: Highlights the treachery of the suitors and Penelope's cunning.
characters.quote: This is what she said, and we assented; whereupon we could see her working upon her great web all day long, but at night she would unpick the stitches again by torchlight.

characters.name: Heroism And Sacrifice
characters.role: Discusses the lasting legacy of heroes and their deeds.
characters.quote: Happy Ulysses, son of Laertes, replied the ghost of Agamemnon, you are indeed blessed in the possession of a wife endowed with such rare excellence of understanding.

scenes.title: Ulysses Returns Home
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives at Laertes' farm and meets his father.
scenes.text:
bowels of the earth. Meanwhile Ulysses and the others passed out of the
town and soon reached the fair and well-tilled farm of Laertes, which
he had reclaimed with infinite labour. Here was his house, with a
lean-t'running all round it, where the slaves wh'worked for him slept
and sat and ate, while inside the house there was an old Sicel woman,
wh'looked after him in this his country-farm. When Ulysses got there,
he said t'his son and t'the other two:
"G't'the house, and kill the best pig that you can find for dinner.
Meanwhile I want t'see whether my father will know me, or fail to
recognise me after s'long an absence."
He then took off his armour and gave it t'Eumaeus and Philoetius, who
went straight on t'the house, while he turned off int'the vineyard to
make trial of his father. As he went down int'the great orchard, he
did not see Dolius, nor any of his sons nor of the other bondsmen, for
they were all gathering thorns t'make a fence for the vineyard, at the
place where the old man had told them; he therefore found his father
alone, hoeing a vine. He had on a dirty old shirt, patched and very
shabby; his legs were bound round with thongs of oxhide t'save him
from the brambles, and he als'wore sleeves of leather; he had a goat
skin cap on his head, and was looking very woe-begone. When Ulysses saw
him s'worn, s'old and full of sorrow, he stood still under a tall
pear tree and began t'weep. He doubted whether t'embrace him, kiss
him, and tell him all about his having come home, or whether he should
first question him and see what he would say. In the end he deemed it
best t'be crafty with him, s'in this mind he went up t'his father,
wh'was bending down and digging about a plant.
"I see, sir," said Ulysses, "that you are an excellent gardener—what
pains you take with it, t'be sure. There is not a single plant, not a
fig tree, vine, olive, pear, nor flower bed, but bears the trace of
your attention. I trust, however, that you will not be offended if I
say that you take better care of your garden than of yourself. You are
old, unsavoury, and very meanly clad. It cannot be because you are idle
that your master takes such poor care of you, indeed your face and
figure have nothing of the slave about them, and proclaim you of noble
birth. I should have said that you were one of those wh'should wash
well, eat well, and lie soft at night as old men have a right t'do;
but tell me, and tell me true, whose bondman are you, and in whose
garden are you working? Tell me als'about another matter. Is this
place that I have come t'really Ithaca? I met a man just now wh'said
so, but he was a dull fellow, and had not the patience t'hear my story
out when I was asking him about an old friend of mine, whether he was
still living, or was already dead and in the house of Hades. Believe me
when I tell you that this man came t'my house once when I was in my
own country and never yet did any stranger come t'me whom I liked
better. He said that his family came from Ithaca and that his father
was Laertes, son of Arceisius. I received him hospitably, making him
welcome t'all the abundance of my house, and when he went away I gave
him all customary presents. I gave him seven talents of fine gold, and
a cup of solid silver with flowers chased upon it. I gave him twelve
light cloaks, and as many pieces of tapestry; I als'gave him twelve
cloaks of single fold, twelve rugs, twelve fair mantles, and an equal
number of shirts. T'all this I added four good looking women skilled
in all useful arts, and I let him take his choice."
His father shed tears and answered, "Sir, you have indeed come t'the
country that you have named, but it is fallen int'the hands of wicked
people. All this wealth of presents has been given t'n'purpose. If
you could have found your friend here alive in Ithaca, he would have
entertained you hospitably and would have requited your presents amply
when you left him—as would have been only right considering what you
had already given him. But tell me, and tell me true, how many years is
it since you entertained this guest—my unhappy son, as ever was? Alas!
He has perished far from his own country; the fishes of the sea have
eaten him, or he has fallen a prey t'the birds and wild beasts of some
continent. Neither his mother, nor I his father, wh'were his parents,
could throw our arms about him and wrap him in his shroud, nor could
his excellent and richly dowered wife Penelope bewail her husband as
was natural upon his death bed, and close his eyes according t'the
offices due t'the departed. But now, tell me truly for I want t'know.
Wh'and whence are you—tell me of your town and parents? Where is the
ship lying that has brought you and your men t'Ithaca? Or were you a
passenger on some other man's ship, and those wh'brought you here have
gone on their way and left you?"
"I will tell you everything," answered Ulysses, "quite truly. I come
from Alybas, where I have a fine house. I am son of king Apheidas, who
is the son of Polypemon. My own name is Eperitus; heaven drove me off
my course as I was leaving Sicania, and I have been carried here
against my will. As for my ship it is lying over yonder, off the open
country outside the town, and this is the fifth year since Ulysses left
my country. Poor fellow, yet the omens were good for him when he left
me. The birds all flew on our right hands, and both he and I rejoiced
t'see them as we parted, for we had every hope that we should have
another friendly meeting and exchange presents."
A dark cloud of sorrow fell upon Laertes as he listened. He filled both
hands with the dust from off the ground and poured it over his grey
head, groaning heavily as he did so. The heart of Ulysses was touched,
and his nostrils quivered as he looked upon his father; then he sprang
towards him, flung his arms about him and kissed him, saying, "I am he,
father, about whom you are asking—I have returned after having been
away for twenty years. But cease your sighing and lamentation—we have
n'time t'lose, for I should tell you that I have been killing the
suitors in my house, t'punish them for their insolence and crimes."
"If you really are my son Ulysses," replied Laertes, "and have come
back again, you must give me such manifest proof of your identity as
shall convince me."
"First observe this scar," answered Ulysses, "which I got from a boar's
tusk when I was hunting on Mt. Parnassus. You and my mother had sent me
t'Autolycus, my mother's father, t'receive the presents which when he
was over here he had promised t'give me. Furthermore I will point out
t'you the trees in the vineyard which you gave me, and I asked you all
about them as I followed you round the garden. We went over them all,
and you told me their names and what they all were. You gave me
thirteen pear trees, ten apple trees, and forty fig trees; you also
said you would give me fifty rows of vines; there was corn planted
between each row, and they yield grapes of every kind when the heat of
heaven has been laid heavy upon them."
Laertes' strength failed him when he heard the convincing proofs which
his son had given him. He threw his arms about him, and Ulysses had to
support him, or he would have gone off int'a swoon; but as soon as he
came to, and was beginning t'recover his senses, he said, "'father
Jove, then you gods are still in Olympus after all, if the suitors have
really been punished for their insolence and folly. Nevertheless, I am
much afraid that I shall have all the townspeople of Ithaca up here
directly, and they will be sending messengers everywhere throughout the
cities of the Cephallenians."
Ulysses answered, "Take heart and d'not trouble yourself about that,
but let us g'int'the house hard by your garden. I have already told
Telemachus, Philoetius, and Eumaeus t'g'on there and get dinner ready
as soon as possible."
Thus conversing the tw'made their way towards the house. When they got
there they found Telemachus with the stockman and the swineherd cutting
up meat and mixing wine with water. Then the old Sicel woman took
Laertes inside and washed him and anointed him with oil. She put him on
a good cloak, and Minerva came up t'him and gave him a more imposing
presence, making him taller and stouter than before. When he came back
his son was surprised t'see him looking s'like an immortal, and said
t'him, "My dear father, some one of the gods has been making you much
taller and better-looking."
Laertes answered, "Would, by Father Jove, Minerva, and Apollo, that I
were the man I was when I ruled among the Cephallenians, and took
Nericum, that strong fortress on the foreland. If I were still what I
then was and had been in our house yesterday with my armour on, I
should have been able t'stand by you and help you against the suitors.
I should have killed a great many of them, and you would have rejoiced
t'see it."
Thus did they converse; but the others, when they had finished their
work and the feast was ready, left off working, and took each his
proper place on the benches and seats. Then they began eating; by and
by old Dolius and his sons left their work and came up, for their
mother, the Sicel woman wh'looked after Laertes now that he was
growing old, had been t'fetch them. When they saw Ulysses and were
certain it was he, they stood there lost in astonishment; but Ulysses
scolded them good naturedly and said, "Sit down t'your dinner, old
man, and never mind about your surprise; we have been wanting t'begin
for some time and have been waiting for you."
Then Dolius put out both his hands and went up t'Ulysses. "Sir," said
he, seizing his master's hand and kissing it at the wrist, "we have
long been wishing you home: and now heaven has restored you t'us after
we had given up hoping. All hail, therefore, and may the gods prosper
you.187 But tell me, does Penelope already know of your return, or
shall we send some one t'tell her?"
"Old man," answered Ulysses, "she knows already, s'you need not
trouble about that." On this he took his seat, and the sons of Dolius
gathered round Ulysses t'give him greeting and embrace him one after
the other; then they took their seats in due order near Dolius their
father.
While they were thus busy getting their dinner ready, Rumour went round
the town, and noised abroad the terrible fate that had befallen the
suitors; as soon, therefore, as the people heard of it they gathered
from every quarter, groaning and hooting before the house of Ulysses.
They took the dead away, buried every man his own, and put the bodies
of those wh'came from elsewhere on board the fishing vessels, for the
fishermen t'take each of them t'his own place. They then met angrily
in the place of assembly, and when they were got together Eupeithes
rose t'speak. He was overwhelmed with grief for the death of his son
Antinous, wh'had been the first man killed by Ulysses, s'he said,
weeping bitterly, "My friends, this man has done the Achaeans great
wrong. He took many of our best men away with him in his fleet, and he
has lost both ships and men; now, moreover, on his return he has been
killing all the foremost men among the Cephallenians. Let us be up and
doing before he can get away t'Pylos or t'Elis where the Epeans rule,
or we shall be ashamed of ourselves for ever afterwards. It will be an
everlasting disgrace t'us if we d'not avenge the murder of our sons
and brothers. For my own part I should have n'more pleasure in life,
but had rather die at once. Let us be up, then, and after them, before
they can cross over t'the main land."
He wept as he spoke and every one pitied him. But Medon and the bard
Phemius had now woke up, and came t'them from the house of Ulysses.
Every one was astonished at seeing them, but they stood in the middle
of the assembly, and Medon said, "Hear me, men of Ithaca. Ulysses did
not d'these things against the will of heaven. I myself saw an
immortal god take the form of Mentor and stand beside him. This god
appeared, now in front of him encouraging him, and now going furiously
about the court and attacking the suitors whereon they fell thick on
one another."
On this pale fear laid hold of them, and old Halitherses, son of
Mastor, rose t'speak, for he was the only man among them wh'knew both
past and future; s'he spoke t'them plainly and in all honesty,
saying,
"Men of Ithaca, it is all your own fault that things have turned out as
they have; you would not listen t'me, nor yet t'Mentor, when we bade
you check the folly of your sons wh'were doing much wrong in the
wantonness of their hearts—wasting the substance and dishonouring the
wife of a chieftain wh'they thought would not return. Now, however,
let it be as I say, and d'as I tell you. D'not g'out against
Ulysses, or you may find that you have been drawing down evil on your
own heads."
This was what he said, and more than half raised a loud shout, and at
once left the assembly. But the rest stayed where they were, for the
speech of Halitherses displeased them, and they sided with Eupeithes;
they therefore hurried off for their armour, and when they had armed
themselves, they met together in front of the city, and Eupeithes led
them on in their folly. He thought he was going t'avenge the murder of
his son, whereas in truth he was never t'return, but was himself to
perish in his attempt.
Then Minerva said t'Jove, "Father, son of Saturn, king of kings,
answer me this question—What d'you propose t'do? Will you set them
fighting still further, or will you make peace between them?"
And Jove answered, "My child, why should you ask me? Was it not by your
own arrangement that Ulysses came home and took his revenge upon the
suitors? D'whatever you like, but I will tell you what I think will be
most reasonable arrangement. Now that Ulysses is revenged, let them
swear t'a solemn covenant, in virtue of which he shall continue to
rule, while we cause the others t'forgive and forget the massacre of
their sons and brothers. Let them then all become friends as
heretofore, and let peace and plenty reign."
This was what Minerva was already eager t'bring about, s'down she
darted from off the topmost summits of Olympus.
Now when Laertes and the others had done dinner, Ulysses began by
saying, "Some of you g'out and see if they are not getting close up to
us." S'one of Dolius's sons went as he was bid. Standing on the
threshold he could see them all quite near, and said t'Ulysses, "Here
they are, let us put on our armour at once."
They put on their armour as fast as they could—that is t'say Ulysses,
his three men, and the six sons of Dolius. Laertes als'and Dolius did
the same—warriors by necessity in spite of their grey hair. When they
had all put on their armour, they opened the gate and sallied forth,
Ulysses leading the way.
Then Jove's daughter Minerva came up t'them, having assumed the form
and voice of Mentor. Ulysses was glad when he saw her, and said t'his
son Telemachus, "Telemachus, now that you are about t'fight in an
engagement, which will show every man's mettle, be sure not t'disgrace
your ancestors, wh'were eminent for their strength and courage all the
world over."
"You say truly, my dear father," answered Telemachus, "and you shall
see, if you will, that I am in n'mind t'disgrace your family."
Laertes was delighted when he heard this. "Good heavens," he exclaimed,
"what a day I am enjoying: I d'indeed rejoice at it. My son and
grandson are vying with one another in the matter of valour."
On this Minerva came close up t'him and said, "Son of Arceisius—-best
friend I have in the world—pray t'the blue-eyed damsel, and t'Jove
her father; then poise your spear and hurl it."
As she spoke she infused fresh vigour int'him, and when he had prayed
t'her he poised his spear and hurled it. He hit Eupeithes' helmet, and
the spear went right through it, for the helmet stayed it not, and his
armour rang rattling round him as he fell heavily t'the ground.
Meantime Ulysses and his son fell upon the front line of the foe and
smote them with their swords and spears; indeed, they would have killed
every one of them, and prevented them from ever getting home again,
only Minerva raised her voice aloud, and made every one pause. "Men of
Ithaca," she cried, "cease this dreadful war, and settle the matter at
once without further bloodshed."
On this pale fear seized every one; they were s'frightened that their
arms dropped from their hands and fell upon the ground at the sound of
the goddess' voice, and they fled back t'the city for their lives. But
Ulysses gave a great cry, and gathering himself together swooped down
like a soaring eagle. Then the son of Saturn sent a thunderbolt of fire
that fell just in front of Minerva, s'she said t'Ulysses, "Ulysses,
noble son of Laertes, stop this warful strife, or Jove will be angry
with you."
Thus spoke Minerva, and Ulysses obeyed her gladly. Then Minerva assumed
the form and voice of Mentor, and presently made a covenant of peace
